TITLE: Campaign to Halt Evictions
GOALDESC: "against home evictions" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/20/social-pressure-halts-evictions-temporarily-in-spain/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Plataforma de Afectados por la Hipoteca (PAH) "  INFORMAL "stopdesahucios"  "Associations and platforms that formed in protest against home evictions" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/20/social-pressure-halts-evictions-temporarily-in-spain/, http://afectadosporlahipoteca.com/contacto/
TARGDESC: "the Asociación Española de Banca (Spanish Banking Association)" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/20/social-pressure-halts-evictions-temporarily-in-spain/, http://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asociaci%C3%B3n_Espa%C3%B1ola_de_Banca
PARTOFF: "In such an unjust climate that has already led to great social discontent, camping out at bank headquarters, and even various suicides of people who were going to be evicted from their homes" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/20/social-pressure-halts-evictions-temporarily-in-spain/, "the recent camp-out of those affected in the Plaza de Celenque in Madrid" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/20/social-pressure-halts-evictions-temporarily-in-spain/
OUTDESC: "Both the announcement of the Spanish Banking Association as well as the recent awareness of politicians can be seen as a success of citizen pressure. ... The affected person added that the solution is not a moratorium but rather a law that contains the three points that PAH has emphasized." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/20/social-pressure-halts-evictions-temporarily-in-spain/
NARR: Campaign to Halt Evictions is a housing campaign aiming to stop evictions with the initiator(s), citizens, based in Spain and the target(s), the housing association based in Spain. Digital activity consisted of mciroblogs, and social networks. Offline activity consisted of protest actions. The structure of the campaign can best be described as large and loose. As of May 7, 2013 the campaign is possibly over, with success partially reached. KS

TITLE: Against Open-Pit Mining in Phulbari
GOALDESC: "not to start the operations." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/25/protests-in-phulbari-against-open-pit-coal-mining-project/
INITDESC: INDIV "local communities have come together to raise their voices against the proposed Phulbari open pit coal mining project." "Journalist and blogger Prabir Kumar Sarker writes" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/25/protests-in-phulbari-against-open-pit-coal-mining-project/
TARGDESC: "demonstrators calling on the government of Bangladesh to halt the Phulbari Coal Mine" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/25/protests-in-phulbari-against-open-pit-coal-mining-project/
PARTOFF: "Thousands of people took to the streets defying the ban and today is the second day [bn] of general strike in Phulbari." "Thousands of people brave police barricades to demonstrate in Phulbari, defying government ban" ,"Several thousand people break through police barricades and take to the streets in Phulbari to defy government ban on public gatherings."- http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/25/protests-in-phulbari-against-open-pit-coal-mining-project/
OUTDESC: "‘The acceptance of the complaints by OECD for investigation into the alleged human rights violation at Phulbari coalmine site dealt a serious blow to GCM, which has been struggling since late 1990s to get government approval for exploration of the coalmine with an estimated reserve of 572 million tonnes of high-quality bituminous coal’, reports the pro-GCM newspaper the Financial Express. " - http://phulbarisolidaritygroup.wordpress.com/
NARR: Against Open-Pit Mining in Phulbari is an environmental-protection campaign aimed at stopping the construction of an open-pit mine, with the initiators, residents of Phulbari, based in Bangladesh, and the target, Global Coal Management, based in the UK. Digital activity consisted of blog posts. Offline activity consisted of protests with thousands of people in Phulbari, Bangladesh. The structure of the campaign seems to be an informal grouping of Phulbari residents. As of May 19, 2013, the campaign has achieved partial success, since the government assented to negotiations. JL

TITLE: For Romanian Language Recognition in Moldovan Constitution
GOALDESC: " demanding the authorities to replace the phrasing “Moldovan language” with “Romanian language” from the highly disputed 13th Article of the Moldovan Constitution." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/01/moldova-our-romanian-language-day-protest/
INITDESC: INDIV "the Moldovan netizens organized via Facebook [ro] a protest " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/01/moldova-our-romanian-language-day-protest/
TARGDESC: "The Government and the Parliament need to create the necessary conditions to protect and promote “the state language” " -http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/01/moldova-our-romanian-language-day-protest/
PARTOFF: "Around 200 people, from more than 1000 who had signed up on the Facebook page, actually turned up at the protest held on August 30 in capital Chisinau." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/01/moldova-our-romanian-language-day-protest/
OUTDESC: "The Constitution of Moldova (Title I, Article 13) states that the Moldovan language is the official language of the country." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moldovan_language
NARR: For Romanian Language Recognition in Moldovan Constitution is a cultural rights campaign aiming to get the Moldovan Constitution to recognize the national language as Romanian. It was initiated by Moldovan citizens and targets government authorities. Digital activity consisted of a Facebook-organized event and blogging about the issue. Offline activity consisted of the event itself, in Chisinau. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a group of concerned citizens coming together for a single tactic.  As of July 16, 2013 the campaign is not a success. The Constitution still recognizes Moldovan as the official language. MJ

TITLE: Nepal, Give Back Our Ballot Boxes Now
GOALDESC: "[against] Nepal’s actions in confiscating their ballot boxes" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/10/04/exiled-tibetans-protesting-seizing-of-ballot-boxes-in-nepal/
INITDESC: INDIV "Angry Tibetans" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/10/04/exiled-tibetans-protesting-seizing-of-ballot-boxes-in-nepal/, FORMAL "Students For a Free Tibet" - https://www.studentsforafreetibet.org/
PARTOFF: "Angry Tibetans around the world are condemning Nepal’s actions in confiscating their ballot boxes by protesting in front of the Nepalese consulates" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/10/04/exiled-tibetans-protesting-seizing-of-ballot-boxes-in-nepal/
OUTDESC: "On February 13, 2011, Nepal police in riot gear shut down local elections for the leadership of a Tibetan community group. The police action was the latest police harassment of Nepal’s long-staying Tibetan community and underscores Nepalese authorities’ effort to prohibit what it perceives as “anti-China” activities by Tibetans in its territory." - http://www.savetibet.org/nepal-police-seize-ballot-boxes-in-kathmandus-tibetan-community-for-second-time/
NARR: Nepal, Give Back Our Ballot Boxes Now is a democracy and rule of law campaign aimed at stopping the Nepalese government from seizing ballot boxes, with the initiators, exiled Tibetans, based in unspecified nations, and the target, the Nepalese government, based in Nepal. Digital activity consisted of nearly 16,000 Facebook page likes, blogs, and video. Offline activity consisted of a protest with fewer than 10 participants in New York. The structure of the campaign appears to be a network of expatriate Tibetan activists and supporters. As of July 3, 2013, the campaign has not achieved any success at all, since the Nepalese government continued to seize ballot boxes and no response was issued. JL

TITLE: Against End of Philosophy Program at Middlesex University
GOALDESC: "Students at Middlesex have started an online protest campaign, and more than 12,000 people have signed an internet petition attacking the closure plan. This weekend they are holding a series of lectures and debates on their Trent Park campus to create an "alternative educational experience" and promote the "ethos" of their philosophy department.", http://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/09/middlesex-university-cuts-protest-philosophers
INITDESC: INDIV, "Students at Middlesex have started an online protest campaign, and more than 12,000 people have signed an internet petition attacking the closure plan. This weekend they are holding a series of lectures and debates on their Trent Park campus to create an "alternative educational experience" and promote the "ethos" of their philosophy department.", http://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/09/middlesex-university-cuts-protest-philosophers
SITE: "online protest campaign" referenced with no link – http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/may/09/middlesex-university-cuts-protest-philosophers
PARTOFF: "Students at Middlesex have started an online protest campaign, and more than 12,000 people have signed an internet petition attacking the closure plan. This weekend they are holding a series of lectures and debates on their Trent Park campus to create an "alternative educational experience" and promote the "ethos" of their philosophy department.", http://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/09/middlesex-university-cuts-protest-philosophers
OUTDESC: "In early June 2010 it was announced that the department's postgraduate component, the CRMEP, was to be transferred to Kingston University but the undergraduate programme still to be phased out.[11]", https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middlesex_University#Restructuring
NARR: Against End of Philosophy Program at Middlesex University is an education campaign aiming to keep a U.K. philosophy program alive, initiated by U.K. students and international professors. Digital activity consisted of an online petition. Offline activity consisted of a sit-in and letters to the editor in London, U.K. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose network. As of 26 June 2013, the campaign is partially successful because the postgraduate program was transferred but not canceled; the undergrad program was still canceled. RM

NARR: Against Digg Version 4 Changes is an entertainment campaign aiming to protest Digg's software changes with the initiator(s), Digg users, and the target(s), Digg, based in the USA. As of June 25, 2013 the campaign is over, having won rollback of some of the disliked features. FE

TITLE: Against a Hungarian Media Law
GOALDESC: ""Uncle Orban" -- as some call the prime minister -- will change the law.." - http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/01/13/hungary.protest/index.html
INITDESC: INDIV "The protests have been brewing and organizing on social networks and blogs," , "Many members of the Facebook generation in Hungary don't trust that "Uncle Orban" -- as some call the prime minister -- will change the law." -http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/01/13/hungary.protest/index.html
TARGDESC: "Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban saying last week that he will change the law if the European Union wants." - http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/01/13/hungary.protest/index.html
BLOG: "protests have been brewing and organizing on ... blogs" - http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/01/13/hungary.protest/index.html, "A blogger of the site Antagon writes that many journalists who have been silent about government scandals" - http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/01/13/hungary.protest/index.html, "Other bloggers support digital activism: Polblog calls for a "blackout4hungary"-day" - http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/01/13/hungary.protest/index.html
PARTOFF: "Protesters who banded together online are expected to take to the streets of Hungary on Friday", "More than 6,000 people have signed up to a Facebook site saying they will join a demonstration planned for Friday in Kossuth-Square outside the parliament in Budapest," - http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/01/13/hungary.protest/index.html
OUTDESC: "Parliament, where the ruling center-right Fidesz party holds a two-thirds majority, voted by 258 to 65 to pass the amendments, with 38 abstentions." - http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/07/us-hungary-media-vote-idUSTRE7265RN20110307
NARR: Against a Hungarian Media Law is an information and expression campaign aimed at repealing a restrictive media law, with the initiators, online activists, based in unspecified nations, and the target, the Hungarian prime minister, based in Hungary. Digital activity consisted of over 100,000 Facebook page likes, blog posts, and unspecified numbers of tweets with no organized hashtag campaign. There is no indication of offline activity, though demonstrations are apparently planned. The structure of the campaign appears to be an almost entirely grassroots upwelling of concerned individuals. As of July 9, 2013, the campaign has achieved partial success, since the Hungarian parliament amended the law but did not strike it down. JL

NARR: Qantas: Allow Musical Instruments Onboard is a campaign launched by an Australian musician to get an Australian airline company to admit musical instruments as carry-on items. INITDESC: INDIV "people" - http://www.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/online-protest-stops-trucks-20100213-nyej.html

Digital activity consisted of 2,783 Facebook page likes. Offline activity consisted of 700 objections tendered to the council. The structure of the campaign appears to be spearheaded by an individual concerned citizen using social media to organize supporters. TITLE: Stop Australian Internet Blackout Bill
GOALDESC: "against government plans to push forward legislation that will lead to blanket censorship of the internet for Australian users" - http://www.futureconscience.com/the-great-australian-internet-blackout/
INITDESC: INDIV "activist Jeff Waugh" - http://www.futureconscience.com/the-great-australian-internet-blackout/, INFORMAL "Electronic Frontiers Australia" - http://www.futureconscience.com/the-great-australian-internet-blackout/
SITE: "Over 500 websites are taking part in the protest ... all of whom will be blacking out their website" - http://www.futureconscience.com/the-great-australian-internet-blackout/
OUTDESC: "On 5 August 2010, the Coalition parties announced that they would not vote for the policy, making it virtually impossible for the filtering scheme to pass" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_Australia
NARR: Stop Australian Internet Blackout Bill is an information and expression campaign aimed at stopping an internet-filter bill from passing in Australia, with the initiators, activist Jeff Waugh and Electronic Frontier Australia, based in Australia, and the target, the Australian government, also based in Australia. Digital activity consisted of digital protest actions conducted by 500 websites and an unspecified number of social-network users. There was no indication of offline activity. The structure of the campaign is spearheaded by a prominent, concerned individual in conjunction with a professional advocacy group. As of July 9, 2013, the campaign has achieved partial success, since the Coalition government said that it does not support the bill, but it remains unclear whether these members of government were able to overturn the bill. JL

TITLE: Against Arial Beel Airport
GOALDESC: "Environmental activists pointed out that the move to erase the wetlands would severely impact both environment as well as livlihoods of the local people living in the beel area.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/13/bangladesh-proposed-international-airport-stumbles-over-environment-controversy/
INITDESC: FORMAL, "Soon however, the issue got politicised, with the leading opposition party, the BNP, joining hands with the protesters and raising the volume of the protests and agitations to thwart the proposed land acquisition.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/13/bangladesh-proposed-international-airport-stumbles-over-environment-controversy/
PARTOFF: "The unrest soon spread and when the government tried to use the police force to control the protests, violence erupted in the area which left 1 policeman dead and over 100 injured.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/13/bangladesh-proposed-international-airport-stumbles-over-environment-controversy/
OUTDESC: "The government is going to appoint a consultant for construction of Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujib International Airport in Munshiganj amid protests from locals and socio-political organisations.", http://news.priyo.com/government/2011/jan/31/18587/govt-goes-ahead-airport-project-arial-beel
NARR: Against Arial Beel Airport is an environmental-protection campaign aimed at stopping the construction of an airport at Ariel Beel, with the initiators, Ariel Beel citizens, based in Bangladesh and the target, the prime minister, also based in Bangladesh. Digital activity consisted of blog posts. Offline activity consisted of protests with at least 100 participants. The structure of the campaign appears to be a combination of grassroots citizen activity and political-party organization. As of June 24, 2013, the campaign has been partially successful, since officials responded to protestors' concerns but are building the airport anyway. JL

TITLE: Against Electoral Fraud in Belarus
GOALDESC: "If on the 19th, this [bastardly] regime does not collapse, I don't even know… [...] To tolerate this filth and these jerks for five more years – it is physically impossible by now!!!" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/12/19/belarus-presidential-election-day-ends-in-protests-and-crackdown/
INITDESC: INDIV "Thousands of people gathered in the center of Minsk ", "Dmitry Rastaev (LJ user rastaev) commented (RUS) on the supposedly voluntary “early voting”  - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/12/19/belarus-presidential-election-day-ends-in-protests-and-crackdown/
TARGDESC: " to storm the government headquarters and the central election commission building" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/12/19/belarus-presidential-election-day-ends-in-protests-and-crackdown/
PARTOFF: "Thousands of people gathered in the center of Minsk to protest " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/12/19/belarus-presidential-election-day-ends-in-protests-and-crackdown/
OUTDESC: "Of the ten candidates, incumbent President Alexander Lukashenko was declared the winner by the Central Election Commission with 79.67% of the votes. Andrej Sannika? (Andrei Sannikov) received the second-highest percentage.[3][4] After a protest was violently suppressed by riot police the night after the election,[5] hundreds of protesters and seven presidential candidates were arrested by the KGB – including runner-up Sannika?.[6]" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belarusian_presidential_election,_2010
NARR: Against Electoral Fraud in Belarus is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to protest election fraud with the initiator(s), Belarusian citizens, based in BLR and the target(s), the BLR government. Digital activity consisted of use of Twitter, blogs, video. Offline activity consisted of a large protest in Minsk, BLR. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a spontaneous offline protest documented and furthered by online netizens which still continues today. As of July 2, 2013 the campaign is not achieved since it doesn't appear anything has been done to address the issues, the protesters were put down violently, and the BLR president is still in power. DS

As of July 8, 2013 the campaign is completely succesful since the water supply was returned. DS

TITLE: End the Decree 7.056/09 in Brazil
GOALDESC: "Among the 11 demands [pt] that the indigenous representatives put forward are: the creation of CNDI (Conselho Nacional de Direitos Indígenas  – National Council for Indigenous Rights) – which would give the indigenous people autonomy in the management of their patrimony, rights and interests -, the consulting of indigenous peoples in matters related the environment and the defense of their social, cultural and religious rights, respect for indigenous land and its natural resources. The indigenous also demand the exoneration [sic?] of the President of FUNAI, Márcio Meira, and his team, for failing to attend to the above demands." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/17/brazil-indigenous-camp-resists-for-eight-months-in-brasilia/
INITDESC: FORMAL " men and women of the Pankararu, Korubo, Mundurucu, Krahô-Canela and Fulni-ô ethnicities" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/17/brazil-indigenous-camp-resists-for-eight-months-in-brasilia/
PARTOFF: no numbers "Since early in January this year, members of different indigenous Brazilian nations have been camping out in front of the Ministry of Justice in Brasília " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/17/brazil-indigenous-camp-resists-for-eight-months-in-brasilia/
OUTDESC: August 2012: "Unfortunately, in recent years, the federal government has no dialogues nor consulted indigenous peoples in important decisions that concern their physical and cultural security. Including having modified without dialogue and transparency also unto the servants, the structure of the Funai official through Decree 7.056/09 and 7.778/12, hindering the fulfillment of its institutional mission in defense of indigenous peoples." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/17/brazil-indigenous-camp-resists-for-eight-months-in-brasilia/
NARR: End the Decree 7.056/09 in Brazil is a rights of ethnic minorities and immigrants campaign aiming to end a particular decree which is leading to the extermination of particular indigenous groups with the initiator(s), the informal group AIR, based in BRA and the target(s), the BRA government, FUNAI, and NGOs based in BRA. Digital activity consisted of use of a website and blogs. Offline activity consisted of extended protests and camping in front of the national congress in BRA. The structure of the campaign can best be described as organized around a specific informal group that seems to represent the larger interests of Brazilian indigenous groups; semi-professionally organized, extended in nature. As of June 25, 2013 the campaign is completely unsucessful since it doesn't appear the protesters have been recognized at all. DS

TITLE: Against Brazil's New Forest Code
GOALDESC: "maintain the current Forestry Code." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/20/brazil-future-of-forests-at-stake/
INITDESC: FORMAL "environmental NGOs like Greenpeace Brazil and WWF-Brazil and institutes such as ISA – Instituto Socioambiental (Socio-Environmental Institute) – and IPAM – Instituto de Pesquisa Ambiental da Amazônia (Environmental Research Institute of the Amazon) – joined their forces in 2010 to fight against the new Code." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/20/brazil-future-of-forests-at-stake/
OUTDESC: "Brazil's president used her veto power to slash through the new Forest Code, making the environmental law a little tougher on large agricultural interests by strengthening reforestation requirements along river banks, a decree published by the government said Thursday." - http://www.businessweek.com/ap/2012-10-19/brazils-president-line-vetoes-new-forest-code
NARR: Against Brazil's New Forest Code is a environmental protection campaign aiming to fight against a new forestry code with the initiator(s), various formal organizations based in Brazil, and the target(s), the Brazilian President. Digital activity consisted of a website, EPET, blogs, video, and Twitter. Offline activity consisted of protests in Jacobina, Bahia and Sao Paulo. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a very organized coalition of formal organizations working effectively for a goal. As of June 18, 2013 the campaign is completely successful, since the Brazil president vetoed the new Forest Code. DS

TITLE: Against  Thermal Energy Project Near Punta de Choros
GOALDESC: "[against the] approval of a thermal energy project [in Chile]" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/27/chile-strong-citizen-response-against-thermal-energy-project/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "The environmental movement Chaopescao" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/27/chile-strong-citizen-response-against-thermal-energy-project/, INDIV "concerned citizens" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/27/chile-strong-citizen-response-against-thermal-energy-project/
TARGDESC: "the Regional Environmental Commission of the Coquimbo Region" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/27/chile-strong-citizen-response-against-thermal-energy-project/
SOCNET: "What started with ... Facebook status updates ... concluded with more than 3,000 people protesting the decision in downtown Santiago" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/27/chile-strong-citizen-response-against-thermal-energy-project/, "In the wall of the Facebook group “Salvemos Punta de Choros” [es] (Let’s Save Punta de Choros), which as of today has 52,525 “likes,” thousands of users commented against the project" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/27/chile-strong-citizen-response-against-thermal-energy-project/
PARTOFF: "more than 3,000 people protesting the decision in downtown Santiago" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/27/chile-strong-citizen-response-against-thermal-energy-project/
OUTDESC: "Today, President Piñera (@sebastianpinera) said the project would not be built near Punta de Choros, but rather elsewhere" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/27/chile-strong-citizen-response-against-thermal-energy-project/
NARR: Against  Thermal Energy Project Near Punta de Choros is an environmental campaign aiming to stop the construction of a thermal electricity plant close from a reserve of Penguins in Atacama desert in Chile. The initiator(s) are an informal environmental group and individuals from Chile. The target is the government of the country only hierarchy with power over the regional approval of the construction. Online activity consisted in thousands of Twitts, a Facebook page with more than 100k members, videos and several blog spots. Offline activity mainly consisted of marches on the capital Santiago in the day of the approval of the construction. The structure of the campaign can be best described as a NGO network of organizations led by an informal group followed by a crowd. Up to June 27, 2013 the campaign has achieved its goals, the president directly intervened and rejected the construction of the plant in that site. LS

TITLE: Free Chen Guangcheng
GOALDESC: "Chinese activists have been campaigning to free Chen Guangcheng and his family from house arrest."  - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/13/china-campaign-to-free-blind-human-rights-activist/
INITDESC: FORMAL "non-governmental organisation China Human Rights Defenders" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/13/china-campaign-to-free-blind-human-rights-activist/
PARTOFF: "a number of human rights activists staged a cultural T-shirt protest [zh] in front of the Shandong regional government office in Beijing." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/13/china-campaign-to-free-blind-human-rights-activist/
OUTDESC: "On 22 April 2012, Chen escaped from house arrest" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chen_Guangcheng#Escape_and_emigration
NARR: Free Chen Guangcheng is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to free from his house arrest a blind Chinese activist in Shandong, a province in eastern China.. The initiators are individuals and NGOs with the based in China  and the target(s), is the Chinese government. Digital activity in this campaign consisted of a youtube video and blog posts. Offline activity consisted of the coordination for helping him to escape to Beijing. The structure of the campaign can best be described as international campaign in which Human rights organizations are involved.  As of  June 14, 2013 the campaign has not achieved its goals but the prisoner escaped. LS

TITLE: Governor Li Hongzhong: Resign
GOALDESC: "demanding Li Hongzhong's resignation." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/03/13/china-journalists-unite-to-demand-governors-resignation/
INITDESC: "journalists, academics and others from across the country" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/03/13/china-journalists-unite-to-demand-governors-resignation/
EPET: "launched a petition demanding Li Hongzhong's resignation." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/03/13/china-journalists-unite-to-demand-governors-resignation/
OUTDESC: "Formerly he was Governor of Hubei and Communist Party Chief and Mayor of Shenzhen, Guangdong province" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Li_Hongzhong
NARR: Governor Li Hongzhong: Resign is a press freedom campaign aiming to get a Chinese governor who mistreated a journalist to resign. It was initiated by a group of Chinese journalists and academics.  Digital activity consisted of an e-petition and some discussion on Twitter. There does not appear to have been any offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a single small tactic put forth by a group of individuals, with some additional discussion on the topic online. As of July 2, 2013 the campaign is a partial succes.  Li is no longer governor of Hubei, but he still holds a high position within the state's Communist party.  It is also unclear if he resigned or left for other reasons.  MJ

TITLE: Against Forced Land Acquisition in Longxu
GOALDESC: "[against] the government-led Canghai artificial lake project" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/10/16/china-riot-against-land-acquisition-in-guangxi/
INITDESC: INDIV "[Longxu] villagers" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/10/16/china-riot-against-land-acquisition-in-guangxi/
BLOG: "blogger lovol888888 compiles informations from different sources" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/10/16/china-riot-against-land-acquisition-in-guangxi/, http://blog.udn.com/kalaok/4497595
PARTOFF: "Around one thousand villagers confronted armed police against forced land acquisition." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/10/16/china-riot-against-land-acquisition-in-guangxi/
OUTDESC: No information on action taken to address demands - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/10/16/china-riot-against-land-acquisition-in-guangxi/
NARR: Against Forced Land Acquisition in Longxu is an economic justice campaign aimed at stopping an artificial-lake project, with the initiators, Longxu villagers, based in China, and the targets, local government officials, also based in China. Digital activity consisted of blog posts. Offline activity consisted of a riot in Longxu, China, with about a thousand participants. The structure of the campaign appears to be a grassroots uprising by concerned individuals with little organization. As of July 2, 2013, there is no indication of the campaign's success or failure, as there has been no response or action. JL

TITLE: For the Legalization of Sex Work in China
GOALDESC: "for the legalization of prostitution [in China]" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/01/china-sex-workers-demand-legalization-organizer-detained/
INITDESC: INDIV "Sex workers and their supporters" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/01/china-sex-workers-demand-legalization-organizer-detained/
PARTOFF: "Sex workers and their supporters in south central China's Wuhan took to the streets with red umbrellas last Wednesday" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/01/china-sex-workers-demand-legalization-organizer-detained/
OUTDESC: "Beijing has shown no sign of moving towards legalizing voluntary sex work in recent years, preferring to regard it as a social problem to be fixed by criminal raids, activists said." - http://www.rfa.org/english/news/china/attacks-05142013143006.html
NARR: For the Legalization of Sex Work in China is a gender and sexuality campaign aiming to legalize prostitution with the initiator(s), sex workers and their supporters, based in CHN and the target(s), the Chinese government. Digital activity consisted of use of video, Twitter, blogs, and a website. Offline activity consisted of at least two people spreading information in south central China's Wuhan. The structure of the campaign can best be described asnot really united, but coming at the issue from multiple angles; some are sprading the word on the street, some are posting on blogs, some writing editorials. As of July 1, 2013 the campaign is completely unsuccessful since nothing seems to have changed as of May 2013. DS

TITLE: Against University Budget Agreement in Costa Rica
GOALDESC: "[against] the budgetary agreement that was reached between the government and university officials where a 7% budget increase was agreed upon after negotiating the original 4% the government proposed" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/29/costa-rica-university-students-protest-budget-agreements/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "FEUCR (University of Costa Rica Student Federation)" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/29/costa-rica-university-students-protest-budget-agreements/, FORMAL "UCR Employee Syndicate (SINDEU)" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/29/costa-rica-university-students-protest-budget-agreements/
PARTOFF: "Some University of Costa Rica students took hold of the social sciences building in protest of the budgetary agreement' - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/29/costa-rica-university-students-protest-budget-agreements/, "A group of students headed by the FEUCR (University of Costa Rica Student Federation) and the UCR Employee Syndicate (SINDEU) invaded the University Council session room" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/29/costa-rica-university-students-protest-budget-agreements/
OUTDESC: "the University authorities reached an agreement with the groups of students stating that they would not cut scholarships, quotas or decrease in the efforts to strengthen the other university sites" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/08/29/costa-rica-university-students-protest-budget-agreements/
NARR: Against University Budget Agreement in Costa Rica is an education campaign aimed at raising the University of Costa Rica's budget increase, with the initiators, the University of Costa Rica Student Federation and the UCR Employee Syndicate, based in Costa Rica, and the target, the UCR Council, also based in Costa Rica. Digital activity consisted of a blog and videos. Offline activity consisted of an unspecified number of students entering a Council meeting uninvited as well as taking over a university building. The structure of the campaign is a coalition between two existing university organizations. As of July 3, 2013, the campaign has been partially successful, since the university acceded to some secondary demands but ultimately did not raise the budget. JL

TITLE: 4% for Education
GOALDESC: "for 4% of GDP for education" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/12/24/dominican-republic-demanding-4-of-national-budget-for-education/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Coalición por una Educación Digna" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/12/24/dominican-republic-demanding-4-of-national-budget-for-education/
VIDEO: "a video made the rounds on the Internet that explained the education realities in the Dominican Republic" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/12/24/dominican-republic-demanding-4-of-national-budget-for-education/, http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=0_yZWrdN2_U
PARTOFF: "The consequence has been that since the first days of November there have been several protests in various parts of the country" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/12/24/dominican-republic-demanding-4-of-national-budget-for-education/
OUTDESC: "Medina's letter to Congress says the 2013 budget is in keeping with the promises contained in his government program, especially the allocation of 4% of GDP for the pre-university education" - http://www.dominicantoday.com/dr/economy/2012/12/12/46059/Education-the-big-winner-in-Dominican-Republic-US133B-Budget
NARR: 4% for Education is an education campaign aimed at requiring that the Dominican Republic's government spend four percent of GDP on elementary and secondary education, with the initiators, Coalición por una Educación Digna, based in the DR, and the target, Congress, also based in the DR. Digital activity consisted of unspecified numbers of Facebook and Twitter users, websites, blogs, and videos. Offline activity consisted of protests at Congress with unspecified numbers of participants. The structure of the campaign is led by an organized but informal organization. As of 7/7/2013, the campaign has been completely successful because the government has agreed to the 4% allocation. JL

TITLE: Against Barrick Gold in the Dominican Republic
GOALDESC: "[against] the terms of the agreement with [Barrick Gold and] the Dominican State, as well as environmental impacts on the [Cotui] region" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/03/28/dominican-republic-opposition-to-barrick-gold-mining-operations/
INITDESC: INDIV "Activists" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/03/28/dominican-republic-opposition-to-barrick-gold-mining-operations/
PARTOFF: "there have been public protests" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/03/28/dominican-republic-opposition-to-barrick-gold-mining-operations/
OUTDESC: "The Dominican Republic and Barrick Gold Corp have reached a preliminary agreement to boost the government's cut of profits from a gold mine in the Caribbean nation" - http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/09/barrick-dominican-idUSL2N0DP3AU20130509
NARR: Against Barrick Gold in the Dominican Republic is an economic-justice campaign aimed at forcing Barrick Gold out of the Dominican Republic, with the initiators, activists, based in the Dominican Republic, and the target, Barrick Gold, based in Canada. Digital activity consisted of 67 Facebook group members and blogs. Offline activity consisted of a planned march in the DR with 10,000 participants. The structure of the campaign appears to be a coordinated effort by individual DR activists. As of July 6, 2013, the campaign has been partially successful, as Barrick Gold renegotiated a contract more favorable to the DR but did not leave the country. JL

TITLE: Campaign Inspired by Murder of Khaled Said
GOALDESC: "against police torture and to demand a new independent autopsy on Saeed’s body" - http://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2010/07/egyp-j19.html
INITDESC: INDIV "Egyptian youth" - http://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2010/07/egyp-j19.html
SOCNET: "the “My Name is Khaled Saeed” group had attracted more than 255,000 members" - http://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2010/07/egyp-j19.html
MICBLOG: "Egyptian youth have organised a series of protests ... using online social network sites such as ... Twitter" - http://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2010/07/egyp-j19.html
VIDEO: "with the case attracting international attention after the publishing of online video reports" - http://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2010/07/egyp-j19.html,
PARTOFF: "In Cairo, protests were held at the October 6 Bridge, Qasr El-Nil Bridge, at the journalists’ union office in the city centre, and in the Maadi suburb. Other protests were held in the Cleopatra neighbourhood of Alexandria where Saeed lived, Assiyut in Upper Egypt, and in Mansoura, in the Delta region" - http://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2010/07/egyp-j19.html
OUTDESC: "A lawyer said the court convicted the two policemen of manslaughter ... Relatives of Said said they had expected a tougher sentence" - http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/15467022
NARR: Campaign Inspired by Murder of Khaled Said is a opposing violence and armed conflict campaign aiming to protest police violence after the murder of an Egyptian man with the initiator(s), Egyptian youth, based in EGY and the target(s), Egyptian police and authorities. Digital activity consisted of the use of Facebook, Twitter, and video. Offline activity consisted of many protests in various parts of Egypt. The structure of the campaign can best be described as not organized around any particular organization, but rather a mass of Egyptian youth brought together by a Facebook group and information on Twitter and video. As of July 1, 2013 the campaign is partially successful since a new autoposy on the body was conducted and 2 police officers were sentenced to jail; however, the authorities who ordered the killing were not jailed. DS

TITLE: For Better Living Conditions in Egypt
GOALDESC: "On 2 May, Cairo was set to witness a nationwide workers’ strike to demand an increase in the national minimum wage.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/05/02/egypt-a-strike-for-minimum-wages/
INITDESC: " A group of activists made a website/blog to promote the strike and cover it, as well as collect all social media material into one place," http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/05/02/egypt-a-strike-for-minimum-wages/
PARTOFF: "the wave of protests, sit-ins and demonstrations demanding ", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/05/02/egypt-a-strike-for-minimum-wages/
OUTDESC: "For the first time Egypt had applied the Minimum wage from 2011. The pre-revolution law stated that there was an intention to develop a minimum wage but it never took place until after the revolution. Currently only one national rate is EGP 700. Also there is an intention to raise this minimum wage to be 1200 LE instead of 700 LE before the end of 2013.", http://www.wageindicator.org/main/salary/minimum-wage/egypt
NARR: For Better Living Conditions in Egypt is a economic justice campaign aiming to force the government to set a living minimum wage with the initiator(s), Egyptian activists, and the target(s), the Egyptian government. Digital activity consisted of use of Twitter, blogs and video. Offline activity consisted of protests in Cairo, EGY. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a group of informal protesters organized online. As of June 24, 2013 the campaign is completely successful since the court ruled to force a relevant bill through, and the protests stopped as evidenced by the halt of twitter responses on the hashtag. DS

TITLE: Against Pension Reform Bill in France
GOALDESC: "against the [French] pension reform bill" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/10/26/france-youth-against-pension-reform/
INITDESC: FORMAL "trade unions" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/10/26/france-youth-against-pension-reform/
PARTOFF: "Oil refineries have been blocked, the SNCF railway and mass transit lines have been affected by the protests, and striking air traffic controllers are causing paralysis in plane departures" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/10/26/france-youth-against-pension-reform/, "between 379 and 1200 high schools and between six and 20 universities were disrupted or blockaded" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/10/26/france-youth-against-pension-reform/
OUTDESC: "French President Nicolas Sarkozy signed the country's controversial pension reform bill Wednesday, the last step in making the bill a law" - http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/europe/11/10/france.pension.reform/index.html
NARR: Against Pension Reform Bill in France is a economic justice campaign aiming to stop the pension reform bill from passing with the initiator(s), various student and labor unions, based in FRA and the target(s), the French government. Digital activity consisted of use of Facebook, blogs, a forum, and video. Offline activity consisted of protests all throughout the country. The structure of the campaign can best be described as very organized and large in scope, requiring members of the unions to vote each day whether or not the strike should continue. As of July 2, 2013 the campaign is not achieved since Sarkozy signed the bill anyway and it does not appear he even addressed the protesters. DS

TITLE: Against Downgrading of Hospital Maternity Units
GOALDESC: "[against] the possible downgrading of three maternity units, including the one at Honiton Hospital" - http://www.thisisdevon.co.uk/Maternity-units-campaign-backed-4-400-online/story-11675425-detail/story.html#axzz2UokP1Yb2
INITDESC: INDIV "Ottery St Mary town councillor Claire Wright, one of the campaign leaders" - http://www.thisisdevon.co.uk/Maternity-units-campaign-backed-4-400-online/story-11675425-detail/story.html#axzz2UokP1Yb2
SOCNET: "An online protest on the social networking site Facebook had gathered more than 2,800 names in support of the campaign at Honiton, almost 1,000 at Tiverton and more than 600 at Okehampton" - http://www.thisisdevon.co.uk/Maternity-units-campaign-backed-4-400-online/story-11675425-detail/story.html#axzz2UokP1Yb2
OUTDESC: "NHS Devon’s board agreed in October 2010, to allow overnight stays to be reinstated, if there was a clinical need, such as help needed with breast-feeding" - http://www.claire-wright.org/index.php/post/fear_over_future_of_honitons_maternity_service_as_births_drop/%20(read%20all)
NARR: 1989 is a health campaign aiming to block the downgrading of maternity units with the initiator(s), Claire Wright, based in GBR and the target(s), NHS Devon based in GBR. Digital activity consisted of use of Facebook and a blog. No offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as relatively amateur since its only on Facebook and a blog and is localized, but one of the initiators is a local city council member, so it perhaps carries a bit more weight. As of July 10, 2013 the campaign is partially successful since there have been some promises, but nothing has actually been done. DS

TITLE: Save BBC6 Music
GOALDESC: "A vocal campaign to save BBC 6 Music from closure....proposal put forward in March by the director general, Mark Thompson, as part of a wide-ranging strategy review.", http://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/jul/05/bbc-6-music-saved
INITDESC:
INDIV, "Welcome to where the Save BBC 6Music campaign kicked off back in early January 2010
" https://www.facebook.com/groups/saved6music/
OUTDESC: "A vocal campaign to save BBC 6 Music from closure was rewarded today when the BBC Trust said the digital music station will stay open.", http://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/jul/05/bbc-6-music-saved
NARR: Save BBC6 Music is an entertainment and fandom campaign aimed at saving the BBC 6 music station, with the initiators, listeners of the station, based in the UK and the target, BBC Trust, also based in the UK. Digital activity consisted of nearly 400 Facebook group members and 25,000 emails. Offline activity consisted of 250 letters mailed. The structure of the campaign is a grassroots upwelling of angered individual listeners. As of June 26, 2013, the campaign has been completely successful, as the BBC Trust decided not to take the station off of the air. JL

TITLE: Return Swansea's Slip Bridge
GOALDESC: "for the return of Swansea's Slip Bridge" - http://www.thisissouthwales.co.uk/Protesters-bring-Slip-Bridge-bid-open/story-12469151-detail/story.html#axzz2Up7xT5Bf
INITDESC: INDIV "46-year-old Ian Howells" - http://www.thisissouthwales.co.uk/Protesters-bring-Slip-Bridge-bid-open/story-12469151-detail/story.html#axzz2Up7xT5Bf
SOCNET:
"a Facebook internet protest site has almost 1,000 members

Read more: http://www.thisissouthwales.co.uk/Protesters-bring-Slip-Bridge-bid-open/story-12469151-detail/story.html#ixzz2bKN5v3WB" -http://www.thisissouthwales.co.uk/Protesters-bring-Slip-Bridge-bid-open/story-12469151-detail/story.html#axzz2Up7xT5Bf
OUTDESC: "The famous 'Slip Bridge' a footbridge which once spanned Oystermouth Road,and Mumbles Railroad, has been relocated several hundred yards" - http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WME4TY_Slip_Bridge_Relocated_within_Swansea_Wales
NARR: 1986 is a economic justice campaign aiming to return a bridge to a town with the initiator(s), individuals from the town in question, based in GBR and the target(s), the Swansea Council based in GBR. Digital activity consisted of use of Facebook. Offline activity consisted of a protest in St Helens, GBR. The structure of the campaign can best be described as amateur individuals protesting a local city council, with offline and online engagement. As of July 10, 2013 the campaign is completely successful since the bridge has been moved back. DS

TITLE: Stop Thorpe Close Garages Being Turned into Houses
GOALDESC: "Furious residents have started an online protest to put a halt to redevelopment plans that "will eat up three quarters of their sunlight.", http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/1995-New-Addington-Advertiser.docx
INITDESC: "Furious residents have started an online protest to put a halt to redevelopment plans that "will eat up three quarters of their sunlight.", http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/1995-New-Addington-Advertiser.docx
SOCNET:
"They also say the council did not consult them properly before giving approval to the plans, and have started a group on social networking site, Facebook, to show the strength of their feelings.
It has 43 members so far", http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/1995-New-Addington-Advertiser.docx
OUTDESC:
"As the council is fully satisfied that the statutory obligation to notify neighbours of the 
proposals was undertaken and the council’s consultation with local residents went 
beyond any statutory obligation, this claim of a lack of notification of neighbours of the 
scheme proposal does not justify suspending the construction of the development.", http://www.croydon.gov.uk/contents/documents/meetings/548170/913962/2010-10-18/c20101018responsespetitions.pdf
NARR: Stop Thorpe Close Garages Being Turned into Houses is an environmental campaign aiming to stop the construction of new houses in current garage spots, because it will dark current houses. The initiator are residents of the community, in Thorpe close, London, Great Britain. The target is the Croydon Council. Digital activity consisted of a facebook page. There is not information regarding the offline participation. The structure of the campaign can be best described as a “no-in-my-back-yard” environmental campaign. Up to June 26, 2013 there is not information regarding the achievement of their goals. LS

TITLE: Against the Ban on Sweets at Arduthie Primary School in Scotland
GOALDESC: "against the restrictions [on sweet foods] imposed by school's head, Gail Macfarlane" -http://www.dnaindia.com/world/1361700/report-school-principal-slaps-ban-on-kids-receiving-sweets-for-good-behaviour
INITDESC: INDIV "parents [of students at Arduthie Primary School]" - http://www.dnaindia.com/world/1361700/report-school-principal-slaps-ban-on-kids-receiving-sweets-for-good-behaviour
TARGDESC: "The head of Arduthie Primary School in Stonehaven, Gail Macfarlane" - http://www.dnaindia.com/world/1361700/report-school-principal-slaps-ban-on-kids-receiving-sweets-for-good-behaviour
SOCNET: ""I am really angry about this nanny state mentality. The government is wrong if it thinks excluding everything makes a 'healthy' diet," the Scotsman quoted a parent, Julie Irvine, as saying on her Facebook page." - http://www.dnaindia.com/world/1361700/report-school-principal-slaps-ban-on-kids-receiving-sweets-for-good-behaviour
OUTDESC: "However, a spokeswoman for Aberdeenshire Council said: "The guidance issued by Arduthie school only applies to Arduthie school. The council will be issuing guidance to all schools regarding the national legislation in the future."" - http://www.dnaindia.com/world/1361700/report-school-principal-slaps-ban-on-kids-receiving-sweets-for-good-behaviour
NARR: Against the Ban on Sweets at Arduthie Primary School in Scotland is a health campaign aimed at removing the ban on sweets as treats, with the initiators, parents of students at the school, based in the UK, and the target, the head of the school, also based in the UK. Digital activity consisted of a Facebook page with an unspecified number of participants. There was no indication of offline activity. The structure of the campaign is a grassroots effort organized by concerned parents. As of Juy 10, 2013, it is unclear whether the campaign was successful or not, since there appears to be disagreement regarding whether the school was required to change their policy or not. JL

TITLE: Save Aylestone Meadows
GOALDESC: "to stop a nature reserve being turned into football pitches" - http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/fight-save-meadows/story-12063418-detail/story.html#ixzz2bzDlgPyU
INITDESC: FORMAL or INFORMAL (need more info) "Aylestone Meadows Appreciation Society " "Leicester Civic Society and Friends of the Earth" INDIV "campaigners" - http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/fight-save-meadows/story-12063418-detail/story.html#ixzz2bzDlgPyU
SITE: an "online protest" is referenced; no URL. – http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/fight-save-meadows/story-12063418-detail/story.html#axzz2UorNztsY
SOCNET: "So far more than 2,100 people have joined a Facebook group dedicated to saving the meadows" -  http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/fight-save-meadows/story-12063418-detail/story.html#ixzz2bzE2P4LI
PARTOFF: "The Aylestone Meadows Appreciation Society is holding a meeting on Wednesday night at the Black Horse Pub, in Narrow Lane, Aylestone, at 7.30pm, for people interested in joining the protest." - http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/fight-save-meadows/story-12063418-detail/story.html#ixzz2bzEdv5TW
OUTDESC: "Plans by Leicester City Council to bulldoze an area within the Aylestone Meadows to make way for an artificial sports pitch, single storey clubhouse and car park, were defeated on 21 March 2011 when the Planning Committee rejected the plans. " - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aylestone
NARR: Save Aylestone Meadows is an environmental campaign aiming to keep a UK wildlife refuge from being built over, initiated by UK group Aylestone Meadows Appreciation Society against the Leicester city council. Digital activity consisted of a petition and a Facebook protest group. Offline activity consisted of letter-writing and awareness-raising at local fairs. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a network of organizations. As of June 25, 2013, the campaign is successful, because the planning committee rejected the building plans after input from protestors. RM

TITLE: Against Pay Cuts for Northamptonshire County Employees

SOCNET: "A Facebook group called "Fair Pay in Schools" has already attracted more than 120 members of staff affected by the cuts" - http://www.northamptonchron.co.uk/news/local/angry-pay-cut-staff-step-up-online-protests-1-899887

NARR: Against Pay Cuts for Northamptonshire County Employees  is an economic justice campaign aiming to protest pay cuts for teachers in a British County with the initiator(s), affected workers, based in the UK and the target(s), the Northamptonshire County Council government. Digital activity consisted of facebook groups, emails to the press, and forum participation. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a group of upset workers without formal organization. As of June, 26 2013 the outcome and/or continuity of the campaign is unclear from available sources. FE

TITLE: Retake the AQA Exam
GOALDESC: "[for giving] students another paper to retake in February or March" - http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/news/4873403.print/
INITDESC: INDIV "students from Bolton School and Thornleigh Salesian College" - http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/news/4873403.print/
SOCNET: "more than 4,000 people have joined the campaign group “The AQA unit 4 biology exam (25/1/2010) was a disgrace!” on the social networking website Facebook" - http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/news/4873403.print/

NARR: Retake the AQA exam is an education campaign aimed at voiding an AQA exam and retaking it, with the initiators, students from Bolton School and Thornleigh Salesian College, based in the UK, and the target, AQA, also based in the UK. Digital activity consisted of 4,000 Facebook members. There was no indication of offline activity. The structure of the campaign is a grassroots effort led by students affected by the exam. As of July 9 2013, the campaign has been partially successful, since AQA said they would take concerns into consideration when grading but did not assent to allowing students to retake the exam. JL

TITLE: Stop Hillend Closure
GOALDESC: "[against the] threatened closure of Scotland's most famous dry ski slope" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/2002-Times-of-London.docx
INITDESC: INDIV "people" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/2002-Times-of-London.docx
SOCNET: "Since a Facebook group, called "Stop Hillend Closure", was set up just a few days ago, more than 6,000 people have joined the online protest" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/2002-Times-of-London.docx
OUTDESC: "The council duly agreed a plan to keep the centre open, involving £600,000 of investment being spent on it by Sportscotland, and the sale of green belt land near the site to developers" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midlothian_Snowsports_Centre
NARR: Stop Hillend Closure is a entertainment and fandom campaign aimed at stopping a ski slope from closing, with the initiators, unspecified people, based in the UK, and the target, the Midlothian council, also based in the UK. Digital activity consisted of 6,000 Facebook page likes. Offline activity consisted of two well-known skiiers voicing their opposition to the media. The structure of the campaign appears to be centered around the Facebook page and unaffiliated celebrity advocates. As of July 3, 2013, the campaign has been completely successful, since the ski slope remains open. JL

TITLE: Stop the Needless Felling of Trees in Queens Park
GOALDESC: "FURIOUS environmentalists have launched an internet campaign to stop the council chopping down mature trees in Queens Park", http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/news/8106462.print/
INITDESC: INDIV, "FURIOUS environmentalists have launched an internet campaign to stop the council chopping down mature trees in Queens Park", http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/news/8106462.print/
SOCNET: "he has created a protest group on social networking website Facebook", http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/news/8106462.print/
PARTOFF: "He is also organising a peaceful protest when more than 100 people will hold a picnic in the park on May 8 and 9", http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/news/8106462.print/
OUTDESC: No information on whether the extra 300 trees were logged or not.
NARR: Stop the Needless Felling of Trees in Queens Park is a environmental justice campaign aiming to stop teh local city council from removing trees with the initiator(s), Gordon Brown and other individuals, based in GBR and the target(s), the Bolton Council based in GBR. Digital activity consisted of a Facebook group. Offline activity consisted of a peaceful protest in the form of a picnic in Queens Park in GBR. The structure of the campaign can best be described as very loosely organized, amateur; seems to be localized only to a small facebook group and a group of 100 or so for an offline picnic protest. As of June 25, 2013 the campaign is partially successful since there has been some reognition of the protesters, yet there does not seem to be any postponing of the tearing down of trees. DS

TITLE: Don't Block Off Brightlingsea Promenade
GOALDESC: "regeneration projects" "the railings were not needed" - http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/local/4888636.Residents_angry_over_seafront_barrier_plan/
INITDESC: INDIV "it had angered residents and traders" - http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/local/4888636.Residents_angry_over_seafront_barrier_plan/
TARGDESC: "We have asked Tendring Council for money for regeneration projects and not got anything" - http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/local/4888636.Residents_angry_over_seafront_barrier_plan/
EPET: "More than 1,000 people have backed an online protest" - http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/local/4888636.Residents_angry_over_seafront_barrier_plan/,
OUTDESC: "We have asked Tendring Council for money for regeneration projects and not got anything," - http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/local/4888636.Residents_angry_over_seafront_barrier_plan/
NARR: Don't Block Off Brightlingsea Promenade is a environmental justice campaign aiming to stop the construction of rails near a beach with the initiator(s), residents of the town where this is taking place, based in GBR and the target(s), the Tendring Council based in GBR. Digital activity consisted of an online petition. Offline activity consisted of signing petitions in local stores in Brightlingsea GBR. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a locatized, mostly amateur campaign, though supported by the local mayor. As of June 25, 2013 the campaign is partially successful since the council spokesperson will meet with the residents of the town to discuss the issue, yet the construction is already planned to take place. DS

TITLE: Abolish Parking Charges at Coventry’s University Hospital

INITDESC: FORMAL "the Socialist Party" - http://www.coventrytelegraph.net/news/coventry-news/3000-join-facebook-protest-over-3070873

NARR: Abolish Parking Charges at Coventry’s University Hospital is a economic justice campaign aiming to eliminate charges for hospital parking with the initiator(s), the Socialist party, based in GBR and the target(s), hospital bosses based in GBR. Digital activity consisted of the use of Facebook and a website. Offline activity consisted of seeking signatures for an offline petition. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a group of hospital workers and patients organizing around the Socialist party banner in order to take action on an issue. As of July 2, 2013 the campaign is partially successful since the fee was reduced, but wasn't eliminated outright. DS

TITLE: Mr. Marshall for Head Teacher
GOALDESC: "demanding [rector Jane Frith] be replaced" - http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/furious-headteacher-threatens-to-expel-pupils-1049042

OUTDESC: "Rector	Jane L. Frith (2009–present)" - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_High_School,_Edinburgh
NARR: Mr. Marshall for Head Teacher is a education campaign aiming to replace the current headteacher for a school with the initiator(s), the school's students, based in GBR and the target(s), the current headteacher based in GBR. Digital activity consisted of use of Facebook. No offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as very loosely organized; just a bunch of school students joining a Facebook page that probably wasn't actually intended to accomplish anything. As of July 2, 2013 the campaign is partially successful since the issue was publicly addressed by the current headteacher, but didn't work because the same woman is still in place. DS

TITLE: Against Home for Schedule-One Child Offenders

Digital activity consisted of an online petition. Offline activity is a demonstration outside the Clarendon House grammar school in Thanet, Great Britain. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a patents coordination. As of July 03, 2013 the campaign has achieved its goals and the company have deleted the Schedule-one offender from the application to the permit. LS

TITLE: Stop Pope Benedict's Visit to the UK
GOALDESC: "against Pope Benedict XVI's planned trip to Britain" - http://freerepublic.com/focus/f-news/2486706/posts
