TARGDESC: "principal Heather Munroe-Blum and provost Anthony Masi" - http://www2.canada.com/montrealgazette/columnists/story.html?id=079c5ac0-d680-4c92-813b-3f860b537f25
OUTDESC: No information about action taken to address demands - http://www2.canada.com/montrealgazette/columnists/story.html?id=079c5ac0-d680-4c92-813b-3f860b537f25
NARR: Against Changes to McGill Language Program Consolidation is an education campaign aiming to prevent cuts to a Canadian University's language program, initiated by a Canadian student. Digital activity consisted of an online petition. There was no offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as small and grassroots. As of 24 June 2013, the campaign's outcome is unknown because the news story provided to code from was written before the petition was delivered. RM

TITLE: Starbucks Workers in Chile Demand Higher Wages
GOALDESC: "the disparity between how much they pay for a cup of coffee and how much the coffee farmers in far away countries may make, but perhaps they don't realise that what they pay may be more even than their barista's hourly wage," - cupcakesandcashmere.com
INITDESC: FORMAL "the Starbucks employee union in Chile" - the Chilean Starbucks workers
OUTDESC: "Hailed as “small victory” by union leader in wake of failed hunger strike." - http://sitt.wordpress.com/2011/08/24/starbucks-chile-fined-for-anti-union-practices/
NARR: Starbucks Workers in Chile Demand Higher Wages is an economic justice campaign aiming to implement better working conditions for Chilean Starbucks employees, initiated by Chilean Starbucks employees. Digital activity consisted of Twitter and news coverage. Offline activity consisted of a hunger strike in Chilean cities. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an informal network. As of 8 July 2013, the campaign is partially successful, because Starbucks Chile was fined for anti-union practices, even though the hunger strike was called off without any demands concessions. RM

TITLE: Workers’ United Center For Multiple Reforms
GOALDESC:
"For a tax reform. We demand companies and the rich to pay higher taxes.
Change in the pension system. We ask for the State to have a bigger role in the pension system and for firms to compulsory contribute to their employees’ fund.
Improvement of health care for all Chileans. We ask for a shift of the current health care insurance system.
New education rules. We support the students’ demands: end of profit in education and access warranted for everyone.
New Labor Code. We demand a new code that warrants union freedom, right to strike, among other reforms.
New Constitution." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/24/chile-paronacional-national-strike-vs-yonoparo-i-dont-strike/
INITDESC: FORMAL "The Workers’ United Center" "a union federation in Chile. " - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workers%27_United_Center_of_Chile http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/24/chile-paronacional-national-strike-vs-yonoparo-i-dont-strike/
PARTOFF: "Up until now, it is uncertain whether or not the call was successful" "called for a national strike for the 24 and 25 of August, 2011" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/24/chile-paronacional-national-strike-vs-yonoparo-i-dont-strike/
OUTDESC: "The government initially cataloged the strike as a complete failure, and yet has now agreed to meet with representatives of the protest movement in order to negotiate. " - http://upsidedownworld.org/main/chile-archives-34/3203-chile-national-strike-forces-government-to-negotiating-table
NARR: Workers’ United Center For Multiple Reforms is a multiple goal type campaign aiming to improve various social and economic freedoms with the initiator(s), the CUT, based in CHL and the target(s), the Chilean government. Digital activity consisted of use of Twitter. Offline activity consisted of a strike and protests in various parts of Santiago, CHL. The structure of the campaign can best be described as organized around the main workers union, participated in by many others, it seems. As of June 24, 2013 the campaign is partially achieved since the government has decided to meet with the represetntatives of the protest movement. DS

TITLE: Against Gas Price Increase in Magallanes
GOALDESC: "against the high cost of the mandated prices of natural gas [in Magallanes, Chile]" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/01/24/chile-citizens-respond-to-natural-gas-crisis-in-magallanes/
INITDESC: INDIV "a Citizen Assembly" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/01/24/chile-citizens-respond-to-natural-gas-crisis-in-magallanes/
TARGDESC: "the government of Chilean President Sebastian Piñera" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/01/24/chile-citizens-respond-to-natural-gas-crisis-in-magallanes/
SOCNET: "a Facebook page [es] that accumulated more than 1,400 followers in seven days" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/01/24/chile-citizens-respond-to-natural-gas-crisis-in-magallanes/
PARTOFF: "Protests [es], barricades [es] in the streets supporting the movement #noalalzadelgas [es] (Say NO to raising gas prices)" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/01/24/chile-citizens-respond-to-natural-gas-crisis-in-magallanes/, "In the middle of the protests a Citizen Assembly [es] formed in Magallanes [es] and rebelled against the high cost of the mandated prices of natural gas and decided to go out into the streets to reject the government measure" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/01/24/chile-citizens-respond-to-natural-gas-crisis-in-magallanes/
OUTDESC: "On January 18, an agreement between the Government of Chile and the Magallanes Citizens' Assembly was signed. The government proposed to increase the price of gas by 3%, far less than its originally planned increase of almost 17%" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Magallanes_protests#End_of_the_conflict
NARR: Against Gas Price Increase in Magallanes is an economic justice campaign aiming to keep gas prices low in southern Chile. It was initiated by Chilean individuals. Digital activity consisted of Twitter, blogs and news coverage. Offline activity consisted of protests in Magallenes, Chile. The structure of the campaign can best be described as crowd-based and grassroots. As of 24 June 2013, the campaign is partially achieved because, while gas prices were raised, they were raised much less than originally planned and the government offered subsidies to the poorest. RM

TITLE: Against Hidroaysen Dam
GOALDESC: "[against] the hydroelectric plant Hidroaysen" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/16/chile-citizens-reject-the-hidroaysen-dam-project/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Patagonia Sin Represas (Patagonia without Dams)" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/16/chile-citizens-reject-the-hidroaysen-dam-project/
PARTOFF: "a protest of about 1,000 people outside the Coyhaique City Hall" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/16/chile-citizens-reject-the-hidroaysen-dam-project/, "Also, a call to protest onthe streets was made in all the country. An estimated 10,000 people reacted to this call" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/16/chile-citizens-reject-the-hidroaysen-dam-project/
OUTDESC: "Plans to build a $3.2-billion complex of dams that would have flooded thousands of acres in the bio-diverse Patagonia region in southern Chile have been put on indefinite hold in the face of ongoing protests against the project" - http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/06/dam-project-chile-patagonia-suspended.html
NARR: Against Hidroaysen Dam is an environmental rights campaign aiming to stop a dam from being built with the initiator(s), informal groups and individuals, based in Chile and the target(s), government, based in Chile. Digital activity consisted of twitter and blogs and videos. Offline activity consisted of protests and marches. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a very loose network of actors. As of June 18, 2013 the campaign is over, with plans on hold indefinitely, a success for the campaigners. KS

TITLE: Against Mining on Riesco Island
GOALDESC: Against "a million dollar coal mining project that threatens protected species on Riesco Island, one of the largest islands of Chile." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/21/chile-social-media-reactions-against-coal-mining-project/
INITDESC: INFORMAL “Once again Chile is on environmental alert, we will save Riesco Island from destruction” was a strong campaign on social networks and YouTube" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/21/chile-social-media-reactions-against-coal-mining-project/,
PARTOFF: "Protest on February 16 2011 in front of the La Moneda after the government approved a coal mining project on Riesco Island." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/21/chile-social-media-reactions-against-coal-mining-project/
OUTDESC:
"Despite some continuing community opposition, this precarious mine has now received approval.
" - http://www.minesandcommunities.org/article.php?a=10722
NARR: Against Mining on Riesco Island is an environmental rights campaign aiming to stop construction of a mine with the initiator(s), an informal group, based in Chile and the target(s), the mine company based in Chile. Digital activity consisted of videos and an e-petition. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a coalition of concerned organizations. As of June 14, 2013 the campaign is over, without success as the mine was approved. KS

TITLE: For an Anti-Discrimination Law in Chile
GOALDESC: "legislation forbids any discrimination based on: race, age, sex, gender, religion, belief, political or other opinion, birth, national origin, cultural or socioeconomic standing, language, marital status, sexual orientation, illness, disability, genetic structure or any other status. Verbal and others who switched their outward gender identity didn’t make the original list. Now, they are fighting to be included." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/20/chile-transsexuals-demand-a-place-in-postponed-anti-discrimination-law/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Citizen" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/20/chile-transsexuals-demand-a-place-in-postponed-anti-discrimination-law/
OUTDESC: "Chile’s president signed an anti-discrimination law on Thursday " - http://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/13/world/americas/chile-president-signs-anti-discrimination-law.html?_r=1&
NARR: For an Anti-Discrimination Law in Chile is a gender and sexuality rights campaign aiming to end discrimination based on sex and gender with the initiator(s), individuals, based in Chile and the target(s), the government based in Chile. Digital activity consisted of blogs and Twitter. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an amateur effort. As of June 18, 2013 the campaign is possibly ongoing (the end is unclear) with at least partial success, as the President has signed more anti-discrimination laws. KS

TITLE: Save Old Buildings in Guandong
GOALDESC: "[against government leaders' overruling city planners' decisions on] projects [and against] the lack of public participation" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/11/chinas-disempowered-urban-planners-build-support-through-weibo/
INITDESC: INDIV "urban planners" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/11/chinas-disempowered-urban-planners-build-support-through-weibo/
MICBLOG: "For Ma Xiangming, chief engineer of Urban and Rural Planning Institute in Guangdong Province, his tweet changed the fate of the old buildings in Guangdong" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/11/chinas-disempowered-urban-planners-build-support-through-weibo/, "City Planner Wang Peng wrote on his Weibo calling for more public participation" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/11/chinas-disempowered-urban-planners-build-support-through-weibo/
OUTDESC: "Within 7 days, the city planning bureau decided to keep the old building due to pressure from the public" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/11/chinas-disempowered-urban-planners-build-support-through-weibo/
NARR: Save Old Buildings in Guandong is a democracy and rule of law campaign aimed at stopping bad public-planning practices, with the initiators, public planners, based in China and the target, the Chinese government, also based in China. Digital activity consisted of "thousands" of microblog posts. There was no indication of offline activity. The structure of the campaign is an unorganized group of interested public planners associated through social media. As of June 25, 2013, the campaign has been partially successful, since at least one instance of poor planning was changed. JL

TITLE: Taxi Drivers and Railway Workers Demand Depreciation Relief
GOALDESC: "This morning, taxi drivers went on strike. They complained about traffic jams and low incomes. They earn about RMB 500 (USD $80) in one working day, but have to pay RMB 220 to the taxi license holding company and RMB 200 for the fuel."
INITDESC: INDIV, "drivers and employees in the urban public transportation sector", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/08/china-taxi-drivers-and-railway-workers-on-strike/
MICBLOG: " drivers’ attempts to post comments to Weibo were being blocked or removed, and that local media refused to cover the strike", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/08/china-taxi-drivers-and-railway-workers-on-strike/ , @hzhouse
PARTOFF: "More than 8,000 taxi drivers participated in a strike in Hanzhou.... there were around 300 railway workers on strike at Changsha railway station", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/08/china-taxi-drivers-and-railway-workers-on-strike/
OUTDESC: "the government said they would introduce two measures: 1. Adjusting the taxi fees at the end of October; 2. The government will provide 1 yuan per ride subsidy for the drivers. The drivers may continue the strikes, if they are not satisfied with the new measures.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/08/china-taxi-drivers-and-railway-workers-on-strike/
NARR: This is an economic justice campaign aiming to get the Chinese government to adjust taxi driver salaries, initiated by Chinese taxi drivers. Digital activity consisted of Weibo and news coverage. Offline activity consisted of protests in Hangzhou, China. The structure of the campaign can best be described as coordinated by an interest group. As of July 14, 2013, the campaign is partially successful, because the government adjusted salaries but taxi drivers were still unsatisfied. RM

TITLE: Save the Nanjing Trees
GOALDESC: "protest against the recent felling of trees on Taiping North Street." - http://www.rfa.org/english/news/china/trees-03232011153052.html
INITDESC: INDVI "a campaign by netizens on popular social media sites." - http://www.rfa.org/english/news/china/trees-03232011153052.html
TARGDESC: "Authorities in the eastern Chinese city of Nanjing, which is preparing to host the G20 international monetary conference next week, have moved to stifle protests " - http://www.rfa.org/english/news/china/trees-03232011153052.html
SOCNET: "They set up a Sina Weibo account called "Save Nanjing's Wutong Trees, Build a Green City," which garnered more than 14,000 followers in just two weeks, sending out 4,200 updates." - http://www.rfa.org/english/news/china/trees-03232011153052.html
MICBLOG: "Netizens used popular microblogging services like Sina Weibo and Twitter to pass around photographs of felled trees" - http://www.rfa.org/english/news/china/trees-03232011153052.html
PARTOFF: "around 500 young people staged a silent sit-in in central Nanjing, many of them wearing green ribbons in protest against the recent felling of trees on Taiping North Street." - http://www.rfa.org/english/news/china/trees-03232011153052.html
OUTDESC: "A planned removal of many trees for the construction of a new subway line in an eastern Chinese city has been suspended amid strong complaints and opposition from the public." - http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90776/90882/7322459.html
NARR: Save the Nanjing Trees is a environmental justice campaign aiming to protest the removal of trees within a chinese city with the initiator(s), Chinese netizens and the target(s), city authorities based in China. Digital activity consisted of microblogging. Offline activity consisted of a sit-in in Nanjing, China. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose group of Chinese netizens, united only by a relatively large microblogging group. As of June 19, 2013 the campaign is compltely successful, since the planned removal of the trees has been suspended. DS

TITLE: Against Fujia p-Xylene Plant
GOALDESC: "protest of the Fujia p-Xylene plant which they feel is located too near to the city. " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/14/china-large-nimby-protest-erupts-in-dalian/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "residents of Dalian in northern China" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/14/china-large-nimby-protest-erupts-in-dalian/
PARTOFF: "residents of Dalian in northern China took to the streets in large numbers on Sunday " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/14/china-large-nimby-protest-erupts-in-dalian/
OUTDESC: "Municipal authorities in Dalian, a city in northeast China, have ordered the closure of a recently built p-xylene plant after protests by local residents. " - https://pubs.acs.org/cen/news/89/i34/8934notw8.html
NARR: Against Fujia p-Xylene Plant is a environmental campaign aiming to request the relocation of a p-Xylene Plant in Dalian in northern China. The initiators are individuals, residents, and the target(s), is the Chinese province government that can order the relocation. Digital activity in this campaign consisted of  pictures and twits and Weibo messages informing about the protest. Censorship from the government was established over that content and most of it was deleted. Offline activity consisted of thousands of people in an demonstration on the street. This is a onetime demonstration informed online. As of  June 14, 2013 the campaign has partially achieved its goals and the authorities are considering the relocation of the plant. LS

TITLE: For Minimum Price Limits of Trucking Loads
GOALDESC: "[against] government reforms that aim to remove the table of cargo charges that, according to the internet news site La silla vacía [es](The Empty Chair), “regulates, since 1997, the minimum prices of the transportation of cargo in the country.”" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/17/colombia-road-chaos-in-bogota-because-of-truck-driver-strike/
INITDESC: INDIV "Colombian truck drivers" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/17/colombia-road-chaos-in-bogota-because-of-truck-driver-strike/, INFORMAL "the Colombian Association of Truck Drivers (ACC)" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/17/colombia-road-chaos-in-bogota-because-of-truck-driver-strike/
PARTOFF: "a significant number of truck drivers who decided to immobilize their vehicles, parking them in various important streets, especially in the west of the city" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/17/colombia-road-chaos-in-bogota-because-of-truck-driver-strike/
OUTDESC: No information about action taken to address demands - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/17/colombia-road-chaos-in-bogota-because-of-truck-driver-strike/
NARR: For Minimum Price Limits of Trucking Loads is an economic justice campaign aiming to protest government reforms with the initiator(s), individuals and a formal organization, based in Colombia and the target(s), the government based in Colombia. Digital activity consisted of Twitter. Offline activity consisted of a strike. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose and informal structure. As of June 11, 2013 the campaign is over, with no additional information about the outcome. KS

TITLE: Revoke Colombia's Law 30
GOALDESC: "[against] the bill to reform higher education Law 30" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/03/colombia-universities-continue-strike-in-protest-of-law-30/
INITDESC: INDIV "Colombian university students" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/03/colombia-universities-continue-strike-in-protest-of-law-30/, INDIV "Representative Angela Robledo" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/03/colombia-universities-continue-strike-in-protest-of-law-30/
SOCNET: "Nevertheless, Internet demonstrations are still present with new accounts on Facebook and other publications on social networks" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/03/colombia-universities-continue-strike-in-protest-of-law-30/
PARTOFF: "college students are still not attending classes and continue with mobilizations in various parts of Colombia" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/03/colombia-universities-continue-strike-in-protest-of-law-30/
OUTDESC: "The Education Minister Maria Fernanda Campo , said that this whole year is dedicated to promoting and encouraging the initiatives that are being developed in higher education institutions in all regions to shape the draft law reform higher education 30" - http://www.vanguardia.com/actualidad/colombia/159953-este-ano-no-habra-reforma-a-la-ley-30-de-educacion
NARR: Revoke Colombia's Law 30 is a education campaign aiming to promote reforms with the initiator(s), students, based in Colombia and the target(s), the government based in Colombia. Digital activity consisted of blogs, microblogs, and video. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a large coalition of individuals. As of  June 25, 2013 the campaign is over, without success, as the government will not accept reforms. KS

TITLE: Against Riot Police on Campus
GOALDESC: "for their right to study in a violence-free environment by expelling the riot police from their campus" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/11/12/colombia-peaceful-protests-to-violent-events-in-medellin/
INITDESC: INDIV "students" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/11/12/colombia-peaceful-protests-to-violent-events-in-medellin/
PARTOFF: "In the audio Pablo Rendón (@prendon on twitter) explains how the students decided to gather together and try to push out the riot police from the campus through songs and chanting in what he considered was a peaceful demonstration" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/11/12/colombia-peaceful-protests-to-violent-events-in-medellin/
OUTDESC: "the students scored a victory of sorts when they stood up for their right to study in a violence-free environment by expelling the riot police from their campus" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/11/12/colombia-peaceful-protests-to-violent-events-in-medellin/
NARR: Against Riot Police on Campus is an anti-violene campaign by students and teachers aiming to make riot police leave that campus of the University of Antioquia. Digital activity consisted of video and tweeting of the event and a press release by the Teacher's Association posted on Facebook. Offline activity consisted of a rally of hundreds of students which forced the riot police to leave campus. The structure of the campaign can best be described as loose coordination by an informal teachers' organization and individual students at the university. As of July 1, 2013 the campaign is a success because the riot police left. MJ

TITLE: Against Mayoral Election Results in Sabaneta
GOALDESC: "The inhabitants of the smallest municipality in the country, Sabaneta, Antioquia, are peacefully opposing the mayoral election results and have called for an investigation into electoral anomalies", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/10/colombia-sabaneta-municipality-outraged-due-to-electoral-anomalies/
INITDESC: INDIV, "The inhabitants of the smallest municipality in the country, Sabaneta, Antioquia, are peacefully opposing the mayoral election results and have called for an investigation into electoral anomalies", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/10/colombia-sabaneta-municipality-outraged-due-to-electoral-anomalies/, INFORMAL, "Anonymous Colombia supported the citizens’ cause by blocking the official website of the municipality"
HACK: "Anonymous Colombia supported the citizens’ cause by blocking the official website of the municipality", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/10/colombia-sabaneta-municipality-outraged-due-to-electoral-anomalies/
PARTOFF: "Citizens of Sabaneta are demonstrating through sit-ins, peaceful marches", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/10/colombia-sabaneta-municipality-outraged-due-to-electoral-anomalies/
OUTDESC: "In the regional elections, 69 votes and a blackout made ??a difference in one of the most hotly contested races for one mayor. It is Sabaneta, Antioquia, where the winner was the conservative candidate supported by the U, Luz Estela Giraldo, above the Indigenous Authorities Movement candidate, Ivan Alonso Montoya Urrego, and the Liberal Party candidate, Gloria Diez. Since then, the Electoral Observation Mission (EOM) and electoral witnesses reported an alleged electoral fraud and alleged negligence and complicity by the agencies. The situation has become so critical that several complainants claim to have been threatened (May, 2012.", http://www.lasillavacia.com/historia/la-cuestionada-eleccion-que-se-definio-por-69-votos-33380
NARR: Against Mayoral Election Results in Sabaneta is a democracy and rule of law campaign aimed at upending the mayoral-election results, with the initiators, citizens of Sabaneta, based in Colombia and the target, the mayoral office, also based in Colombia. Digital activity consisted of 600 Facebook page likes and 60 tweets. Offline activity consisted of at least 50 protestors in Sabaneta, Colombia. The structure of the campaign appears to be chiefly outraged individual citizens building a grassroots movement. As of June 24, 2013, the campaign has been partially successful, as the results were not overturned but were reviewed.

TITLE: Calling for Elections in Denmark
GOALDESC: "calling the parliamentary elections" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/26/denmark-at-last-the-prime-minister-calls-the-elections/
INITDESC: INDIV "Danish netizens have expressed themselves through humorous online statements." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/26/denmark-at-last-the-prime-minister-calls-the-elections/
TARGDESC: "the Danish Prime Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen has finally let the Danes out of suspense by calling the parliamentary elections" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/26/denmark-at-last-the-prime-minister-calls-the-elections/
OUTDESC: "Today the Danish Prime Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen has finally let the Danes out of suspense by calling the parliamentary elections" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/26/denmark-at-last-the-prime-minister-calls-the-elections/
NARR: This is a democracy campaign aiming to facilitate Danish elections, initiated by Danish netizens. Digital activity consisted of a website and Tumblr use. There was no offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an individual-based grassroots network. As of 14 July 2013, the campaign is successful because the Danish prime minister set a date for elections. RM

TITLE: Arab Spring: Algeria
GOALDESC: "[for removal of Algerian president] Bouteflika [from power]" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/12/algeria-protesters-at-feb12-march-arrested-beaten/
INITDESC: INDIV "protesters for democracy" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/12/algeria-protesters-at-feb12-march-arrested-beaten/
SOCNET: "Algerian protests from the facebook album of RCD Algerie" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/12/algeria-protesters-at-feb12-march-arrested-beaten/, http://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10150113301440489&set=a.10150113300785489.287611.70499175488, http://www.facebook.com/pages/Site-officiel-du-RCD/70499175488
VIDEO: Videos of thousands of protesters have been posted on You Tube and facebook - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/12/algeria-protesters-at-feb12-march-arrested-beaten/
PARTOFF: "Videos of thousands of protesters have been posted on You Tube and facebook" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/12/algeria-protesters-at-feb12-march-arrested-beaten/, "An unemployed 36-years-old man set himself on fire and died in the Eastern town of El Oued" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/12/algeria-protesters-at-feb12-march-arrested-beaten/, "Similar protests are being held in the town of Oran" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/12/algeria-protesters-at-feb12-march-arrested-beaten/
OUTDESC: "[Outcome:] Lifting of the 19-year-old state of emergency" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_Spring
NARR: Arab Spring: Algeria is a democracy and rule of law campaign aimed at instituting democracy in Algeria, with the initiators, protestors, based in Algeria and the target, Algerian authorities, also based in Algeria. Digital activity consisted of nearly 10,000 Facebook likes and over 25,000 tweets, plus blogs and video. Offline activity consisted of protests with "thousands" of participants in Algiers, Algeria. The structure of the campaign is a grassroots uprising of individual protestors. As of June 19, 2013, the campaign achieved partial success, since Algeria lifted its declaration of a two-decade-long state of emergency. JL

TITLE: Free Israeli Embassy Detainees
GOALDESC: "[for] the release of protesters and bystanders arrested on Sunday 15 May, 2011, for being at a protest outside the Israeli Embassy in Cairo to commemorate the Nakba" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/17/egypt-online-campaigns-to-release-arrested-protesters-underway/
INITDESC: INDIV "Egyptian cyber activists" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/17/egypt-online-campaigns-to-release-arrested-protesters-underway/
SOCNET: https://www.facebook.com/freetarekshalaby, "A ‘Free Mosa'ab ElShamy‘ page was set up for him on Facebook" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/17/egypt-online-campaigns-to-release-arrested-protesters-underway/, https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=124274940985060&id=124140504331837, "On Facebook, another page calling for the freeing of 17-year-old Omar Hani Farouk Albstawisy has been formed" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/17/egypt-online-campaigns-to-release-arrested-protesters-underway/
OUTDESC: "A military court on Thursday gave suspended one-year sentences to 15 protesters and suspended six-month sentences to 10 others, all detained by military police while commemorating the Palestinian Nakba in front of the Israeli embassy last Sunday. ... All 25 were released Thursday evening. ... The rest of the protesters are expected to be tried in front of a military court on Saturday." - http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2011/05/19/25-israeli-embassy-protesters-released-after-receiving-suspended-sentences/
NARR: Free Israeli Embassy Detainees is a human rights campaign aiming to release political prisoners with the initiator(s), individuals, based in Egypt and the target(s), the government  based in Egypt. Digital activity consisted of Facebook, titter, and blogs. Offline activity consisted of protests and demonstrations. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a large network of actors. As of June 19, 2013 the campaign is over with success, as the prisoners were released. KS

TITLE: No Mil Trials
GOALDESC: "calling for an end to military trials" - http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2011/08/28/activists-launch-e-protest-against-military-trials-of-civilians/
INITDESC: FORMAL "Al-Nadeem Center for the Rehabilitation of Victims of Torture said on its Twitter account, "Physical injuries heal quickly, but psychological pain takes years to heal … No to military trials."" - https://alnadeem.org/en/contact
TARGDESC: "The protest started at 10 pm and included the official Facebook pages of the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces (SCAF) and the Cabinet." - http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2011/08/28/activists-launch-e-protest-against-military-trials-of-civilians/
SOCNET: "Over 100,000 comments were posted on the Facebook page of the ruling military council last Saturday as part of an online protest", "This is the first time an organized electronic protest is launched on both Twitter and Facebook against military trials,", "more than 15,000 comments were posted on SCAF’s Facebook page calling for an end to military trials, according to Azer.", ""No to military trials … end this farce immediately," ElBaradei said on his Facebook page." - http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2011/08/28/activists-launch-e-protest-against-military-trials-of-civilians/
PARTOFF: "He has been on a hunger strike since Aug. 22, and his health is quickly deteriorating." - http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2011/08/28/activists-launch-e-protest-against-military-trials-of-civilians/
OUTDESC: "Article 198 of Egypt's new constitution, approved by a popular referendum last month, allows for the trial of civilians in military courts.The article was added to the new constitution’s draft at the insistence of the army representative in the Constituent Assembly, as it was finalizing the document." - http://www.amnesty.org/en/news/egyptian-blogger-facing-military-trial-must-be-released-2013-01-07
NARR: 1908 is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to end military trials of civilians with the initiator(s), the informal organization No to Military Trials for Civilians, based in EGY and the target(s), the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces and the Cabinet based in EGY. Digital activity consisted of use of Twitter and Facebook. No offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as semi-professionally organized and participated in by tens of thousands of people, many of whom acted within a collective narrow timeframe. As of July 15, 2013 the campaign is not at all successful since it doesn't appear the targets have responded in any way. DS

TITLE: "Free Maikel Nabil Sanad"
GOALDESC: "On Twitter, netizens continue to rally for his freedom, remembering his words and warnings from the military, particularly after 11 months of military rule.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/21/egypt-free-maikel-nabil-sanad-egypts-first-post-revolution-jailed-blogger/
INITDESC: INDIV, "netizens are remembering the words of one blogger who had warned that the army and the people were never one hand.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/21/egypt-free-maikel-nabil-sanad-egypts-first-post-revolution-jailed-blogger/
PARTOFF: "Maikel today stopped taking liquids and medicine and has no intention to stop his hunger strike."http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/21/egypt-free-maikel-nabil-sanad-egypts-first-post-revolution-jailed-blogger/,
OUTDESC: "An Egyptian blogger jailed by the military junta for insulting the army has been officially pardoned, as the country's ruling generals attempt to bolster public support before protests planned for the Wednesday's anniversary of the uprising.", http://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jan/22/egypt-pardons-blogger-anniversary-protests?newsfeed=true
NARR: "Free Maikel Nabil Sanad" is a rule of law campaign by Maikel to achieve his release from prison.  The target is the military government of post-revolutionary Egypt. Digital activity consisted of reports on the case from Maikel and his family published on Twitter and Facebook. There is no evidence of offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a political prisoner starting a campaign for his own freedom through social media. As of July 16, 2013 the campaign is a success.  Mikel was pardoned and freed. MJ

TITLE: Against Virginity Tests of Egyptian Activitsts
GOALDESC: "Following the appalling confirmation that virginity tests were conducted for female protesters who were detained during the Egyptian revolution, rage took over not only Egyptian females but also males who couldn't believe that those who fought for dignity and freedom had been attacked in such a humiliating way." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/03/egypt-v-for-verifiying-virginity/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Egyptian females but also males" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/03/egypt-v-for-verifiying-virginity/
OUTDESC: "Forced "virginity tests" on female detainees were ruled illegal in Egypt on Tuesday, after a court ordered an end to the practice." - http://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/27/virginity-tests-egypt-protesters-illegal
NARR: Against Virginity Tests of Egyptian Activists is a gender and sexuality campaign by individual Egyptians expressing outrage at the SCAF. The goal (redress) is unclear though they seem to want some kind of justice for the victims and for the practice to cease.  Digital activity consisted of blogging, tweeting, and the creation of video testimony of women effected. Offline activity consisted of at least one offline protest, though the source provided only an image and no other details. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose grouping of individuals in Egypt, later joined by allies and around the world who blogged and tweeted about the issue. As of July 1, 2013, the campaign is a partial success.  The tests were ruled illegal in court opening the way for civil suits for damages.  The only reason this is not counted as a full success what that the initial campaigners did not state this outcome as their goal, though is it certainly in line with their aims. [no author indicated]

TITLE: Against Constitutional Reform in Spain
GOALDESC: "[against] constitutional reform [in Spain]" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/10/spain-intense-political-and-social-debate-on-constitutional-reform/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "the assemblies of Puerta del Sol and seconded by the entire 15M movement" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/10/spain-intense-political-and-social-debate-on-constitutional-reform/
TARGDESC: "the PSOE (Spanish Socialist Workers’ Party), with the support of the PP (People's Party)" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/10/spain-intense-political-and-social-debate-on-constitutional-reform/
EPET: " More than 141,000 people request a constitutional referendum now bit.ly/qckZTZ #yoquierovotar (#iwanttovote)" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/10/spain-intense-political-and-social-debate-on-constitutional-reform/
PARTOFF: "there have been protests throughout the country" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/10/spain-intense-political-and-social-debate-on-constitutional-reform/, hundreds of protestors - http://es.globalvoicesonline.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/2muh-375x280.jpg
OUTDESC: "On September 7, the Senate ratified the reform, with 233 votes in favor and 3 against" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/10/spain-intense-political-and-social-debate-on-constitutional-reform/
NARR: Against Constitutional Reform in Spain is a democracy campaign aiming to stop new laws with the initiator(s), an informal organization, based in Spain and the target(s), the Government based in Spain. Digital activity consisted of microblogs and videos. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a large, formal campaign. As of June 7, 2013 the campaign is over, when the constitutional reform passed. KS

TITLE: 15M Movement
GOALDESC: "The series of protests demand a radical change in Spanish politics, as protesters do not consider themselves to be represented by any traditional party nor favoured by the measures approved by politician", http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011%E2%80%932012_Spanish_protests
INITDESC: INDIV, " demonstrations in Spain whose origin can be traced to social networks such as Real Democracy NOW (Spanish: Democracia Real YA) or Youth Without a Future (Spanish: Juventud Sin Futuro) among other civilian digital platforms and 200 other small associations.[6] ", http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011%E2%80%932012_Spanish_protests
TARGDESC: "rejection of the current political system, capitalism, banks and political corruption.[13] Many call for basic rights, which consist of home, work, culture, health and education rights.[14]"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011%E2%80%932012_Spanish_protests
MICBLOG: "Using Twitter and Facebook it called "the unemployed, poorly paid, the subcontractors",http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011%E2%80%932012_Spanish_protests
PARTOFF: "According to statistics published by RTVE, the Spanish public broadcasting company, between 6.5 and 8 million Spaniards have participated in these protests.", http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011%E2%80%932012_Spanish_protests
OUTDESC: "The 2011–present Spanish protests" (On going nos significant changes), http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011%E2%80%932012_Spanish_protests
NARR: 15M Movement is a democracy and rule of law campaign seeking a change to Spain's political system, with the initiators, Democracy Real YA, based in Spain and the target, the Spanish government, also based in Spain. Digital activity consisted of over 300,000 tweets, websites, blogs, and Facebook pages. Offline activity consisted of tens of thousands of protestors in Madrid and other cities in Spain, with millions of protestors participating over the course of the campaign. As of 6/24/2013, the campaign has achieved partial success, since some politicians have responded to the protestors' concerns but have otherwise done nothing. JL

TITLE: Ethiopian Campaign to Stop Violence Against Women
GOALDESC: "This page is created to raise our VOICE for Justice!! To Aberash Hailay & all the ladies in Ethiopia & all over the world who are being terreriosed, abused and harrased by Men everyday", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/17/ethiopia-aberash-hailays-case-ignites-online-campaign-to-stop-violence-against-women/
INITDESC: "On September 22, netizens took a campaign called “Ahun BeAyne Meta!!!” Campaign for Aberash Hailay and other suvivors of VAW (violence against women) to Facebook. The campaign page with over 200 page likes read", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/17/ethiopia-aberash-hailays-case-ignites-online-campaign-to-stop-violence-against-women/
TARGDESC: "More than 1,300 people have signed an online petition to the Ethiopian government to stop violence against womenMore than 1,300 people have signed an online petition to the Ethiopian government to stop violence against women", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/17/ethiopia-aberash-hailays-case-ignites-online-campaign-to-stop-violence-against-women/
OUTDESC: No information on whether the suspect was punish or changes in legislation
NARR: Ethiopian Campaign to Stop Violence Against Women is a gender campaign aimed at justice for a women attacked by her ex-husband, with initiators, Ethiopian activists, based in Ethiopia, and target, the Ethiopian government, also based in Ethiopia. Digital activity consisted of 1270 Facebook page likes and 1574 signatures on an online petition. Offline activity consisted of a meeting to organize the campaign and a letter sent to the Prime Minister of Ethiopia. The structure of the campaign is centered around a few outspoken activists who have organized both on- and offline. As of 6/17/2013, the campaign's success is uncertain, since no outcome had been reached regarding the woman's attacker, and no response was indicated from the government. JL

TITLE: For Official Acknowledgement of 1961 Tragedy
GOALDESC: "for the French government's admission of the 1961 tragedy" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/31/france-calls-for-official-recognition-of-1961-paris-algerian-massacre/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "the website Mediapart" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/31/france-calls-for-official-recognition-of-1961-paris-algerian-massacre/
OUTDESC: "The French Republic has officially recognized Wednesday bloody crackdown against Algerian protesters October 17, 1961" - http://www.france24.com/fr/20121016-algerie-france-17-octobre-1961-jour-ebranla-pas-paris-jean-Luc-einaudi-massacre-manifestation-guerre
NARR: For Official Acknowledgement of 1961 Tragedy is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to obtain recognition from the French government for a massacre, with the initiator(s), the French political left, a website, and a number of famous people, based in FRA and the target(s), the French government. Digital activity consisted of use of blogs and a map. No offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a mixture of politically organized people (politicians) and individuals and an informal group (website) working towards a common goal. As of June 18, 2013 the campaign is completely successful, since the French government did officially recognize the bloody Algerian crackdown. DS

TITLE: Students in Gabon Demand Stipend
GOALDESC: " students were demonstrating [fr] because they have not received their 100 Euros (66,000 Central African Francs) monthly scholarship money since July 2010.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/11/gabon-students-protest-army-deployed/

Whereas protests last week involved mostly opposition members, the unrest appears to be developing into a wider social conflict.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/11/gabon-students-protest-army-deployed/
OUTDESC: (no information found regarding the reimbursement of the late scholarship or about the start of the payment)
NARR: This is an education campaign aiming to reinstate three professors and pay salaries to Gabonese students, initiated by Gabonese students. Digital activity consisted of Facebook, Twitter, and videos. Offline activity consisted of protests in Libreville, Gabon. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a student-led coalition. As of 14 July 2013, the campaign's outcome is undetermined because the information given is unclear. RM

TITLE: Free Eynulla Fatullayev
GOALDESC: "call for the release of an imprisoned journalist and newspaper editor in Azerbaijan. Eynulla Fatullayev" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/24/azerbaijan-jon-snow-and-amnesty-international-in-twitter-action/
INITDESC: FORMAL "Amnesty International declared Fatullayev to be a prisoner of conscience and in April 2010 the European Court of Human Rights ruled in favor of his immediate release. " - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amnesty_International
TARGDESC: "the Azerbaijani Supreme Court" "I’m calling on @presidentaz to free wrongly imprisoned journalist #Eynulla Fatullayev in #azerbaijan"  - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/24/azerbaijan-jon-snow-and-amnesty-international-in-twitter-action/
OUTDESC: "Just two days after the UK branch of Amnesty International launched its Twitter campaign to call for the release of Eynulla Fatullayev comes news that the imprisoned journalist and prisoner of conscience has been included in a list of prisoners to be pardoned ahead of the 93rd anniversary of the founding of the Azerbaijan Democratic Republic." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/26/azerbaijan-eynulla-fatullayev-pardoned/
NARR: Free Eynulla Fatullayev is a democracy and rule of law campaign aimed at freeing a journalist, with the initiator, Amnesty International, based in the UK and the target, the Azerbaijani Supreme Court, based in Azerbaijan. Digital activity consisted of 886 tweets. There was no indication of offline activity. The structure of the campaign is organized almost entirely around one huge formal organization and associated celebrities. As of June 24, 2013, the campaign has been entirely successful, since the journalist was released. JL

Digital activity consisted of an e-petition. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a tight, driven network. As of June 18, 2013 the campaign's success is unknown, as no information is available. KS

TITLE: Stop the Tullos Deer Cull
GOALDESC: "stop a deer cull in Aberdeen" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1910-Aberdeen-Press-and-Journal.docx
INITDESC: INDIV "Opponents and animal-rights activists have stepped up their fight", "Nearly 3,000 people have joined an online protest group, Stop the Tullos Deer Cull", "Torry resident Suzanne Kelly, who has been at the forefront of the campaign", "John Robins, from the national Animal Concern group, said"
TARGDESC: "Aberdeen City Council approved the controversial plans in May" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1910-Aberdeen-Press-and-Journal.docx
SITE: online protest group, Stop the Tullos Deer Cull, referenced – http://www.pressandjournal.co.uk/Article.aspx/2454721
PARTOFF: "campaigners have also staged public demonstrations against the move" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1910-Aberdeen-Press-and-Journal.docx
OUTDESC: "Aberdeen City Council has confirmed that it will go ahead with the cull of the deer located on Tullos Hill, in order that new trees can be planted, in line ACC's 'Tree for every citizen' programme." - http://torrycommunitycouncil.webs.com/apps/blog/show/7054930-tullos-deer-cull
NARR: Stop the Tullos Deer Cull is an environmental campaign aiming to protect deer at a deer run in Great Britain, initiated by local residents. Digital activity consisted of an online protest group. Offline activity consisted of attendance at a city council meeting in Torry, Scotland. The structure of the campaign can best be described as community based and local. As of 3 July 2013, the campaign is unsuccessful because the city council voted to go ahead with the cull. RM

TITLE: Free the UAE Five
GOALDESC: "for [the UAE Five's] immediate and unconditional release" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAE_Five
INITDESC: FORMAL "Amnesty International" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAE_Five, FORMAL "Human Rights Watch" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAE_Five, FORMAL "Front Line Defenders" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAE_Five, FORMAL "Index on Censorship" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAE_Five, FORMAL "Arabic Network For Human Rights Information" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAE_Five, FORMAL "US National Academy of Sciences" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAE_Five, FORMAL "Scholars at Risk" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAE_Five, FORMAL "Committee of Concerned Scientists" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAE_Five
PARTOFF: "the five began a hunger strike to protest their continued detention" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAE_Five
OUTDESC: "The following day, however, the five received a presidential pardon and were released" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAE_Five
NARR: Free the UAE Five is a democracy and rule of law campaign aimed at freeing five UAE activists who were arrested and charged with insulting the government, with the initiators, several formal human-rights organizations, based in the UK, US, Ireland, and Egypt and the target, the UAE government, based in UAE. Digital activity consisted of websites set up for the campaign. Offline activity consisted of unnamed celebrities spreading word about the issue at a festival. The structure of the campaign is a coordinated effort by several well-established formal organizations. As of June 25, 2013, the campaign has achieved complete success, since the activists were pardoned and released. JL

TITLE: Against Austerity in Greece
GOALDESC: "Greeks are angry over the relentless and ineffective austerity measures, culminating in the recent “haircut” deal negotiated by banks and European politicians, which many fear signifies the beginning of a new foreign “occupation” of the country.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/02/greece-anti-austerity-protests-disrupt-ochi-day-parades-2/
INITDESC: INDIV, "Greeks are angry over the relentless and ineffective austerity measures...Several local bloggers and activists in Thessaloniki found themselves in the middle of events, posting updates and photos from their cellphones", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/02/greece-anti-austerity-protests-disrupt-ochi-day-parades-2/
SOCNET: " call on social media centered around an impromptu Facebook group (since deleted) had advocated citizen protest on Ochi Day, based on the theme of the national holiday" http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/02/greece-anti-austerity-protests-disrupt-ochi-day-parades-2/
PARTOFF: "up to 30,000 people ended up participating in the Thessaloniki protest [el].", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/02/greece-anti-austerity-protests-disrupt-ochi-day-parades-2/
OUTDESC: "(May 1, 2013) A general strike against tough austerity measures is under way in Greece, with trade unions calling for "mass mobilisation" of protesters.", http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22362757
NARR: Against Austerity in Greece is an economic-justice campaign aimed at ending Greece's austerity measures, with the initiators, Greek citizens, based in Greece and the target, the Greek president, also based in Greece. Digital activity consisted of more than 940 thousand tweets, a Facebook group, blogs, and videos. Offline activity consisted of tens of thousands of protestors in Thessaloniki and hundreds of protestors in Athens. The structure of the campaign appears to be a grassroots upswelling of angry individuals. As of June 19, 2013, the campaign has achieved partial success, as the prime minister responded to the protestors' arguments. JL

" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Stabilization_Mission_in_Haiti
NARR: For the Withdrawal of the United Nations Stabilization Mission in Haiti is a anti-occupation campaign aiming to get UN Peacekeepers to leave Haiti with the initiator(s), informal organizations, based in Haiti and the target(s), the UN based in the USA. Digital activity consisted of video, Twitter, and blogs. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a network of concerned actors. As of June 27, 2013 the campaign is over, without success. KS

TITLE: Against the Illegalization of Homeless
GOALDESC: "against the modification of the law that would punish “recurrent residing in public places” with an increased fine of €530 or imprisonment" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/01/hungary-solidarity-with-the-homeless-and-the-poor/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "The City is for All grassroots group" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/01/hungary-solidarity-with-the-homeless-and-the-poor/, FORMAL "European Federation of National Organisations Working With the Homeless (FEANTSA)" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/01/hungary-solidarity-with-the-homeless-and-the-poor/, INDIV "citizen[s]" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/01/hungary-solidarity-with-the-homeless-and-the-poor/
PARTOFF: "a citizen group called Börtön helyett lakhatást (Housing, Not Prison) organized a sit-in protest in Máté Kocsis’ mayor's office" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/01/hungary-solidarity-with-the-homeless-and-the-poor/, "A week later, a silent protest was organized [hu] in front of the Parliament" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/01/hungary-solidarity-with-the-homeless-and-the-poor/
OUTDESC: "The new Act on Petty Offenses, adopted in November 2011, and which entered into force on April 15, 2012, makes it a criminal offense to reside habitually in public spaces or to store belongings in them" - http://www.hrw.org/news/2012/04/16/hungary-revoke-law-criminalizing-homeless
NARR: Against the Illegalization of Homeless is an economic-justice campaign aimed at removing a law that criminalizes homelessness, with the initiators, various homeless and human-rights advocate groups, based in Hungary and Belgium and the target, the mayor of district 8, based in Hungary. Digital activity consisted of websites, blogs, video, and a Facebook event. Offline activity consisted of several protestsi in Budapest, Hungary, with one garnering over 1,200 participants. The structure of the campaign is a collection of loosely associated formal and informal organizations. As of June 25, 2013, the campaign has not achieved any success at all, since the bill has not been repealed and there is no indication of a response. JL

TITLE: Campaign to Annul Restrictive IT Rules
GOALDESC: "against IT Rules-2011 in Rajya Sabha" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/06/india-freedom-fast-to-save-your-voice/
