PARTOFF: "Today is the fifth day of the hunger strike of Aseem Trivedi and Alok Dixit" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/06/india-freedom-fast-to-save-your-voice/
OUTDESC: "The Committee have desired the Ministry of Communications & Information Technology to have a fresh look at the Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines) Rules, 2011, and make such amendments as necessary to ensure that there is no ambiguity in any of the provisions of the said rules" - http://kafila.org/2013/03/27/lok-sabha-committee-tells-kapil-sibal-to-re-examine-the-information-technology-rules/
NARR: Campaign to Annul Restrictive IT Rules is a information and expression campaign aiming to stop new IT laws in India with the initiator(s), Save Your Voice, based in IND and the target(s), the Indian government. Digital activity consisted of use of Facebook, Twitter, and blogs. Offline activity consisted of fasting in India. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a small informal organization that generated a small following until the fasting ended. As of June 18, 2013 the campaign is partially successful since the government said they will potentially revise the law, but it still remains in place. DS

TITLE: Ban Endosulfan
GOALDESC: "pressurizing the Indian Government to favor the ban." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/30/india-kerala%E2%80%99s-debate-on-endosulfan/
INITDESC: FORMAL "Keralas’ current chief minister V.S Achuthandan (member of the Communist Party of India) led a big team of volunteers in a one day fasting protest for supporting the ban." INDIV "Thulasi Kakkat, a photo blogger", "Harish Madiyan, a citizen journalist,", "Physel Pollil, another blogger"- http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/30/india-kerala%E2%80%99s-debate-on-endosulfan/
PARTOFF: "As recently as last week, Keralas’ current chief minister V.S Achuthandan (member of the Communist Party of India) led a big team of volunteers in a one day fasting protest for supporting the ban. Kerala witnessed a hartal organized by the same party on April 29th 2011 to pressurize the Indian Government." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/30/india-kerala%E2%80%99s-debate-on-endosulfan/
OUTDESC: " In a major change of position, India on Friday accepted at a world convention in Geneva that the pesticide Endosulfan is a health hazard.... It has now agreed to a phased out ban with an exemption for some crops." - http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/india-agrees-to-endosulfan-ban-102347
NARR: Ban Endosulfan is a health campaign aiming to ban a pesticide with the initiator(s), individuals, based in India and the target(s), government based in India. Digital activity consisted of blogs. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as informal. As of June 20, 2013 the campaign is over, with success, as the pesticide was banned. KS

TITLE: Free Hossein Ronaghi Malki
GOALDESC: ""Free Hossein [fa], is a campaign on the internet has been launched to provide the information on this jailed blogger", ,http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/16/iran-jailed-blogger-hossein-ronaghi-in-danger/
INITDESC: http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/16/iran-jailed-blogger-hossein-ronaghi-in-danger/
SOCNET: "The campaign's Facebook page has around 1500 fans.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/16/iran-jailed-blogger-hossein-ronaghi-in-danger/
OUTDESC: "Hossein Ronaghi Maleki is on hunger strike ( 11th August, 2013)", https://hra-news.org/en/hossein-ronaghi-maleki-is-on-hunger-strike
NARR: Free Hossein Ronaghi Malki is a health campaign aimed at attaining medical care for an imprisoned Iranian blogger, with the initiator, the Free Hossein organization, based in Iran, and the target, the Iranian judiciary, also based in Iran. Digital activity included 1500 Facebook likes and a website. Offline activity included a letter addressed to the judiciary. The structure of the campaign is centered on a single informal single-issue organization. As of June 18, 2013, it remains unclear whether Hossein received medical treatment, and no indication of a government response was issued. JL

TITLE: Save Lake Urmia
GOALDESC: "demand that the Iranian government save Lake Urmia." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/14/iran-protest-art-to-save-lake-urmia/
INITDESC: INDIV "Iranian bloggers reported about repression and arrests of several Azeri activists." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/14/iran-protest-art-to-save-lake-urmia/
TARGDESC: "demand that the Iranian government save Lake Urmia." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/14/iran-protest-art-to-save-lake-urmia/
PARTOFF: "Protesters took to the streets again on Monday in Ardabil, in Iran's Azarbaijan's region", "reported about repression and arrests of several Azeri activists.", "Two protesters got arrested as they chanted slogans. I walked toward Shariati Square and I witnessed ten people getting arrested. I heard in other parts of town that more were arrested by security forces." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/14/iran-protest-art-to-save-lake-urmia/
OUTDESC: "Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has issued a special order for speeding up efforts to restore Lake Urmia, Mehr news agency reported." - http://www.azernews.az/region/53500.html
NARR: Save Lake Urmia is an environmental campaign aiming to protect a lake from drying up with the initiator(s), Azeria activists  based in Iran and the target(s), the Iranian government. Digital activity consisted of blogs, social networks, and video. Offline activity consisted of street protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as informal. As of August 29, 2013 the campaign is a partial success. President Ahmedinijad committed to speed up efforts to restore the lake but it is not clear what action will actually be taken.  MJ

TITLE: For a Government Response to Bear Abuse
GOALDESC: "calling on Iranian authorities to punish the hunters. " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/24/iran-rage-over-video-of-tortured-bear-cubs/
INITDESC: FORMAL "It all started when the Iranian Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals published a video showing “hunters” in Samirom in the Isfahan province killing a brown bear and torturing her cubs as a game before the camera." - http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1051564.html
TARGDESC: " calling on Iranian authorities to punish the hunters." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/24/iran-rage-over-video-of-tortured-bear-cubs/
OUTDESC: "News reports said two of the “hunters” were arrested." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/24/iran-rage-over-video-of-tortured-bear-cubs/
NARR: For a Government Response to Bear Abuse is an environmental campaign aiming to punish several Iranian men for torturing bears, initiated by the Iranian Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Digital activity consisted of blogs, Facebook use and a video. There was no offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as loose and grassroots. As of 10 July 2013, the campaign is partially successful because two of the hunters were arrested, but it's unclear whether there are more to be captured. RM

TITLE: Arab Spring: Iraq
GOALDESC: "Iraqi people were inspired the revolutions around the Arab world and announced their own day of rage on 25th February." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/26/iraq-to-the-entire-world-iraqis-are-coming/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "people" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/26/iraq-to-the-entire-world-iraqis-are-coming/
PARTOFF: "The main demonstration centred on Tahrir Square in Baghdad" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/26/iraq-to-the-entire-world-iraqis-are-coming/
OUTDESC: "Government overthrown on 11 February 2011. The replacement government was ousted by military 2013 Egyptian coup d'état." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_Spring
NARR: Arab Spring: Iraq is a democracy campaign aiming to protest the government with the initiator(s), individuals, based in Iraq  and the target(s), the government based in Iraq. Digital activity consisted of Facebook, Twitter and blogs. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a large, loose coalition. As of June 14, 2013 the campaign is ongoing, as the president has decided not to run again. KS

TITLE: Pass Dead Sea Rehabilitation Bill
GOALDESC: "to convince the relevant ministers to change their original votes", "repair all damage they have caused to the sea" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1708-Jerusalem-Post.docx
INITDESC: FORMAL "a joint effort of global web activist group Avaaz, Adam Teva V'Din (Israel Union for Environmental Defense) and Friends of the Earth Middle East," - http://www.avaaz.org/en/contact/
TARGDESC: "the petitioners intend to rally the public to convince the relevant ministers to change their original votes" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1708-Jerusalem-Post.docx
EPET: "activist groups are banding together to promote an online petition" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1708-Jerusalem-Post.docx, https://secure.avaaz.org/en/stop_stoning/?hp
OUTDESC: "The cabinet rejected a bill for the second time that would provide for the comprehensive rehabilitation of the Dead Sea region, during a meeting on Monday." - http://www.jpost.com/LandedPages/PrintArticle.aspx?id=252924
NARR: Pass Dead Sea Rehabilitation Bill is an environmental-protection campaign aimed at getting Israeli ministers to change their votes and pass a Dead Sea rehabilitation bill, with the initators, a coalition of environmental groups, based in Israel and Jordan and the targets, Israeli ministers who voted against the bill, based in Israel. Digital activity consisted of over 15,000 petition signatures. There was no indication of offline activity. The structure of the campaign is a coalition of established environmental activist groups. As of June 25, 2013, the campaign has not achieved any success at all, since the Israeli cabinet again defeated the bill and there was no indication of a response. JL

TITLE: J14 Movement
GOALDESC: "Israelis from across the board have come together in protest against a higher ideal – not political and not necessarily demanding for a change in government...It is an effort by the young Israelis to recapture an older, more egalitarian, more idealistic country that their parents lost", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/10/israel-protests-for-social-justice-sweep-the-country/
INITDESC: INDIV, "The J14 movement was initiated by a young Israeli woman named Daphni Leef who pitched a tent in the center of Tel Aviv three weeks ago (July 14th) in protest of the unaffordable cost of housing.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/10/israel-protests-for-social-justice-sweep-the-country/
SOCNET: A variety of Facebook event pages send updates on current events"", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/10/israel-protests-for-social-justice-sweep-the-country/
PARTOFF: "The movement for social justice spurred tent cities in major metropolitan hubs across the country, mobilizing over 4 per cent of Israel's total population (one out of every 20 Israelis took to the streets in last week's massive protest)", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/10/israel-protests-for-social-justice-sweep-the-country/
OUTDESC: "On 26 July 2011, Prime Minister Netanyahu announced a new housing plan, including significant incentives for contractors who build smaller apartments, rent-earmarked housing and student housing, and plans to add 50,000 apartments to Israel's housing market over the next two years. The plan would allow contractors to purchase land from the Israel Land Administration up to 50% cheaper if they agree to build small apartments.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/10/israel-protests-for-social-justice-sweep-the-country/
NARR: J14 Movement is a economic justice campaign aiming to protest the unaffordable cost of housing with the initiator(s), a young Israeli woman and many other individuals, based in Israel and the target(s), the Israeli government. Digital activity consisted of website, video, Facebook and Twitter. Offline activity consisted of huge protests in Tel Aviv. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a very large group of organized protesters who formed around an individual action and took it further. As of June 18, 2013 the campaign is completely successful since Netanyahu announced a new housing plan in response. DS

TITLE: Arab Spring: Jordan
GOALDESC: "for a transition to a constitutional monarchy, major economic reforms, a new election law, and increased political voice for Jordanian citizens" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/25/jordan-reactions-to-ammans-friday-protests-photos/
INITDESC: INDIV "thousands of Jordanians representing diverse groups and voices" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/25/jordan-reactions-to-ammans-friday-protests-photos/
PARTOFF: "After demonstrations in Amman, Jordan on Friday 18 February, 2011, thousands of Jordanians representing diverse groups and voices took to the streets this Friday 25 February" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/25/jordan-reactions-to-ammans-friday-protests-photos/, "The afternoon ended with the detention of three people for being drunk and two others for pickpocketing among the 7,000 protesters" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/25/jordan-reactions-to-ammans-friday-protests-photos/
OUTDESC:
"[Outcome:] On February 2011, King Abdullah II dismisses Prime Minister Rifai and his cabinet[103]
On October 2011, Abdullah dismisses Prime Minister Bakhit and his cabinet after complaints of slow progress on promised reforms[104]
On April 2012, as the protests continues, Al-Khasawneh resigned, and the King appoints Fayez al-Tarawneh as the new Prime Minister of Jordan[105]
On October 2012, King Abdullah dissolves the parliament for new early elections, and appoints Abdullah Ensour as the new Prime Minister of Jordan" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_Spring
NARR: This is a democracy campaign aiming to change elements of the Jordanian government initiated by Jordanian individuals. Digital activity consisted of Twitter. Offline activity consisted of protests in Amman and across Jordan. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a crowd-based large network that manifested in protests. As of July 14, 2013, the campaign is partially successful because some reforms occurred. RM

TITLE: Against Gamer "Shut-Down" System
GOALDESC: "[against] a law clamping down on the online gaming industry [in South Korea]" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/04/south-korea-womens-ministry-gaming-clampdown-backfires/
INITDESC: "net users" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/04/south-korea-womens-ministry-gaming-clampdown-backfires/
TARGDESC: "The South Korean government's Ministry of Gender Equality and Family Affairs" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/04/south-korea-womens-ministry-gaming-clampdown-backfires/
EPET: "Enraged net users have filed an online petition, blaming the Ministry's decision as neither justifiable nor effective.",http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/04/south-korea-womens-ministry-gaming-clampdown-backfires/, second round petition; http://bbs3.agora.media.daum.net/gaia/do/petition/read?bbsId=P001&articleId=105511
OUTDESC: "The game shutdown system, introduced by the Ministry of Gender Equality and Family in Korea, is a regulation that prohibits gamers under 16 from connecting to online games between midnight and 6 in the morning. The regulation came into effect on Nov. 20 last year" - http://societyinkorea.blogspot.com/2012/10/teenage-pro-gamer-hit-by-shutdown-system.html
NARR: Against Gamer "Shut-Down" System is an entertainment and fandom campaign aiming to stop the  "Shut-Down" System for gaming between 12PM and 6AM for younger than 16years old. The initiator(s), are individuals in South Korea, based in South Korea, and the target is the South Korean government's Ministry of Gender Equality and Family Affairs. Digital activity consisted of two online petitions and Twits. No information available regarding offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as crowd of users of a service complaining by a limitation in the access to the games.  As of July 8, 2013 the campaign has not achieved its goals and it is into effect since Nov. 2011. LS

TITLE: Against US-South Korea Free Trade Agreement
GOALDESC: " protesting against the country's Free Trade Agreement (FTA) with the United States" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/06/south-korea-anger-over-free-trade-agreement-and-media-silence/
INITDESC: INDIV "Citizens have expressed deep discontent with the government and the ruling Grand National party", FORMAL "The Media Workers Union (@mediaworker) tweeted [ko] a video and photos of the protest", "one senior judge's long Facebook post [ko] criticizing the current president and the free trade agreement with the United States came under fire." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/06/south-korea-anger-over-free-trade-agreement-and-media-silence/
TARGDESC: "the government and the ruling Grand National party", " the ruling Grand National Party and most mainstream media " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/06/south-korea-anger-over-free-trade-agreement-and-media-silence/
SOCNET: "one senior judge's long Facebook post [ko] criticizing the current president and the free trade agreement with the United States came under fire" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/06/south-korea-anger-over-free-trade-agreement-and-media-silence/
PARTOFF: "The most recent protest on December 3, gathered several thousand protesters [ko] across the country.", "Over 50,000 people showed up." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/06/south-korea-anger-over-free-trade-agreement-and-media-silence/
OUTDESC: " The agreement entered into effect in March 2012." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_trade_agreement_between_the_United_States_of_America_and_the_Republic_of_Korea
NARR: Against US-South Korea Free Trade Agreement is a economic justice campaign aiming to prevent the FTA between the US and South Korea with the initiator(s), The Media Workers Union and South Korean citizens, based in KOR and the target(s), the KOR government, ruling party, and media based in KOR. Digital activity consisted of blog, Twitter, forum, Facebook, and video. Offline activity consisted of major and minor protests in various South Korean cities. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a large collection of KOR citizens, with a union, and more important journalists and musicians protesting. As of June 18, 2013 the campaign is unsuccessful since the FTA passed anyways. DS

TITLE: Against Internet Price-Gouging
GOALDESC: "for the release of Wang Lihong" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/07/18/china-campaigning-for-the-release-of-female-activist-wang-lihong/
INITDESC: INDIV "prominent bloggers" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/07/18/china-campaigning-for-the-release-of-female-activist-wang-lihong/
OUTDESC: "Wang Lihong, a widely-known human rights activist, was released from prison on 20 December after having served her sentence" - http://www.amnestyusa.org/our-work/latest-victories/great-news-chinese-human-rights-activist-wang-lihong-released
NARR: Against Internet Price-Gougingis an information campaign aiming to lower prices for Internet with the initiator(s), individuals, based in Kuwait and the target(s), Internet companies based in Kuwait. Digital activity consisted of blogs and Twitter. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose network of individuals. As of June 19, 2013  the campaign is over, with success, as internet prices have been reduced. KS

TITLE: Arab Spring: Kuwait
GOALDESC: "demand the departure of Al-Mohammed Al-Sabah whom they accuse of corruption." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/18/kuwait-protesters-storm-the-national-assembly/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Kuwaiti youth " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/18/kuwait-protesters-storm-the-national-assembly/
PARTOFF: "Thousands of angry Kuwaitis stormed the National Assembly building " "around 1,000 protesters showed up" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/18/kuwait-protesters-storm-the-national-assembly/
OUTDESC: "Ongoing" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_Spring
NARR: Arab Spring: Kuwait is a democracy campaign aiming to protest the government with the initiator(s), individuals, based in Kuwait and the target(s), the government based in Kuwait. Digital activity consisted of videos. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as very loose. As of June 14, 2013 the campaign is ongoing without success. KS

TITLE: End the Sectarian Regime in Lebanon
GOALDESC:
“We as Lebanese citizens we want:
A democratic, secular and civil country. A country of social justice and equality
The right of a decent to every citizen through:
Raising the minimum wage; The reduction of the basic commodities prices; The reduction of fuel prices; Enhancing public educational system; Providing equal access to public and private employment; Abolition of patronage, brokerage, and bribes; The right of proper housing
Enhancing the Social Security and Old Age Security systems”, http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/03/04/lebanon-protests-against-the-sectarian-regime/
INITDESC: INDIV, "The protesters were of all ages, genders and religious beliefs and refused to be related to any political party in the country.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/03/04/lebanon-protests-against-the-sectarian-regime/
TARGDESC: "“The people want to bring down the regime” , http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/03/04/lebanon-protests-against-the-sectarian-regime/
PARTOFF: "More than 2,500 Lebanese citizens marched on February 27, 2011, in the capital Beirut against the sectarian system governing Lebanon and they're planning to march again after tomorrow (March 6).", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/03/04/lebanon-protests-against-the-sectarian-regime/
OUTDESC: "In early January 2011, the national unity government collapsed due to growing tensions stemming from the Special Tribunal for Lebanon, which was expected to indict Hezbollah members for the Hariri assassination.[68] The parliament elected Najib Mikati, the candidate for the Hezbollah-led March 8 Alliance, Prime Minister of Lebanon, making him responsible for forming a new government.[69] Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah insists that Israel was responsible for the assassination of Hariri.[70] A report leaked by the Al-Akhbar newspaper in November 2010 stated that Hezbollah has drafted plans for a takeover of the country in the case an indictment against its members is issued by the Special Tribunal for Lebanon.[71][72]", http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lebanon
NARR: End the Sectarian Regime in Lebanon is a democracy and rule of law campaign aimed at ousting the current Lebanese regime, with the initiators, Lebanese citizens, based in Lebanon and the target, the sectarian regime, also based in Lebanon. Digital activity consisted of over 20000 Facebook likes and over 3400 tweets. Offline activity consisted of a protest with more than 2500 people participating in Beirut as well as at least two sit-ins. The structure of the campaign is grassroots, with no identifiable leader or organizer and most coordination taking place via social media. As of June 18, 2013, the campaign has not yet achieved success, since the regime did not step aside. JL

TITLE: Arab Spring: Libya
GOALDESC: "a bid to overthrow his 42-year-old regime" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/03/27/libya-citizen-reporting-from-the-battlefield/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "protesters" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/03/27/libya-citizen-reporting-from-the-battlefield/
PARTOFF: "It was captured by pro-democracy forces" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/03/27/libya-citizen-reporting-from-the-battlefield/
OUTDESC: "Government overthrown on 23 August 2011" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_Spring
NARR: Arab Spring: Libya is a Democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to overthrow Muammar Gaddafi's 42-year-old regime in Lybia. The initiators are individuals, combatants in Libya. Digital activity consisted in videos posted in YouTube to show the offline battles. Offline activity can be best described as a civil war with displaced people  and guerillas in the cities. As of June 10, 2013 the campaign has achieved its goals, the government fell down and Gaddafi’s was killed. LS

TITLE: For Political Reform in Mexico
GOALDESC: "[for] the possibility for citizens to present initiatives directly to the [Mexican] Congress, a preference initiative for the leader of the Executive Power and reelection for mayors and legislators" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/30/mexico-reformapoliticaya-political-reform-now-reactions-on-twitter/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "citizen organizations and activist" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/30/mexico-reformapoliticaya-political-reform-now-reactions-on-twitter/
OUTDESC: "Things came to a head last week when Cordero said he would put forward an initiative for political reform in Mexico with the PRD in the Senate" - http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/20/us-mexico-reforms-idUSBRE94J0M820130520
NARR: For Political Reform in Mexico is an electoral reform campaign aiming to reform the electoral system with the initiator(s), informa groups and individuals, based in Mexico and the target(s), the government based in mexico. Digital activity consisted of Twitter. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a network. As of June 28, 2013 the campaign is over, without success. KS

TITLE: For the 5th of June Law
GOALDESC: "(To pressure the president to sign) a bill that would require all daycare centres in the country – public, private or mixed – to meet minimum safety requirements, assure quality standards, and submit to periodic inspections. It also includes the creation of a national register of daycare centres.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/25/mexico-president-signs-law-two-years-after-fire-at-abc-daycare-centre/
INITDESC: INDIV, "The childrens’ parents ran an astute campaign to find those responsible and bring them to justice before the Mexican Supreme Court of Justice. In addition, they promoted a bill", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/25/mexico-president-signs-law-two-years-after-fire-at-abc-daycare-centre/
OUTDESC: "Thanks to this exercise of collective citizenship, the President has conceded and announced the enactment of the law at his residence yesterday, Monday, October 24. ", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/25/mexico-president-signs-law-two-years-after-fire-at-abc-daycare-centre/
NARR: For the 5th of June Law is a democracy and rule of law campaign aimed at forcing President Calderon to sign a daycare-reform bill, with the initiators, Mexican netizens, based in Mexico and the target, President Calderon, also based in Mexico. Digital activity consisted of over 12,000 tweets. There was no indication of offline activity. The structure of the campaign was a grassroots movement of individual citizens. As of June 24, 2013, the campaign achieved complete success, as President Calderon signed the bill. JL

TITLE: Against the Draft Law on Youth
GOALDESC: "The withdrawal of the Draft Law on Youth from the parliamentary procedure " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/02/macedonia-ngos-and-netizens-prevent-undemocratic-youth-law/
INITDESC: FORMAL " Youth Educational Forum" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/02/macedonia-ngos-and-netizens-prevent-undemocratic-youth-law/
OUTDESC: "The withdrawal of the Draft Law on Youth from the parliamentary procedure indicates that the otherwise stubborn authorities can be persuaded not to do more harm if the civil society, social media users and international organizations work together." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/02/macedonia-ngos-and-netizens-prevent-undemocratic-youth-law/
NARR: Against the Draft Law on Youth is a democracy and rule of law campaign opposed to a "Youth Law" proposed in Macedonia, with the initiator, Youth Educational Forum, based in Macedonia, and the target, the Macedonian government, also based in Macedonia. Digital activity consisted of websites, blogs, and Facebook and Twitter tagging. Offline activity consisted of a meeting of stakeholders and NGOs in Macedonia. The structure of the campaign appears to be a coalition of several different NGOs organizing under the same umbrella cause. As of June 18, 2013, the campaign has achieved complete success, since the Macedonian government withdrew the proposed law. JL

TITLE: Against Police Brutality in Macedonia
GOALDESC: "The protesters were demanding full disclosure of all aspects of the crime and the alleged cover-up ... of a murder of a man during street celebrations for the re-election victory of Macedonia's ruling party" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/specialcoverage/2011-special-coverage/macedonia-protests-2011/
INITDESC: INDIV "Macedonians" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/specialcoverage/2011-special-coverage/macedonia-protests-2011/
PARTOFF: "Macedonians protested daily throughout the month of June 2011 against the police cover-up of a murder of a man during street celebrations for the re-election victory of Macedonia's ruling party" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/specialcoverage/2011-special-coverage/macedonia-protests-2011/
OUTDESC: "The police officer, Igor Spasov, member of the special forces and the only person on trial for the murder of Martin Neshkoski, received a sentence of 14 years in prison ... The public prosecutor denied [mk] the victim's family's formal request to press criminal charges against the known and unknown accomplices" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/01/21/macedonia-policeman-who-beat-young-man-to-death-gets-14-years-in-prison/
NARR: Against Police Brutality in Macedonia is a democracy and rule of law campaign aimed at bringing a police officer to justice for the murder of a young man, with the initiators, Macedonian citizens, based in Macedonia and the target, government authorities, also based in Macedonia. Digital activity consisted of almost 6,000 tweets, blogs, and video. Offline activity consisted of protests in Macedonia with an unspecified number of participants. The structure of the campaign appears to be a grassroots upwelling of angered citizens. As of June 24, 2013, the campaign has been completely successful, as the police officer received a prison sentence. JL

TITLE: Against the Veles Lead Smelting Factory
GOALDESC: "against restarting of the lead smelting factory in the city of Veles" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/15/macedonia-veles-says-no-to-lead-poisoning-government-remains-ambiguous/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "the group of NGO's called “Green coalition”" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/15/macedonia-veles-says-no-to-lead-poisoning-government-remains-ambiguous/
PARTOFF: "Estimates of the number of the protest participants range from 10,000 to over 15,000" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/15/macedonia-veles-says-no-to-lead-poisoning-government-remains-ambiguous/
OUTDESC: Unclear whether lead-smelting factory will be reopened - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/15/macedonia-veles-says-no-to-lead-poisoning-government-remains-ambiguous/
NARR: Against the Veles Lead Smelting Factory is a health campaign aiming to protest against the restarting of the lead smelting factory in Veles with the initiator(s), Veles citizens, based in MAcedonia and the target(s), the Macedonian PM. Digital activity consisted of YouTube, Twitter, Facebook, and blogs. Offline activity consisted of at least one protest in Veles, Macedonia. The structure of the campaign can best be described as amateur protests of many individuals, backed up by some sparse online activity. As of June 17, 2013 the campaign is ongoing, as Facebook posts on the official page have been posted in the past couple months. DS

TITLE: Free Burma’s Video Journalists
GOALDESC: "to ‘Free Burma’s Video Journalists ", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/03/myanmar-interactive-prison-map/
INITDESC: INDIV (no description)
SITE: "The website also includes testimonies from former political detainees who bravely shared their prison experiences" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/03/myanmar-interactive-prison-map/
OUTDESC: "ALL DVB VIDEO JOURNALISTS WERE FREED FROM PRISON ON JANUARY 14 2012", http://www.freeburmavj.org/
NARR: Free Burma’s Video Journalists is a democracy campaign aiming to free jailed journalists with the initiator(s), an informal group, based in Myanmar and the target(s), the government based in Myanmar. Digital activity consisted of interactive maps and a website. Offline activity consisted of a protest. The structure of the campaign can best be described as formal. As of June 24, 2013 the campaign is over, date unknown, as the prisoners have been released. KS

TITLE: Arab Spring: Mauritania
GOALDESC: "[for] social, political and economic reforms, and an end to Mauritania's military rule" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/26/mauritania-pro-democracy-protests-break-out-in-nouakchott/
INITDESC: INDIV "young people" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/26/mauritania-pro-democracy-protests-break-out-in-nouakchott/

OUTDESC: No outcome listed as result of protest - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_Spring
NARR: Arab Spring: Mauritania is a democracy campaign aiming to end corruption with the initiator(s), individuals and informal groups, based in Mauritania and the target(s), the regime, based in Mauritania. Digital activity consisted of Twitter and Facebook. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a large and loose coalition. As of June 28, 2013 the campaign is ongoing, with success unknown. KS

TITLE: Against the Peaceful Assembly Bill
GOALDESC: "[against the] Malaysian government’s plan to table the Peaceful Assembly Bill" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/29/malaysia-protesting-the-peaceful-assembly-bill/
INITDESC: INDIV "citizens" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/29/malaysia-protesting-the-peaceful-assembly-bill/
SOCNET: "there is also a Facebook group set up to protest the introduction of the law" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/29/malaysia-protesting-the-peaceful-assembly-bill/
PARTOFF: "300 people gathering in KLCC park in protest of this very bill" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/29/malaysia-protesting-the-peaceful-assembly-bill/
OUTDESC: "The Parliament has approved the bill with no dissenting votes after the Opposition walked out of the sessions" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/29/malaysia-protesting-the-peaceful-assembly-bill/
NARR: Against the Peaceful Assembly Bill is a rule of law campaign aiming to pass a bill with the initiator(s), citizens,  based in Malaysia and the target(s), the government, based in Malaysia. Digital activity consisted of video, twitter, and blogs. Offline activity consisted a peace march. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a crowd-driven effort. As of June 19, 2013 the campaign is over with success as the bill was passed. KS

TITLE: Prime Minister Najib Tun Razak: Resign
GOALDESC: "The resignation of the Prime Minister was demanded on the same day when thousands of people marched in the streets during the Bersih 2.0 rally last July 9." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/07/15/malaysia-facebook-netizens-want-prime-minister-to-resign/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Malaysian netizens" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/07/15/malaysia-facebook-netizens-want-prime-minister-to-resign/
OUTDESC: "Dato' Sri Haji Mohammad Najib bin Tun Haji Abdul Razak (born 23 July 1953) is a Malaysian politician who has been the sixth Prime Minister of Malaysia since 2009." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Najib_Razak
NARR: Prime Minister Najib Tun Razak: Resign is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming obtain the resignation of the Malaysian Prime Minister. The initiators are individuals who opposed to the arrest , by police, of more than a thousand offline” activists who were asking for democratic reforms. The ain platform is an Facebook page with more than 255K likes. It also count with blog posts and Twitter activity. There is no information regarding offline participation for this specific campaign, however theres is information about Bersih 2.0 (a sister offline campaign). The structure of the campaign can best be described as the digitalization of offline protest.  As of June 14, 2013 the campaign has failed to achieve its goals, and the Prime Minister remain in office. LS

TITLE: Demanding a Constitution for Nepal
GOALDESC: "demanding that the constitution be drafted by the May 28 deadline" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/18/nepal-social-media-as-a-civic-activism-tool/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "NepalUnites" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/18/nepal-social-media-as-a-civic-activism-tool/
MICBLOG: "NepalUnites is very active at Facebook,Twitter and YouTube" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/18/nepal-social-media-as-a-civic-activism-tool/
PARTOFF: "On Saturday May 7, 2011, hundreds gathered at a public square in Kathmandu demanding that the constitution be drafted by the May 28 deadline" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/18/nepal-social-media-as-a-civic-activism-tool/
OUTDESC: "After May 29, 2011 the Constituent Assembly kept on extending the Interim Constitution by a few months at a time" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Nepal#Nepal_Constituent_Assembly
NARR: Demanding a Constitution for Nepal is a democracy campaign aiming to get the Constitution drafted with the initiator(s), individuals, based in Nepal and the target(s), the government based in Nepal. Digital activity consisted of Facebook and blogs and videos. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described asa large network. As of June 18, 2013 the campaign is ongoing, without success as the constitution has still not been written. KS

TITLE: Pushing for Better Governance in Nepal
GOALDESC: "protest against the current situation of political deadlock and inability of the government to finish the constitution. The program was themed, "Constitution: no work no pay"... “Constitution should come out on time, if it does not the politicians have no rights to waste the people’s tax paid money", http://www.movements.org/blog/entry/nepal-activism-hacktivism-facebook/
INITDESC: INDIV, "A youth based Facebook group “The Red Revolution” organized a silent protest at Basantapur in Kathmandu", http://www.movements.org/blog/entry/nepal-activism-hacktivism-facebook/
TARGDESC: " A youth based Facebook group “The Red Revolution” organized a silent protest at Basantapur in Kathmandu agaisnt the current situation of political deadlock and inability of the government to finsih the constitution", http://www.movements.org/blog/entry/nepal-activism-hacktivism-facebook/
PARTOFF: "The rally started from Basantapur Durba square at 8:00 AM in the morning towards Birendra International Convention Center (BICC) which is the current official work station of the Constitution Assembly Members (CAM) . Hundred of youth’s voiced and protested slogans like NO WORK NO PAY", http://www.movements.org/blog/entry/nepal-activism-hacktivism-facebook/
OUTDESC: "On May 28, 2012, Prime Minister Baburam Bhattarai dissolved the Constituent Assembly after it failed to finish the constitution in its last time extension, ending four years of constitution drafting and leaving the country in a legal vacuum.[2][3] Election of the new Constituent Assembly is due Spring 2013.", http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Nepal
NARR: Pushing for Better Governance in Nepal is a democracy campaign aiming to protest delays in writing the constitution with the initiator(s), an informal organization, based in Nepal and the target(s), the government based in Nepal. Digital activity consisted of videos and Facebook. Offline activity consisted of a silent protest. The structure of the campaign can best be described as amateur. As of June 14, 2013 the campaign is over, without success. KS

TITLE: Force Finance Minister Bharat to Resign
GOALDESC: "demand is resignation of Finance Minister Bharat Mohan Adhikary.", "keep civil servants safe from political meddling." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/04/nepal-frustrated-undercurrents/
INITDESC: INDIV "At Twitter and on the blogosphere, some young people have already started organizing." , "Blogger Ushaft is now leading the call for more youth lead direct action" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/04/nepal-frustrated-undercurrents/
TARGDESC: "As the public anger gather momentum and the pressure on the government grows," - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/04/nepal-frustrated-undercurrents/
OUTDESC: "Rameshwor Khanal , who created a stir when he resigned as finance secretary in the previous government of Prime Minister Jhalanath Khanal, was appointed economic advisor to Prime Minister Baburam Bhattarai througha cabinet decision." - http://ranabhola.blogspot.com/2011/09/rameshwor-khanal-appointed-pms-economic.html
NARR: Force Finance Minister Bharat to Resign is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to seek the resignation of the Nepali Finance Minister with the initiator(s), Nepali bloggers, based in NPL and the target(s), the NPL Finance Minister. Digital activity consisted of use of Twitter, blogs, and Facebook. No offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose and amateur campaign organied by anonymouse netizens and forwarded by a few bloggers; seems very informal. As of July 2, 2013 the campaign is unclear in outcome, since there was a confusion with the sources/goaldesc. DS

TITLE: Arab Spring: Oman
GOALDESC:
"[for:] (1) An end to corruption in the government
(2) More jobs for people in need
(3) increase in salaries for the poor, widows and divorced women
(4) Lowering prices
(5) An end to financial and administrative wasta (influence/nepotism) in the government and private sector" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/26/oman-the-people-want-an-end-to-corruption/
INITDESC: INDIV "Omanis" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/26/oman-the-people-want-an-end-to-corruption/
PARTOFF: "“The people want an end to corruption” chanted thousands of Omanis, who have been protesting since Friday in Salalah and Sohar" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/26/oman-the-people-want-an-end-to-corruption/
OUTDESC:
"[Outcome:] Economic concessions by Sultan Qaboos
Dismissal of ministers
Granting of lawmaking powers to Oman's elected legislature" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_Spring
NARR: Arab Spring: Oman is primarily an economic justice campaign with a number of goals related to economic opportunity and corruption, though not regime change.  The campaign seems to have been organized by individual Omanis and the target is the Sultan. Digital activity consisted of tweeting news of the protests and capturing video. Offline activity consisted of protests in the hundred and thousands in the cities of Muscat, Salalah, and Sohar. The structure of the campaign can best be described as loosely connected individuals who put forth a range of reform goals, some specific (“We want the Shura Council to have legislative powers!) and some general (“The people want an end to corruption”). As of July 1, 2013, the campaign is a partial success, if only because of the broad of goals and the vague nature of some.  The Sultan made a number of significant concessions, including giving the Shura lawmaking authority and making economic concessions. MJ

TITLE: For Democratic Process in Changing Panamanian Electoral Law
GOALDESC: Against "The controversial and unilateral decisions taken by the current Panamanian government " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/08/panama-twitter-sparks-protests-against-the-government/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Civil society " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/08/panama-twitter-sparks-protests-against-the-government/
PARTOFF: " hundreds of Panamanians agreed to honk their car horns and hit their pots with spoons." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/08/panama-twitter-sparks-protests-against-the-government/
OUTDESC: "Perhaps the noise will one day reach the president's ears." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/08/panama-twitter-sparks-protests-against-the-government/
NARR: For Democratic Process in Changing Panamanian Electoral Law is a democracy campaign aiming to insist on the rule of law with the initiator(s), Panamanians, based in Panama and the target(s), the government based in Panama. Digital activity consisted of microblogs. Offline activity consisted of honking car horns. The structure of the campaign can best be described as crowdsourced. As of June 24, 2013 the campaign's status is unknown. KS

TITLE: Against Mishandling of Sewage Project in Iquitos
GOALDESC:
"1. The planning of the works in order to avoid blocking whole sectors of the city with traffic.
2. The coordination and scheduling of the execution of works, with the residents of the streets to be repaired.
3. Quality in the works, such as filling the trenches with suitable material and not the same that has been excavated to avoid subsidence.
4. Designing of an emergency plan to repair sunken trenches and not properly resurfaced.
5. The immediate proceeding of the removal of the leftover of work and a total cleaning.
6. The review of the work of the company hired to supervise the company that executes the sewage work.
7. The development of a full plan, coordinating the public with the municipal and regional authorities, in order to overcome the general chaos of the city and restore its beauty and tranquility." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/21/peru-iquitos-against-the-chaos-caused-by-sewage-works/
INITDESC: INFORMAL - "the Amazon Collective" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/21/peru-iquitos-against-the-chaos-caused-by-sewage-works/
TARGDESC: "the Regional Government and Provincial Municipality of Maynas" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/21/peru-iquitos-against-the-chaos-caused-by-sewage-works/
PARTOFF: "meetings and strikes [es] in protest against the broken and not properly closed streets" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/21/peru-iquitos-against-the-chaos-caused-by-sewage-works/
OUTDESC: "Attorney Carlos Perez-Alvarado, of the 8th Corporate Criminal Provincial Prosecutor Maynas, today from 9 am starts proceedings against Wang Yankun and Enrique Asalde Vives, representative of China International Water & Electric Corp. and General Contractors SAC ASWO." - http://diariolaregion.com/web/2013/01/08/ejecutivos-de-empresa-china-son-citados-a-fiscalia-ante-denuncia-de-la-municipalidad-de-punchana/
NARR: Against Mishandling of Sewage Project in Iquitos is an environmental campaign aiming to control a development project in Peru, initiated by locals. Digital activity consisted of blogs and Facebook use. Offline activity consisted of a meeting in Iquitos, Peru. The structure of the campaign can best be described as local-based and effective. As of July 3, 2013, the campaign is partially achieved because, while it is unclear whether all the outlined goals were met, the contractor responsible for the project was facing trial for mishandling the project. RM

TITLE: Stop all Mining in Puno
GOALDESC: "[for] the cancellation of all mining concessions in [the] Puno [region in Peru] ... [and for] a repeal of the Decreto Supremo 082-2007-EM" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/10/peru-aymara-indigenous-people-announce-resumption-of-protests-in-puno/
INITDESC: FORMAL "the Aymara Indians" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/10/peru-aymara-indigenous-people-announce-resumption-of-protests-in-puno/
PARTOFF: "around 15,000 Aymaras seized [es] the city of Puno, after which they incited violence [es] that paralised the Puno capital for days and left many tourists stranded" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/10/peru-aymara-indigenous-people-announce-resumption-of-protests-in-puno/
OUTDESC: "The government has rejected the cancellation [es], but came to an agreement with the Aymara communities to suspend mining and petroleum concessions in Puno for 14 months in four provinces" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/10/peru-aymara-indigenous-people-announce-resumption-of-protests-in-puno/
NARR: Stop all Mining in Puno is a rights of ethnic minorities and immigrants campaign aiming to stop all mining concessions in Puno, Peru. The initiators are Aymaras Indigenous communities from Puno region. The target is the central government in charge of mining concessions.  The online activity is limited to few blogers supporting the campaign; however, there are some tweets against the Aymaras campaign. Offline activity consisted of violent occupation of the main city plaza, blocking streets and clashing with the police.  The structure of the campaign can best be described as a traditional indigenous’ right mobilization -only informed by digital tools. As of June 25, 2013 the campaign has not achieved its goals and the mining activities continue. LS

TITLE: Stop Exploiting Ripley Workers
GOALDESC: "protesting for workers’ rights and a raise in salary similar to the Ripley employees in Chile." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/22/peru-customers-show-support-for-ripley-department-store-employees/
INITDESC: FORMAL "The Ripley workers’ union continues its protests on the streets as well as on its Facebook page.", INDIV "many Ripley customers to take the opportunity to express their disappointment with the company, organizing a Facebook virtual event called “Campaña para no comprar en Tiendas Ripley” (Campaign Against Buying from Ripley Stores)" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/22/peru-customers-show-support-for-ripley-department-store-employees/
SOCNET: https://www.facebook.com/events/115767785188157/, "The Ripley workers’ union continues its protests on the streets as well as on its Facebook page." - https://www.facebook.com/sindicato.ripleyperu (broken),
PARTOFF: "YouTube user Marciel Soto (Marcialsotosanchez) uploaded this video from the union protests", "The Ripley workers’ union continues its protests on the streets" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/22/peru-customers-show-support-for-ripley-department-store-employees/
OUTDESC: "Employees from two of Peru’s major retail stores took to the streets of Lima on Wednesday to protest low salaries and working conditions." - http://www.peruthisweek.com/news-3245-peru-ripley-and-saga-employees-protest-over-work-conditions/
NARR: 1828 is a economic justice campaign aiming to demand fair wages for workers of a company with the initiator(s), Peruvian workers, based in PER and the target(s), the Ripley retail store company based in Chile. Digital activity consisted of video, Facebook, Twitter, and blog. Offline activity consisted of strikes in Peru. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a group of workers from the same retail store organizing the protest, though it doesn't seem to be professionally organized. As of July 15, 2013 the campaign is not at all successful since there is no indication of a response from the company itself. DS

TITLE: Improve Conditions at Manila Zoo
GOALDESC: "The sorry state of Manila Zoo caused a stir among Filipino netizens after photos were posted online" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/14/philippines-uproar-over-sorry-state-of-manila-zoo/
INITDESC: INFORMAL " Nix de Pano " - http://org/2011/08/14/philippines-uproar-over-sorry-state-of-manila-zoo/
MICBLOG: "resulting in the rise of the keywords “Manila Zoo” as a popular trending topic on Twitter last month." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/14/philippines-uproar-over-sorry-state-of-manila-zoo/
OUTDESC: "I have never been in a Zoo and walked out of it miserable. The condition of the animals here is very poor. I don't understand why they still continue to operate." - http://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g298573-d531663-r160528882-Manila_Zoo-Manila_Metro_Manila_Luzon.html#REVIEWS
NARR: Improve Conditions at Manila Zoo is an environmental protection campaign aiming to  stop plans to get more animals for the zoo. They are demanding for the improvement of the animals’ welfare and ultimately, the closing of the zoo . The initiator are few blogers from Manila that posted pictures of the state of animals. Digital activity consisted of  blog posts, and online petition supported by an international environmental organization.There is no information regarding offline participation. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a crowd that also included people attacking the campaign for being outdated. As of June 14, 2013 the campaign has failed to achieve its goals, and current reviews  complaining about the state of the animals. LS

TITLE: Against the Anti-Planking Bill
GOALDESC: In support of planking - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/26/philippines-anti-planking-bill-draws-more-planks/
INITDESC: "Youth groups" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/26/philippines-anti-planking-bill-draws-more-planks/
PARTOFF: "critics even planking in front of Castelo's own office in Congress to mock the measure." "the 10,000-strong march of public university students and teachers"- http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/26/philippines-anti-planking-bill-draws-more-planks/
OUTDESC: " Despite the criticisms, Castelo is still defending his bill, maintaining that it is something relevant enough to be tackled by a national legislature, and clarified that he is not against planking but it should be done in safety." - http://en.wikipilipinas.org/index.php?title=Anti-planking_bill_of_2011
NARR: Against the Anti-Planking Bill is an Information and expression campaign aiming to condemn the bill that forbid planking. The initiators are group of young activists (mainly students) in Manila, Philippines and the target is the House Representative Costelo. Digital activity consisted of a Facebook page and Twitter posting (no Hashtag). Offline activity consisted of planking protest in Manila, Philippines and the Congress. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an offline traditional street “sitting” protests but now lying down which was minimally amplified by social media. As of June 12, 2013 the campaign is uncertain on whether the goal was achieved or not. LS

TITLE: "Free Ericson Acosta"
GOALDESC: ""Civil society groups, writers, artists, his family and friends have decried these allegations as trumped-up and called for his unconditional and immediate release..", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/15/philippines-political-prisoner-writes-online-prison-diary/
INITDESC: "Civil society groups, writers, artists, his family and friends have decried these allegations as trumped-up and called for his unconditional and immediate release..", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/15/philippines-political-prisoner-writes-online-prison-diary/
OUTDESC: "PEN International is delighted to learn that on January 31, 2013, the case against poet, song-writer, journalist, and activist Ericson Acosta was dismissed for lack of evidence. Acosta had been held without trial since February 2011" http://worldvoices.pen.org/rapid-action/2013/02/01/poet-ericson-acosta-released-charges-dropped#sthash.erI99hiT.dpuf"
NARR: "Free Ericson Acosta" is a rule of law campaign aiming to free the political prisoners Ericson Acosta, initiated by his friends and family.  Though the target is a government entity, the specific entity is not stated. Digital activity consisted of video, a Facebook page, an e-petition, and a blog written by Acotsa himself. Offline activity consisted of at least one public meeting presenting information on his case. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a group of volunteers directly connected to Acosta offline starting an online campaign to free him. As of July 16, 2013 the campaign is a success.  Charges were dropped and he was freed. MJ

TITLE: For Total Abortion Ban in Poland
GOALDESC: "[for] the draft amendment to Poland's abortion law intending to ban abortion in Poland without exceptions" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/07/05/poland-citizen-initiative-for-complete-abortion-ban/
INITDESC: FORMAL "Citizen Legislative Committee created by PRO–Right to Life Foundation" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/07/05/poland-citizen-initiative-for-complete-abortion-ban/
OUTDESC: "The Parliament in Poland has voted down legislation that would strengthen the nation’s existing pro-life laws by instituting a complete ban on abortions in the Catholic eastern European nation." - http://www.lifenews.com/2011/08/24/poland-mps-vote-down-legislation-for-complete-abortion-ban/
NARR: For Total Abortion Ban in Poland is a gender and sexuality campaigned aimed at banning all abortions in Poland, with the initiator, PRO–Right to Life Foundation, based in Poland, and the target, the Polish parliament, also based in Poland. Digital activity consisted of 9365 Facebook likes and 600000 petition signatures. Offline activity consisted of a draft amendment submitted to parliament and a protest with at least one participant. The structure of the campaign is centered around the anti-abortion formal organization. As of June 18, 2013, the campaign has not achieved any success, since the draft bill was voted down. JL.

TITLE: To Amend the Drug Law in Poland
GOALDESC: "crowdsourcing ideas to improve Polish legislation." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/08/poland-facebook-initiative-puts-pressure-on-politicians/
INITDESC: FORMAL " “Appeal to parliamentarians” " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/08/poland-facebook-initiative-puts-pressure-on-politicians/
OUTDESC: "Encouraged by the success of the campaign" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/08/poland-facebook-initiative-puts-pressure-on-politicians/
NARR: To Amend the Drug Law in Poland is a democracy campaign aiming to increase citizen input on laws with the initiator(s), an informal organization, based in Poland and the target(s), the government based in Poland. Digital activity consisted of Facebook and videos. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as formal. As of June 14, 2013 the campaign is over, with successful passage of the law. KS

TITLE: The Indignados of Portugal
GOALDESC: "calling for “participatory democracy, transparency in policy and the end of the precariousness of life”" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/17/portugal-15opt-videos-photos/
INITDESC: INDIV "80,000 “indignados” (protestors) in the main squares of eight cities around the country." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/17/portugal-15opt-videos-photos/, INFORMAL "A People's Assembly was organized afterwards with around 100 players and several approved proposals, such as the permanence of the occupation, the call for initiatives of peaceful civil disobedience, and a new demonstration on 26 November." - http://5dias.net/contacto/
TARGDESC: "Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho announced historic cuts for public servants" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/17/portugal-15opt-videos-photos/
SOCNET: ""The governments piss all over us! Media tells us it is raining!" (Coimbra, 15/10/2011). Photo by Aurélio Malva shared on Facebook." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/17/portugal-15opt-videos-photos/
PARTOFF: "gathered around 80,000 “indignados” (protestors) in the main squares of eight cities around the country.", "In the city of Porto around 15,000 demonstrators marched from Batalha Square to Liberdade Square" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/10/17/portugal-15opt-videos-photos/
OUTDESC: "the Government argues that "the country has to impoverish citizens have emigrated and pay the debt is the sole purpose a down economy. "" - http://www.dn.pt/inicio/portugal/interior.aspx?content_id=2138062
NARR: The Indignados of Portugal is an economic-justice campaign aimed at ending austerity measues, with the initiators, protestors called indignados, based in Portugal and the target, the prime minister, also based in Portugal. Digital activity consisted of over 80,000 tweets, blog posts, and videos. Offline activity consisted of 80,000 protestors nationwide, including thousands of protestors in Lisbon and 15,000 protestors in Porto. The structure of the campaign appears to be a grassroots uprising of concerned individuals. As of June 24, 2013, it is unclear whether the campaign has achieved any success, as there was no indication of a response. JL

TITLE: Against Legislative Election Fraud in Russia
GOALDESC: "against election fraud [in Russia]" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/05/russia-the-revolt-of-net-hamsters/

NARR: Against Legislative Election Fraud in Russia is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to rally against election fraud with the initiator(s), an informal Russian organization, and the target(s), the Russian government or ruling party. Digital activity consisted of use of Twitter, blogs, and video. Offline activity consisted of protests in Russian cities. The structure of the campaign can best be described as pretty loosely organization around one informal organization, numbering in few thousands. As of June 18, 2013 the campaign is partially successful since there was a government response, thought the goals were not fully accomplished. DS

TITLE: For Political Freedom in Qatif
GOALDESC: "the people of Qatif took to the streets to demand reforms, equality, the release of their detainees, and political freedom" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/05/saudi-arabia-netizens-turn-to-online-activism-to-draw-attention-to-qatif-protests/
INITDESC: INDIV "the people of Qatif" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/05/saudi-arabia-netizens-turn-to-online-activism-to-draw-attention-to-qatif-protests/
SOCNET: "The youth of Qatif used YouTube, Facebook and Twitter as their platform to spread the news from the protests" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/05/saudi-arabia-netizens-turn-to-online-activism-to-draw-attention-to-qatif-protests/
PARTOFF: "The month of November marked the return of protests to the Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia in 2011, as the people of Qatif took to the streets" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/05/saudi-arabia-netizens-turn-to-online-activism-to-draw-attention-to-qatif-protests/, "Bahrainis protesting in solidarity with the people of Qatif" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/05/saudi-arabia-netizens-turn-to-online-activism-to-draw-attention-to-qatif-protests/, "protests also moved to Istanbul, Turkey" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/05/saudi-arabia-netizens-turn-to-online-activism-to-draw-attention-to-qatif-protests/
OUTDESC: " The government declared protests to be illegal and it had previously warned against this action. NARR: For Political Freedom in Qatif is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to have political prisoners released, demand reforms and political freedom, with the initiator(s), the people of Qatif, based in Saudi Arabia and the target(s), the Saudi Arabian government. Digital activity consisted of use of Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube. Offline activity consisted of multiple protests in cities throughout Saudi Arabia. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose crowd of individuals from different locations who participated either online, offline, or in both ways. As of June 17, 2013 the campaign is unclear whether or not it is successful, as there is no information presented on that matter. DS

GOALDESC: " is a campaign by Saudi Arabian women, who have more rights denied to them by the regime than men,[1] for the right to drive motor vehicles on public roads", http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women_to_drive_movement#2011.E2.80.932012_campaign
INITDESC: " is a campaign by Saudi Arabian women, who have more rights denied to them by the regime than men,[1] for the right to drive motor vehicles on public roads. ", http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women_to_drive_movement#2011.E2.80.932012_campaign

Digital activity consisted ofFacebook. Offline activity consisted ofn women driving cars. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a large, crowd-sourced campaign. As of June 19, 2013  the campaign is over, with partial success, as some women are able to drive but most rights are still very limited. KS

"Economic concessions by King Abdullah[154][155]

King Abdullah announces women's approval to vote and be elected in 2015 municipal elections and to be nominated to the Shura Council[158]", http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_Spring
NARR: Arab Spring: Saudi Arabia is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to have a political prisoner released with the initiator(s), Saudi Arabian ctiizens, and the target(s), Saudi Arabian authorities. Digital activity consisted of Facebook, Twitter, and video. Offline activity consisted of protests in 2 cities in Saudi Arabia. The structure of the campaign can best be described as loose and amateur protests online and offline. TITLE: Free Alim Boushi
GOALDESC: "Alim’s freedom is our demand", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/01/18/sudan-sudanese-activist-alim-boushi-freed-from-prison/

NARR: Free Alim Boushi is a human rights campaign aiming to free a blogger with the initiator(s), individuals and formal groups, based in the Sudan and the target(s), the Sudanese government based in the Sudan. Digital activity consisted of blogs, twitter and videos. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formalized and loose coalition. As of June 18, 2013 the campaign is over, with complete success, after his release. KS

TITLE: Against Power Cuts in Senegal
GOALDESC: "its discontent at power cuts", "attacks mass unemployment, police brutality and corruption", "But above all, it tries to make people take part.", "mobilise young people and give them a voice in anticipation of the 2012 presidential election." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/08/senegal-enough-is-enough-movement-first-the-web-now-the-presidential-palace/
INITDESC: INDIV "The group hails from the Dakar suburbs and is led by several local rappers, including Fou Malad, Thiat (from the group Keur Gui) and Matador. " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/08/senegal-enough-is-enough-movement-first-the-web-now-the-presidential-palace/
TARGDESC: "Enough is Enough does not hesitate to slam President Abdoulaye Wade's government" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/08/senegal-enough-is-enough-movement-first-the-web-now-the-presidential-palace/
MICBLOG: "Many young Senegalese have shown their support for the campaign on Facebook and Twitter" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/08/senegal-enough-is-enough-movement-first-the-web-now-the-presidential-palace/
PARTOFF: "The outcome: several hundred young enthusiasts, but most notably, the police – who were on the lookout under the shadow of the obelisk – did not use any tear gas." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/08/senegal-enough-is-enough-movement-first-the-web-now-the-presidential-palace/
OUTDESC: "Senelec rehabilitated its machinery and generators under a plan started by the administration of President Abdoulaye Wade, boosting output by 70 megawatts, Diallo said. Macky Sall, who defeated Wade in a March election, said in July the government would spend 120 billion CFA francs ($236 million) on subsidies to keep the price of power from Senelec down." - http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-10-30/senegal-sells-power-surplus-to-neighbors-as-output-rises
NARR: Against Power Cuts in Senegal is a economic justice campaign aiming to protest the power cuts with the initiator(s), an informal org in Senegal, and the target(s), the Senegalese power utilities. Digital activity consisted of use of Facebook, Twitter, and video. Offline activity consisted of  protests in Senegal. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a relatively loose group of Senegalese youth and informally organized rappers working to have their message heard in public. As of June 18, 2013 the campaign is completely successful, since Senegal has made corrections in this area and will be selling surplus power to neighboring countries to benefit the economy. DS

TITLE: Against Electoral Reform in Senegal
GOALDESC: "derail the electoral reform that would allow the election of the president with 25% of the votes in the first round and would also propose a dual ticket with a vice-president, much like the American electoral system. " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/29/senegal-the-protests-will-be-twitterized/

While no one can deny that the street was able to bend the government, a phenomenon which some have called the “Peanut Revolution”, President Wade has stated that he withdrew the bill under pressure from religious leaders" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/29/senegal-the-protests-will-be-twitterized/

Offline activity consisted of protests in Dakar, Senegal. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a crowd-based network. As of 14 July 2013, the campaign is successful because the protests accomplished their stated goal. RM

TITLE: Save the World's Saddest Dolphins
GOALDESC:
"Please ask Resorts World to let the dolphins go. Please lend your voice and support.
" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/13/singapore-%E2%80%98save-the-world%E2%80%99s-saddest-dolphins%E2%80%99-campaign/

Offline activity consisted at least of a small demonstration outside of the park. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a single NGO campaign which get internationally amplified by associating with other international NGOs who work in the same issue.  As June 14, 2013 the campaign is has not achieved its goals because the dolphins are still at the park. LS

INITDESC: FORMAL ""Union leaders and activists in Swaziland took to the streets of Manzini on Tuesday 12 and Wednesday 13 April, 2011, demanding political reform and calling on King Mswati III, Africa's last absolute monarch, to return power to the people.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/13/swaziland-protest-leaders-journalists-arrested/"
TARGDESC: "Union leaders and activists in Swaziland took to the streets of Manzini on Tuesday 12 and Wednesday 13 April, 2011, demanding political reform and calling on King Mswati III, Africa's last absolute monarch, to return power to the people.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/13/swaziland-protest-leaders-journalists-arrested/""
PARTOFF: "Union leaders and activists in Swaziland took to the streets of Manzini on Tuesday 12 and Wednesday 13 April, 2011...Riot police fired tear gas at protesters, arrested union leaders and journalists.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/13/swaziland-protest-leaders-journalists-arrested/

NARR: For Democracy in Swaziland is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to have the Swazi king give more power to the people with the initiator(s), a few formal and informal orgs, based in SWZ and USA and the target(s), the Swazi king. Digital activity consisted of use of Facebook, Twitter, and blogs. Offline activity consisted of protests in the street. The structure of the campaign can best be described as organized by many formal and informal groups working in conjuction if not directly together, as well as individual participants. As of June 17, 2013 the campaign is unclear on success as nothing is mention in these articles, though it appears to be ongoing. DS

TITLE: Free Anas Maarawi
GOALDESC: "This summer, Bank of America proposed a new $5 monthly fee for any customer who tried to use a debit card. I was angry that Bank of America decided to set its sights on my meager checking account to pad its profits and pay out huge bonuses to the very folks who wrecked the economy in the first place. That's why I started a petition on Change.org, where anyone, anywhere, can start a campaign about the issues they care about.", http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/nov/02/petition-bank-of-america-debit-card-fee
INITDESC:
INDIV, "A month ago, if you had asked me if a 22-year-old woman working two jobs could successfully challenge one of the most powerful corporations in the world, I would have laughed.
With Bank of America's announcement Tuesday that it will drop its unpopular $5 debit card fee, I know that a 22-year-old woman (namely, myself, Molly Katchpole), with a little social media support, can go head to head with a corporate giant. And she can win.", http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/nov/02/petition-bank-of-america-debit-card-fee
TARGDESC: "pressure on Bank of America. Brian Moynihan, Bank of America's CEO.", http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/nov/02/petition-bank-of-america-debit-card-fee
OUTDESC: "Bank of America has ditched its plan to charge a $5 monthly debit card fee", http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/nov/02/petition-bank-of-america-debit-card-fee
NARR: Free Anas Maarawi is a democracy campaign aiming to free a blogger with the initiator(s), individuals, based in Syria and the target(s), the government based in Syria. Digital activity consisted of blogs, Twitter and Facebook. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a network of connected, concerned bloggers. As of June 14, 2013 the campaign is successful, with the blogger's release. KS

TITLE: Free Razan
GOALDESC: "Syrian authorities have arrested blogger Razan Ghazzawi.... Her arrest has drawn criticism and anger from bloggers and activists around the world, who called for her immediate release.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/04/syria-free-razan-ghazzawi/

NARR: Free Razan is a democracy and rule of law campaigned aimed at getting a Syrian blogger released, with the initiators, netizens, based in Syria, and the target, the Syrian government, also based in Syria. Digital activity consisted of nearly 10000 tweets and over 6000 Facebook likes. There was no indication of offline activity. The structure of the campaign appeared to be centered around a number of well-connected bloggers and online personalities. As of June 17, 2013, the campaign has achieved complete success, as the Syrian government released the imprisoned blogger not long after she was arrested. JL

TITLE: Remove the Assad Regime from Power in Syria

NARR: Remove the Assad Regime from Power in Syria is a democracy and rule of law campaign aimed at forcing the Assad regime out of power, with the initiators, Syrian citizens, based in Syria, and the target, President Assad, also based in Syria. Digital activity consisted of hacking attacks by Anonymous, websites, over 200,000 tweets, blogs, and videos. Offline activity consisted of several protests and demonstrations in Syria ranging from dozens to thousands of participants as well as supportive protests in Lebanon and Brazil. The structure of the campaign appears to be a grassroots uprising comprising Syrian citizens. As of July 9, 2013, the campaign has achieved partial success, since some members of the Syrian government resigned and parts of the country are controlled by opposition forces. JL

TITLE: For Press Freedom in Togo
