As of June 24, 2013, the campaign is over, with partial success as prisoners were released but journalist freedom still declines. KS

TITLE: For Assertiveness in Preah Vihear Border Dispute
GOALDESC: "The protesters insist that Thailand is not being assertive enough in the Preah Vihear border dispute against Cambodia." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/01/thailand-the-yellow-shirt-protesters-are-back/
INITDESC: FORMAL "Thailand’s Yellow Shirt protesters are back in the streets. ... The Yellow Shirts are members of the People's Alliance for Democracy (PAD)." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People's_Alliance_for_Democracy
TARGDESC: " against key government officials", "PM Abhisit and 3 other ministers" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/01/thailand-the-yellow-shirt-protesters-are-back/
PARTOFF: "The Red Shirts have recently gathered tens of thousands of their members to demand the resignation of the ‘undemocratic’ Abhisit government.", "Thailand’s Yellow Shirt protesters are back in the streets." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/01/thailand-the-yellow-shirt-protesters-are-back/
OUTDESC: "Thailand, which will make its case on Wednesday, said that it would "fight the case transparently and with [its] best effort"." - http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22149576
NARR: For Assertiveness in Preah Vihear Border Dispute is a country-border conflict campaign aiming to demand the Thai government to tight policies towards Cambodia. The initiators are a group called Yellow shirts, based in Thailand. The target is the Thai government.  Digital activity consisted of blog posts favoring the campaign, but also from opposing groups, both in Thailand and Cambodia. The structure of the campaign can best be described as interest group pressuring government, the online activity is mainly informative of the offline clashes.  As of June 25, 2013 the campaign seems achieved its goals, because clashes between parts resulted in 18 killed people what it seems the Thai government strengthened its position. The conflict is now being heard by the international Court.  LS

TITLE: Free Samir Feriani
GOALDESC: "for the immediate release of Samir Feriani" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/13/tunisia-a-protest-to-free-a-government-critic/
INITDESC: "Human Rights Watch" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/13/tunisia-a-protest-to-free-a-government-critic/
PARTOFF: "Protesters took to the streets in the Tunisian capital Tunis yesterday, calling for the immediate release of Samir Feriani" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/06/13/tunisia-a-protest-to-free-a-government-critic/
OUTDESC: "On September 22, Feriani was released by a military court" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samir_Feriani
NARR: Free Samir Feriani is an information and expression campaign aiming to free the police officer Samir Feriani from military detention and drop any charges that are based solely on his whistle-blowing efforts and transfer any other charges to a civilian court. The initiator(s), are Human Rights Watch –NGO based in New York- and individuals  in Tunisia, the target is the Tunisian government. Digital activity consisted of some twits and one video. Offline activity consisted in protest of dozens of citizen on the streets of Tunis, Tunisia. The structure of the campaign can best be described as NGO network coalition supporting an amateur spontaneous campaign. As of June 25, 2013 the campaign has achieved its goals Samir Feriani was released in September 2011, and acquitted of most charges in March 2012. LS

TITLE: For an Independent Judiciary in Tunisia
GOALDESC: “People want independent judiciary” "An independent judiciary capable of bringing to justice former corrupt officials, and those responsible for the murder of peaceful protesters is a key popular demand" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/11/tunisia-people-want-an-independent-judiciary/
INITDESC: INDIV “People" "Activists" "Tunisian netizens" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/11/tunisia-people-want-an-independent-judiciary/
SOCNET: "A protest called “People Want the Revolution Again”, was launched on Facebook, and is due to take place next Saturday night [August, 13]." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/11/tunisia-people-want-an-independent-judiciary/
PARTOFF: "A protest called “People Want the Revolution Again”, was launched on Facebook, and is due to take place next Saturday night [August, 13]." "thousands of Tunisians who demonstrated, and were in sit-ins" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/08/11/tunisia-people-want-an-independent-judiciary/
OUTDESC: The TJC proposes to remedy the issues of concern to the activists, though its success and ultimate passage is unsure. "Tunisia’s National Constituent Assembly should commit to the creation of an independent judiciary free from government interference. The assembly will consider a proposed law to establish a Temporary Judicial Council (TJC)... which would replace the discredited Supreme Judicial Council.... The proposed law... still raises concerns about the extent that ministers would continue to have influence on the disciplining of judges and other issues affecting their independence from government." - http://www.hrw.org/news/2013/03/28/tunisia-new-law-should-create-independent-judges
NARR: For an Independent Judiciary in Tunisia is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to create an independent judiciary in Tunisia, with the initiator(s), Tunisian netizens and international bloggers, based in TUN and USA and the target(s), the Tunisian judiciary. Digital activity consisted of use of Twitter, blogs, Facebook, and video. Offline activity consisted of protests in Tunis, Tunisia. The structure of the campaign can best be described as informal, with a group of people protesting in the streets while seemingly non-networked bloggers wrote online articles or posted on microblogging sites in protest. As of June 24, 2013 the campaign is partially successful since there has been some response - a new law which would create the independent judiciary; but at the time of this article the law has not yet been passed. DS

TITLE: Anti-Censorship Protest in Turkey
GOALDESC: "Thousands of Turks gathered in some 40 cities and towns around the country on Sunday, to join marches organized on Facebook against state Internet censorship.", http://blogs.wsj.com/emergingeurope/2011/05/15/yes-we-ban-turks-protest-internet-censorship/?mod=wsj_qt_latest_wsj
INITDESC: INDIV, "Thousands of Turks gathered in some 40 cities and towns around the country on Sunday, to join marches organized on Facebook against state Internet censorship.", http://blogs.wsj.com/emergingeurope/2011/05/15/yes-we-ban-turks-protest-internet-censorship/?mod=wsj_qt_latest_wsj
TARGDESC: "Turkey’s Internet regulator, the Information and Communication Technologies Authority, or BTK", http://blogs.wsj.com/emergingeurope/2011/05/15/yes-we-ban-turks-protest-internet-censorship/?mod=wsj_qt_latest_wsj
SOCNET: "Thousands of Turks gathered in some 40 cities and towns around the country on Sunday, to join marches organized on Facebook against state Internet censorship.", http://blogs.wsj.com/emergingeurope/2011/05/15/yes-we-ban-turks-protest-internet-censorship/?mod=wsj_qt_latest_wsj
PARTOFF: "Thousands of Turks gathered in some 40 cities and towns around the country on Sunday, to join marches organized on Facebook against state Internet censorship.", http://blogs.wsj.com/emergingeurope/2011/05/15/yes-we-ban-turks-protest-internet-censorship/?mod=wsj_qt_latest_wsj
OUTDESC: "Turkey is backtracking on a plan to toughen Internet censorship.", https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2011/08/week-internet-censorship-good-news-turkey-bad-news
NARR: Anti-Censorship Protest in Turkey is a information and expression campaign aimed at ending Turkey's internet censorship, with the initiators, Turkish citizens, based in Turkey and the target, the Information and Communication Technologies Authority, based in Turkey. Digital activity consisted of organizing via Facebook. Offline activity consisted of "thousands" of protestors in Istanbul and in other cities. The structure of the campaign appears to be a grassroots upwelling of individual citizens. As of June 24, 2013, the campaign was partially successful, as the government agreed not to institute new, more stringent rules but kept the old restrictions in place. JL

TITLE: Free Vincent Nzaramb
GOALDESC: "author of a book who was imprisoned for five days without access to his lawyers or family." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/22/uganda-anti-museveni-author-freed-after-five-days/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "netizens" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/09/22/uganda-anti-museveni-author-freed-after-five-days/

NARR: Free Vincent Nzaramb is an Information and expression campaign aiming to free an Academic an Author of a Book calling for a revolution in Uganda. The initiator are individuals from Uganda, the target is the Ugandan Government. Online activity consisted on a Facebook page where most of the exchanges took place. Also, the book become popular for downloading it from an online platform. There was not online activity in this 5 days campaign. As of June 14, 2013 the campaign has achieved its goals and Vincent Nzaramb was released 5 days after his detention.  LS

TITLE: Stop the Keystone XL Pipeline
GOALDESC: "block the controversial Keystone XL project" - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keystone_Pipeline#Protests_and_postponements
INITDESC: INDIV "McKibben and other activists moved toward a new oppositional approach" - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keystone_Pipeline#Protests_and_postponements
TARGDESC: "try to convince Barack Obama to block the controversial Keystone XL project." - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keystone_Pipeline#Protests_and_postponements
PARTOFF: "1000 nonviolent arrests at the White House.", "several thousand environmentalist supporters, some shouldering a long black inflatable replica of a pipeline, formed a human chain around the White House", "approximately 35,000 to 50,000 protestors attended a rally in Washington, D.C. " - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keystone_Pipeline#Protests_and_postponements
OUTDESC: "TransCanada Corp. says the long-delayed Keystone XL pipeline will be in service months later than expected and cost more than its current $5.3 billion price-tag as it continues to await U.S. government approval." - http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/04/26/keystone-pipeline/2116179/
NARR: This is an environmental campaign aiming to stop the U.S. Keystone pipeline, initiated by U.S. individuals. There was no digital activity. Offline activity consisted of protests, primarily in Washington, D.C. The structure of the campaign can best be described as grassroots, large and tightly organized. As of 14 July 2013, the campaign is unsuccessful because TransCanada is still planning on opening the pipeline, though it's been delayed. RM

TITLE: Protect Veterans' Benefits from Budget Cuts
GOALDESC: "[for protecting] veterans’ compensation and benefits from being targeted for cuts in the ongoing debt crisis negotiations" - http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2011-07-25/local/35267614_1_disabled-veterans-veterans-benefits-veterans-groups
INITDESC: FORMAL "Disabled American Veterans" - http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2011-07-25/local/35267614_1_disabled-veterans-veterans-benefits-veterans-groups
OUTDESC: No information about action taken to address demands - http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2011-07-25/local/35267614_1_disabled-veterans-veterans-benefits-veterans-groups
NARR: Protect Veterans' Benefits from Budget Cuts is an economic-justice campaign aimed at maintaining veterans' compensation, with the initiator, Disable American Veterans, based in the US and the targets, the White House and Congress, also based in the US. Digital activity consisted of 176 thousand Facebook likes, 375 tweets, and emails sent by "thousands" of online protestors to the White House and Congress. There was no indication of offline activity. The structure of the campaign is a coalition of veterans-advocacy organizations led by one prominent formal organization. As of June 19, 2013, there is no indication that the campaign succeeded or failed. JL

TITLE: Against Cell Phone Censorship by Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART)
GOALDESC: "Protesters threatened that more would follow “until BART decides to back away from their policy of cellphone censorship,”" - http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/21/us/21bcbart.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0
INITDESC: "activists" - http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/21/us/21bcbart.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0
SITE: Anonymous announced on a Web site where the information was posted that it had attacked BART - http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/21/us/21bcbart.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&
HACK: "BART’s technology personnel have been working round the clock to fend off a disparate group of hackers who penetrated the agency’s Web sites last week and released sensitive information, in retaliation for the shutdown of the cellphone and wireless services." - http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/21/us/21bcbart.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0
PARTOFF: "The protests, while still small, appear to have grown in number and potency." - http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/21/us/21bcbart.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0
OUTDESC: "In December 2011 BART adopted a new "Cell Service Interruption Policy" that only allows shutdowns of cell phone services within BART facilities "in the most extraordinary circumstances that threaten the safety of District passengers, employees and other members of public, the destruction of District property, or the substantial disruption of public transit service."[78] According to a spokesperson for BART, under the new policy the wireless phone system would not be turned off under circumstances similar to those in August 2011. Instead police officers would arrest individuals who break the law" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_the_United_States#Bay_Area_Rapid_Transit_.28BART.29_cell_phone_service_suspension
NARR: Against Cell Phone Censorship by Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) is a freedom of expression campaign initiated by Anonymous targeting San Francisco's BART. Digital activity consisted of hacking of BART servers and publishing private information that was located. A twitter account shared news and a hashtag promoted the campaign. Offline activity consisted of occupations of at least 4 BART stations, forcing the closure of those stations during rush hour on at least one day. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a group of hackers associated with Anonymous starting a campaign that focused on hacking but also included offline elements.   As of July 1, 2013 the campaign is a partial success.  BART upheld its right to cut cell phone service, but limited that right to a narrow set of circumstances. MJ

TITLE: Tell Sallie Mae: Stop the Unemployment Penalty
GOALDESC: “Tell Sallie Mae: Stop the Unemployment Penalty” with Change.org., a group based in San Francisco. ", http://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/03/education/sallie-mae-to-change-forbearance-fee-policy.html?_r=2&nl=todaysheadlines&emc=tha23&
INITDESC: INDIV, "Stef Gray, 23, a New Yorker who owes $600 a month on four loans, saw it as a predatory effort to squeeze blood from a generation of turnips — graduates already buried under a mountain of student debt. In November, she started a petition, “Tell Sallie Mae: Stop the Unemployment Penalty” with Change.org., a group based in San Francisco. ", http://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/03/education/sallie-mae-to-change-forbearance-fee-policy.html?_r=2&nl=todaysheadlines&emc=tha23&
TARGDESC: "Sallie Mae, the nation’s largest private student-loan provider", http://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/03/education/sallie-mae-to-change-forbearance-fee-policy.html?_r=2&nl=todaysheadlines&emc=tha23&
OUTDESC: "On Thursday, Sallie Mae, the nation’s largest private student-loan provider, changed its fee policy in response to an online petition.", http://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/03/education/sallie-mae-to-change-forbearance-fee-policy.html?_r=2&nl=todaysheadlines&emc=tha23&
NARR: Tell Sallie Mae: Stop the Unemployment Penalty is an economic justice campaign aiming to protest fees with the initiator(s), individuals, based in the USA and the target(s), a business based in the USA. Digital activity consisted of an e-petition. Offline activity consisted of a press event. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a small, centralized campaign. As of June 17, 2013 the campaign is over, with partial success as new rules make interest harder to charge. KS

As of June 18, 2013 the campaign is over, without success, as Nickelback performed.  KS

GOALDESC: "The AFL-CIO launched a Tweet-a-Thon Wednesday in efforts to get unemployment compensation insurance extended during bad economic times. INITDESC: FORMAL, "The AFL-CIO launched a Tweet-a-Thon Wednesday in efforts to get unemployment compensation insurance extended during bad economic times. ", http://crooksandliars.com/kenneth-quinnell/afl-cio-launches-tweet-thon-calli

OUTDESC: "H.R. 3765 (112th): Temporary Payroll Tax Cut Continuation Act of 2011", http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/hr3765
NARR: Extend Unemployment Insurance is a economic justice campaign aiming to extending unemployment insurance with the initiator(s), AFL-CIO, based in USA and the target(s), Congress and Rep Dave Camp based in USA. Digital activity consisted of Tweets, blog posts, and an EPET. No offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as professional organized by a formal organization. As of June 17, 2013 the campaign is completely successful, as Dave Camp and the President both signed and approved the bill. DS

TITLE: #FreeMona Campaign
GOALDESC: To Free " Mona El Tahawy" (Arrested by the Egyptian Army), http://technosociology.org/?p=566

NARR: #FreeMona Campaign is a democracy and rule of law campaign aimed at freeing an Egyptian writer, with the initiator, Zeynep Tufekci, based in the US and the target, SCAF, based in Egypt. Digital activity consisted of nearly 8,000 tweets. Offline activity consisted of certain individuals contacting personal contacts in the US government. The structure of the campaign is a grassroots effort led by a well-connected scholar. As of June 24, 2013, the campaign was completely successful, since the writer was released by the Egyptian military. JL

TITLE: No to Qwikster

BLOG: blog posts mentioned, no link given

NARR: No to Qwikster is an entertainment and fandom campaign aiming to get Netflix to cancel plans for a separate Qwikster service, initiated by U.S. Netflix users. Digital activity consisted of social media, blogs, and subscription cancellations. There was no offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as fan-based and fast-moving. As of 3 July 2013, the campaign is successful, because Netflix canceled the Qwikster plans. RM

The structure of the campaign is an ad-hoc coalition of lawyers, organizations, and celebrities. TITLE: Arab Spring: Yemen

TITLE: Reuters: FIre Mohammad Sudam
GOALDESC: "(Activists ask the removal of the reporter) Over the past week Yemeni activists have been enraged after discovering that Reuters reporter Mohammad Sudam, has also been President Ali Abdullah Saleh's personal translator and his secretary since 2009. This clearly raised many issues, besides the integrity of Reuters, the conflict of interest of the reporter and the questionable objectivity of his reporting.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/18/yemen-reuters-yields-to-the-power-of-twitter/
INITDESC: "ver the past week Yemeni activists have been enraged after discovering that Reuters reporter Mohammad Sudam", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/18/yemen-reuters-yields-to-the-power-of-twitter/
OUTDESC: "Statement from Reuters regarding Mohamed Sudam: Sudam’s work as a Reuters stringer over the course of many years has been fair and accurate. When he became a translator for the president, he disclosed his role to Reuters. On reviewing the matter, however, we believe it’s not appropriate to use a stringer who is also working for the government. He is no longer reporting for us from Yemen", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/18/yemen-reuters-yields-to-the-power-of-twitter/
NARR: Reuters: FIre Mohammad Sudam is a Information and expresion campaign aiming to have a biased reporter removed from Yemen reporting for Reuters, as well as an apology, with the initiator(s), Yemeni individuals and the target(s), Reuters based in GBR. Digital activity consisted of Tweets, blogs, and YouTube usage. No offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose group of individuals from Yemen protesting online through differenr formats. As of June 17, 2013 the campaign is completely successful since Reuters apologized and removed the man from his post reporting in Yemen. DS

PARTOFF: "picketing" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/21/chile-citizens-fight-to-save-valparaisos-emblematic-elevators/
OUTDESC: Source1 indicated that "Now, only five are still cranking" in 2011, while "as of 2013 8 are still in active use." indicating that at least some repairs occurred. - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Funicular_railways_of_Valpara%C3%ADso, http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/11/21/chile-citizens-fight-to-save-valparaisos-emblematic-elevators/
NARR: Against Purchase of Luxury Vehicles for Zim Ministers is a democracy and rule of law campaign aimed at stopping the Zimbabwe government from buying luxury vehicles, with the initiator, Convention of People's Charter, based in Zimbabwe and the target, the Zimbabwean government, based in Zimbabwe. Digital activity consisted of an online petition. There was no indication of offline activity. The structure of the campaign is "a loose coalition of civil society groups." As of June 19, 2013, the campaign has achieved partial success, since a parliamentary committee investigated the purchases but the Zimbabwean government continues to purchase luxury vehicles. JL

TITLE: Stop Gina's Mining Media
GOALDESC: "wants to foil Ms Rinehart's investment in Fairfax Media." - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/1700-Australian-Financial-Review.docx
INITDESC: FORMAL "International activist group Avaaz" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/1700-Australian-Financial-Review.docx
OUTDESC: "In the 2010s, Rinehart bought a stake in media organisations, becoming the largest shareholder in Fairfax Media and taking a significant share in the Ten Network Holdings." Ð http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gina_Rinehart
NARR: Stop Gina's Mining Media is an Information and expression campaign aiming to o foil Ms Rinehart's investment in Fairfax Media (to avoid concentration of ownership of media). With the initiator(s), Avaaz and informal advocacy organization internationally based which target Australia for this campaign.  Online participation consisted in emails and tweets directed to Ms.Rinehart and communication minister. Offline activity consisted of telephone calls directed the same target. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an international advocacy network targeting a single country for a case specific.  As June 3, 2013 there is no information related to the outcome. LS

TITLE: Against Sale of Shark's Fin at FairPrice
GOALDESC: "No shark's fin products at FairPrice" - http://www.eco-business.com/news/no-sharks-fin-products-at-fairprice-by-end-march/
INITDESC: INDIV "many raising their concerns on the wall of FairPrice’s Facebook page" - http://www.eco-business.com/news/no-sharks-fin-products-at-fairprice-by-end-march/
SOCNET: "after an incident in November last year when an employee of Thern Da Seafood, a supplier of sharkÕs fin products to FairPrice, made disparaging remarks about divers who were against shark finning on his Facebook page. This sparked an online protest, with many raising their concerns on the wall of FairPriceÕs Facebook page.", http://www.eco-business.com/news/no-sharks-fin-products-at-fairprice-by-end-march/
OUTDESC: "FairPrice will no longer be extending new commitments for sharkÕs fin products but will honour current commitments to its suppliers", http://www.eco-business.com/news/no-sharks-fin-products-at-fairprice-by-end-march/
NARR: Against Sale of Shark's Fin at FairPrice is an environmental campaign aiming to stop the sale of shark fins with the initiator(s), Facebook users and the target(s), FairPrice based in Singapore. Digital activity consisted of commenting on FairPrice's Facebook page. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an unorganized group of individual Facebook users. As of May 17, 2013 the campaign has been fully successful. FE

TITLE: Global March for Syria
GOALDESC: "[against] the Assad regime" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/02/world-global-march-against-the-syrian-dictator/
INITDESC: INDIV "Activists" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/02/world-global-march-against-the-syrian-dictator/
PARTOFF: no textual numbers for "global march for Syria"
OUTDESC: "The Syrian civil war, also called the Syrian uprising,[50] is an ongoing armed conflict in Syria between forces loyal to the Syrian Ba'ath Party government and those seeking to oust it" Ð http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syrian_civil_war
NARR: March for Syria is a democracy and human rights campaign aiming to end the oppression and violence of the Assad regime in Syria.  The campaign is initiated by an online organization called Like for Syria which gives very little information about itself. Digital activity consisted of promoting the event through Facebook and a YouTube video. Offline activity consisted of marches in at least 15 cities (Toronto, Washington DC, Ottawa, Calgary, Montreal, Chicago, London, Geneva, Seine, Paris, Bergen, Zürich, Munich, San Francisco, and an unnamed city in New Zealand). The structure of the campaign can best be described as an informal organization called Like for Syria attempting to mobilize offline action using primary Facebook. As of April 11, 2013 that particular campaign is complete, though it does not appear to have any effect on the Syrian conflict. MJ

TITLE: Oikos Yoghurt: Don't Rip off John Butler Song
GOALDESC: "Fans flooded the John Butler Trio Facebook  page after the American football match with complaints about the striking similarity between the music on the Oikos Greek yoghurt commercial starring actor John Stamos." - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/1761-The-Daily-Telegraph-.docx
INITDESC: INDIV Fans of the musician
SOCNET: "Fans flooded the John Butler Trio Facebook  page" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/1761-The-Daily-Telegraph-.docx
OUTDESC: "manager Phil Stevens posted a message to his Facebook  fans confirming they were seeking advice from copyright experts. Dannon acknowledged the controversy after fans also expressed their outrage and made a qualified apology. "We apologise for concerns this has caused John Butler Trio's members and fans,'' -  http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/1761-The-Daily-Telegraph-.docx
NARR: Oikos Yoghurt: Don't Rip off John Butler Song is an intellectual property rights campaign aiming to get financial restitution for a company using a piece of music similar to that of John Butler in a yoghurt advertisement without consent.  The initiators are Butler's fans. Dannon is based in France, but the location of the fans is unclear. Digital activity consisted of "flooding Butler's Facebook" page asking him to take legal action. Offline activity consisted of legal action taken by Butler. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an informal group of fans alerting an artist to an injustice and urging him to self-advocate offline. As of May 7, 2013 the campaign is a success. A settlement was reached and all parties are satisfied. MJ

TITLE: Argentines Mobilize Around Multiple Demands
GOALDESC: "to protest the recent [currency reform] policies enacted by the government of Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner" "for “Justice, Liberty, Security, Inflation, [a] Locked Exchanged Market”" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/14/argentina-protesters-say-enough-to-governments-policies/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "The Facebook page “Yo no voté a la Kretina y Ud?” [es] (I did not vote the Cretin and you?) spread the announcement " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/14/argentina-protesters-say-enough-to-governments-policies/, https://www.facebook.com/YONOLAVOTE/info
TARGDESC: "the government of Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner" -http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/14/argentina-protesters-say-enough-to-governments-policies/
PARTOFF: Photos show ~ 20000 protesters "On September 13, 2012, several marches and cacerolazos (pots and pans protest) were held in different cities across Argentina to protest the recent policies enacted by the government of Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/14/argentina-protesters-say-enough-to-governments-policies/
OUTDESC: Protests against Kirchner continue - http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-22211591
NARR: Argentines Mobilize Around Multiple Demands is an economic justice campaign aiming to protest recent policies with the initiator(s), informal organizations, based in Argentina and the target(s), the government based in Argentina. Digital activity consisted ofTwitter, Facebook and videos. Offline activity consisted of large protest marches. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an informal movement. As of May 13, 2013 the campaign is over, outcome information not available. KS

TITLE: Opposition to "Monsanto Law" on Biotech Intellectual Property
GOALDESC: "The Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries [es] of Argentina is working on a new law to protect the intellectual property rights of companies that produce transgenic seeds. This bill, dubbed by small producers as ‘Seed Law’ or ‘Monsanto Law', is being strongly criticized by various sectors who consider that Argentina could lose its food sovereignty if the law moves forward." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/06/argentina-and-transgenic-seeds-monsanto-law-sparks-controversy/
INITDESC: INDIV Individuals mentioned, initiators unclear
PARTOFF: about 100 people attended a "mega event spread through Plaza San Mart’n in order to condemn the criminal actions of the company, the use of pesticides, and reject the amendments to the seed law proposed by the national government, already known as the ÔMonsanto LawÕ" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/06/argentina-and-transgenic-seeds-monsanto-law-sparks-controversy/
OUTDESC: "opposition to the bill from sectors within the center-left government and among some farm groups has prevented it from reaching Congress this year and raised doubts about its chances of ever becoming law." - http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/12/21/grains-argentina-seeds-idUSL1E8NK9O020121221
NARR: Opposition to "Monsanto Law" on Biotech Intellectual Property is an intellectual property campaign aiming to stop a law that would make farmers pay royalties to Monsanto with the initiator(s), an informal organization, based in Argentina and the target(s), a government agency based in Argentina. Digital activity consisted of Facebook and video. Offline activity consisted of events. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose campaign by a variety of actors. As of May 20, 2013 the campaign appears to be ongoing, without success as the law will probably be brought forward again. KS

TITLE: #OccupyMashtotsPark to Protect Green Space
GOALDESC: "[against] the erection of shops in Mashtots Park, one of the city's last remaining green spaces" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/22/armenia-activists-occupy-yerevan-park/
INITDESC: INDIV "a small yet dedicated group of environmental activists" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/22/armenia-activists-occupy-yerevan-park/
SOCNET: "Some of the activism was initiated by the Ô????? ??? ??? ?????? ????Õ (We are the owners of this city) Facebook group "  http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/22/armenia-activists-occupy-yerevan-park/, https://www.facebook.com/#!/pages/Kassouny/156492924442939, https://www.facebook.com/events/178585568919184/
BLOG: "The hashtag ‘#OccupyMashtotsPark‘ was also spread on Twitter before Monday night's action and used by Armenian news outlets and individual journalists as well as bloggers" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/22/armenia-activists-occupy-yerevan-park/
PARTOFF: "100 of the environmental activists broke through a police cordon to demand a reversal of the decision to build in a public park. The activists stayed until sundown in almost freezing temperatures" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/22/armenia-activists-occupy-yerevan-park/
OUTDESC: "On familiarizing himself with the situation, Head of the republic gave an indication to Mayor of Yerevan to dismantle the stalls immediately." - http://eng.kavkaz-uzel.ru/articles/20908/
NARR: #OccupyMashtotsPark to Protect Green Space is an environmental campaign aiming to protect an  park in the Armenian capital from commercial development.  The initiators are a loose group of environmental activists and the target is the municipal government. Digital activity consisted of videos and livestreaming, Twitter news reports, and coordination via a Facebook group. Offline activity consisted of occupation of the park. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose group of committed individual activists coordinating via social media. As of April 6, 2013 the campaign was a success.  The president himself ordered the commercial development be removed.  MJ

TITLE: Stop Education Cuts in New South Wales
GOALDESC: "against the state government's education cuts." - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1724-Wentworth-Courier.docx
INITDESC: "STUDENTS from Sydney Girls High School" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1724-Wentworth-Courier.docx
SOCNET:
"post it to their Facebook page to convey their message to the Liberals.
In just over one week, the page has attracted more than 600 followers" -
PARTOFF: "teachers are planning mass walkouts in October" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1724-Wentworth-Courier.docx
OUTDESC: "The NSW Government announced it would slash $1.7 billion funding to Catholic, private, independent and public schools in September last year. Now four months later there are still no details of the new funding model with schools unable to plan ahead, predict future operating costs or assess the full impact of the cuts. "The reduction in funding is expected to take effect from mid 2013" - http://www.sydneycatholic.org/news/latest_news/2013/2013131_724.shtml
NARR: Stop Education Cuts in New South Wales is an education campaign aiming to protest proposed budget cuts with the initiator(s), an informal organization of students, based in Australia and the target(s), the government based in Australia. Digital activity consisted of Facebook. Offline activity consisted of a proposed walk-out. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose effort by students. As of May 21, 2013 that campaign is over, having not achieved any success. KS

TITLE: Demanding Concessions for International Students in Victoria
GOALDESC: ''Concession [public transport ] tickets for international students, please!'' - http://www.theage.com.au/technology/technology-news/chinese-students-in-baillieu-blog-stoush-20120411-1ws6s.html#ixzz2aZX26WAH
INITDESC: INDIV "Hundreds of international students" - http://www.theage.com.au/technology/technology-news/chinese-students-in-baillieu-blog-stoush-20120411-1ws6s.html
MICBLOG: "Mr Baillieu opened an account on the popular social networking site Weibo last month" Ð Read more: http://www.theage.com.au/technology/technology-news/chinese-students-in-baillieu-blog-stoush-20120411-1ws6s.html#ixzz2a0MnDk00
OUTDESC: "WITH Victoria being the only state to withhold public transport concessions to international students ..." Ð http://www.meldmagazine.com.au/2013/04/public-transport-concessions-international-students-victoria/
NARR: Demanding Concessions for International Students in Victoria is an economic justice campaign asking the head of the Australian state of Victoria to grant reduced fares for international students using public transportation. It seems to have been initiated by individual students who are themselves internationals studying in Australia.  Digital activity consisted of bombarding the official's Chinese weibo account with messages demanding the change. There does not appear to have been any offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a short-lived "flash-mob" style action in which a group of individuals took concerted action for a short time without previous coordination. As of may 9, 2013 the campaign is has failed.  The students did not receive the concessions they requested. MJ

TITLE: Demanding Justice for Slain Journalists Sagar Sarwar and Meherun Runi
GOALDESC: "justice for the murdered couple", "the immediate arrest of the murderers of Sagar and Runi" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/16/bangladesh-bloggers-march-for-murdered-journalist-couple-demand-justice/
INITDESC: INDIV "Bloggers have once again taken to the street", "nothing could stop the bloggers, journalists, students and ordinary citizens from showing solidarity and participating in singing the protest songs" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/16/bangladesh-bloggers-march-for-murdered-journalist-couple-demand-justice/
TARGDESC: "March to the Parliament and submit a memorandum to the Speaker of the House, demanding arrest and trial of the killers of Sagar-Runi" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/16/bangladesh-bloggers-march-for-murdered-journalist-couple-demand-justice/
PARTOFF: "On 11 May, they organized a protest in front of the public library in Shahbagh, Dhaka" (maybe a dozen here). Other image shows maybe 30 people protesting
OUTDESC: "A Dhaka court on Sunday permitted police to send to the United States for test the DNA samples of three more suspects in sensational murder of the journalist couple" - http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/01/13/more-dna-test-in-sagar-runi-murder
NARR: Demanding Justice for Slain Journalists Sagar Sarwar and Meherun Runi is a justice and rule of law campaign aiming to encourage government to solve two murders with the initiator(s), individuals and an informal group, based in Bangladesh and the target(s), the government based in Bangladesh. Digital activity consisted of video and social networking sites. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a tight campaign with multiple events. As of May 6, 2013 the campaign is possibly ongoing. KS

TITLE: Demanding Freedom and Proper Care for Abdulhadi AlKhawaja
GOALDESC: "to demand the release of all those arrested, brutalized, and sentenced to jail for their support and participation in the pro-democracy movement." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/27/bahrain-hungry4bh-trends-worldwide/
INITDESC: INDIV "Khawaja, and several other detainees" "Bahrainis"  FORMAL "Front Line Defenders" - http://www.frontlinedefenders.org/contactus, http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/27/bahrain-hungry4bh-trends-worldwide/
PARTOFF: "over 130 Human Rights Defenders from more than 80 countries protested at the Saudi Embassy in Dublin" Ð http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/27/bahrain-hungry4bh-trends-worldwide/; hunger strike, no numbers listed.
OUTDESC: "He is currently in prison in Bahrain" Ð http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abdulhadi_al-Khawaja
NARR: Demanding Freedom and Proper Care for Abdulhadi AlKhawaja is a human rights campaign by individuals in Bahrain and at least one formal organization overseas to demand that Bahrain and Saudi authorities act to free Bahraini democracy activist Abdulhadi AlKhawaja. Digital activity consisted of a successful trending hashtag related to an offline action, #Hungry4BH. Offline activity consisted of the hunger strike and small protests in Bahrain and Ireland. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose network of individuals, mostly in Bahrain, and international individual allies and at least one formal rights NGO. As of April 11, 2013 the campaign is ongoing and Abdulhadi AlKhawaja is still imprisoned. MJ

TITLE: Against Formula One in Bahrain
GOALDESC: "called for a cancellation of the 2012 Bahrain Grand Prix"
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Human rights activists called for a cancellation", "Anonymous launched on 21 April 2012 the operation opBahrain, threatening the Formula 1 representatives of a cyberattack" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahrain_Grand_Prix#2012_controversy
TARGDESC: "want the sport's governing body to cancel", "threatening the Formula 1 representatives" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahrain_Grand_Prix#2012_controversy
HACK: "threatening the Formula 1 representatives of a cyberattack in case they go on with Bahrain Grand Prix. Hours later, Anonymous hackers took down the f1-racers.net website after launching a distributed denial-of-service attack on it." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahrain_Grand_Prix#2012_controversy
OUTDESC: "the 2012 Bahrain Grand Prix, which took place on 22 April" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahrain_Grand_Prix#2012_controversy
NARR: Against Formula One in Bahrain is a pro-democracy campaign aiming to have Formula One cancel a race in Bahrain to bring awareness to the regime with the initiator(s), Bahraini Twitter users, based in Bahrain and the target(s), Formula One based in the United Kingdom. Digital activity consisted of Twitter use. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a crowd-led online campaign of individuals without organizations. As of April 10, 2013, the campaign is ended, having mobilized users and gotten a response from Formula One but without success.  KS

TITLE: Stop Luka
GOALDESC:
"We – the movement “STOP LUKA”.
We stand for the unconditional withdrawal of the power of Lukashenka and his henchmen, lustration gosudartvennyh officials, security forces, all the administrative resources. The dictator will answer for their crimes." -
INITDESC: INDIV http://www.stopluka.org/en/category/our-moderators-en/
OUTDESC: Lukashenko retained office - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belarusian_parliamentary_election,_2012#Results
NARR: Stop Luka is a pro-democracy campaign aiming to challenge the president Alexander Lukashenko with the initiator(s), Stop Luka, based in Belarus. Digital activity consisted of social media, twitter, and blogging. Offline activity consisted of promoting an election boycott and refusing to vote in the 2012 elections in Belarus. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a crowd of supporters organized through social media by an informal organization. As of May 8, 2013 the campaign is over, with Lukashenko retaining the presidency - though it appears that some did refuse to vote, and turnout was estimated at ~30%, relatively low. FE

TITLE: More and Better Internet for Bolivia
GOALDESC: "the goal is that by 2014, all Bolivian households have access to 1 mbps (as minimum speed) [Internet connection] at a cost less than 20 US dollars" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/04/10/bolivia-activists-push-for-better-internet-connectivity/

PARTOFF: "the first National Meeting to Promote Connectivity in Bolivia [es] took place in late January 2012. .... blogger Mario R. Dur‡n from Palabras Libres [es]... met [es] with Bolivia's upper Chamber President, Ms. Gabriela Monta–o." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/04/10/bolivia-activists-push-for-better-internet-connectivity/
OUTDESC: "only 30 percent of the Bolivian population has access to the Internet, mostly at a connection speed less than 0.256 megabits per second (mbps) or indirectly from their work or at Internet cafes (cabins). For a connection speed of 1 mbps, the average Bolivian would have to spend about $60 USD per month" - https://blog.wikimedia.org/2013/06/27/wikimedia-foundation-values-bolivian-experience/
NARR: More and Better Internet for Bolivia is a technology and expression campaign aiming to provide affordable fast internet access with the initiator(s), Bolivian citizens, based in Bolivia and the target(s), the Bolivian government based in Bolivia. Digital activity consisted of Facebook, microblogs and blogs. Offline activity was not mentioned. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an informal online campaign. As of April 19, 2013 the campaign is ongoing. KS

TITLE: World Resists with Guarani-Kaiowá
GOALDESC: "against their expulsion and the abandonment of indigenous communities by the government." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/28/worldwide-protests-for-brazils-indigenous-guarani-kaiowa/

NARR: World Resists with Guarani-Kaiowá is an indigenous rights campaign aiming to protest the removal of an indigenous nation from their land with the initiator(s), the nation, based in Brazil and the target(s), the government based in Brazil. Digital activity consisted of Facebook, videos and Twitter. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a multi-faceted campaign. As of May 15, 2013 the campaign is over, having achieved success. KS

TITLE: Calling for Peace in Alagoas

NARR: Calling for Peace in Alagoas is a anti-armed conflict campaign aiming to protest senseless murders with the initiator(s), Brazilian citizens, based in Brazil and the target(s), the PubliC Ministry based in Brazil. TITLE: Against the Impunity of Past Dictators
GOALDESC: "“The main theme [of the blogs] was outrage against the torture, disappearances and impunity,”" - Protests against celebration and commemoration of torturous coup. - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/04/26/brazil-military-dictatorship-desarquivandobr/

OUTDESC: "anger at police tactics has grown as law enforcement struggle to contain a wave of protests that have been raging since last month." Ð http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/04/26/brazil-military-dictatorship-desarquivandobr/
NARR: Against the Impunity of Past Dictators is a protest campaign aiming to bring attention to the former military regime with the initiator(s), citizens, based in Brazil and the target(s), former members of the military regime based in Brazil. Digital activity consisted of video, citizen journalism, images, and blogs. Offline activity consisted of protests in Brazil. The structure of the campaign can best be described as loose and run by individuals. As of April 19, 2013 the campaign is over without success.  KS

TITLE: Protect Residents of Quilombo do Rio dos Macacos
GOALDESC: Protesting the naval occupation of "Quilombo Rio de Macacos in Bahia, one of the oldest communities of descendents of slaves in Brazil, woke up enclosed by military police threatening their eviction on Sunday morning, March 4, 2012."- http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/09/brazil-navy-quilombo-eviction/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "The Ondina settlement of the Occupy Salvador movement"
MAP: "A map showing how to get to the community was shared" http://pt.globalvoicesonline.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/quilombo-mapa.jpg - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/09/brazil-navy-quilombo-eviction/
OUTDESC: "06/03/13...About 400 protesters from organizations and social movements occupied on the morning of Wednesday (06) the headquarters of the Attorney General (AGU) in Salvador (BA). The lawsuit seeks the immediate suspension of the legal proceedings initiated by the Navy of Brazil, which wants to expel the maroon community of Rio Monkeys territory located in the municipality of Bahia Sim›es Filho.", 06/03/13http://www.brasildefato.com.br/node/12204
NARR: Occupation to Protect Residents of Quilombo do Rio dos Macacos is a land rights campaign connected to an ethnic minority of descendants of slaves.  It aims to legally and perpetually protect their right to their land against the Navy's attempts to remove them. Though started by Brazil-based Occupy Salvador, the rights of the residents was also supported by the international e-campaigning organization Avaaz, based in the US. Digital activity consisted of online coordination of the protest, two petitions, and use of Twitter. Offline activity consisted of the occupation. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an informal group of committed activists (Occupy Salvador) taking action and being later supported through an online action by a profession international advocacy organization. As of June 2, 2013 the campaign is ongoing but has not achieved success . MJ

TITLE: Sanitation is Basic
GOALDESC: "Meu Rio has launched an online petition accompanied by the video “Eu quero 100% de #saneamentoparaorio” (I want 100% sanitation for Rio), which presents the problems of everyday life that the people of Rio have to put up with:" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/12/brazil-sanitation-rio-de-janeiro/
INITDESC: FORMAL Meu Rio
TARGDESC: No particular targets named, but implied target is Rio de Janeiro water authority
OUTDESC: "Among the challenges is the still high number of poor Brazilians living in urban slums (favela) and in rural areas without access to piped water or sanitation; water scarcity in the Northeast of Brazil; water pollution, especially in the South-East of the country; the low share of collected wastewater that is being treated (35% in 2000)" -  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Brazil (1st 2 paragraphs)
NARR: Sanitation is Basic is a public health and environmental campaign aiming to get better sanitation services for the city of Rio in Brazil.  The initiator is an organization called Meu Rio which has features of a formal organization (staff, a board) and of an informal organization (no public physical address). The target is the governor of the state. Digital activity consisted of an e-petition and a campaign hashtag. There did not appear to be any offline activity.  The structure of the campaign can best be described as a semi-formal organization taking action exclusively online. As of May 4, 2013, the campaign is over but there is no information about goal achievement. MJ

TITLE: Save Cross River South Forest Reserve
GOALDESC: "[against] plans to allow a cocoa plantation of 7241.160 hectares to be planted in the Cross River South Forest Reserve and the Support Zone of the Cross River National Park" - http://www.sbwire.com/press-releases/african-ngo-turns-to-netizens-to-save-a-forest-150724.htm
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Rainforest Resource Development Centre" - http://www.sbwire.com/press-releases/african-ngo-turns-to-netizens-to-save-a-forest-150724.htm
TARGDESC: "the governor of Cross River State in Nigeria, Governor Liyel Imoke" - http://www.sbwire.com/press-releases/african-ngo-turns-to-netizens-to-save-a-forest-150724.htm
SOCNET: "online activists working under the Forest Activists United group on facebook" - http://www.sbwire.com/press-releases/african-ngo-turns-to-netizens-to-save-a-forest-150724.htm
OUTDESC: "In addition to the indigenous land rights issues, the plantation areas encroach deep into Cross River National Park, home to several endemic primate species including the endangered Preuss Red Colobus and the Drill." - http://www.palmwatchafrica.org/tag/high-forest-low-deforestation/
NARR: Save Cross River South Forest Reserve is an environmental campaign aiming to end rainforest deforestation with the initiator(s), an informal environmental group, based in Canada and the target(s), government based in Nigeria. Digital activity consisted of an e-petition. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a focused campaign by an informal organization. As of May 7, 2013 the campaign has not succeeded. KS

TITLE: Idle No More
GOALDESC: "to protest the effects of current and proposed government policies on the nation’s indigenous peoples."
INITDESC: FORMAL "First Nations " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/15/indigenous-idle-no-more-movement-sweeps-canada/
PARTOFF: "widespread rallies, protests, and roadblocks" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/15/indigenous-idle-no-more-movement-sweeps-canada/, "Attawapiskat Chief Theresa Spence began a hunger strike on Tuesday" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/15/indigenous-idle-no-more-movement-sweeps-canada/
OUTDESC: "Prime Minister Harper announced a meeting with a delegation of First Nation leaders coordinated by the Assembly of First Nations ... His statement announcing the meeting made no mention of Idle No More" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idle_No_More#January_11.2C_2013_meeting
NARR: Idle No More is an ethnic minority rights campaign aiming to protest government policies that hurt indigenous nations with the initiator(s), indigenous nations and supports, based in Canada and the target(s), the government based in Canada. Digital activity consisted of Facebook, Twitter, blogs. Offline activity consisted of mobilizations. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formalized campaign with a tight coalition of actors. As of May 15, 2013 the campaign is ongoing, having achieved partial succes because the Prime minister agreed to talk to First Nation representatives. KS

TITLE: Save the Bowmanville Train Whistle
GOALDESC: "keep the train whistles in [Bowmanville] for safety and to save our tax dollars" - http://www.durhamregion.com/news-story/3501527-residents-connect-to-save-the-bowmanville-train-whistle/
INITDESC: INDIV "Christian Forsey" - http://www.durhamregion.com/news-story/3501527-residents-connect-to-save-the-bowmanville-train-whistle/
EPET: 'keep the train whistles in our municipality for safety and to save our tax dollars so they can be used to better serve the community we live in'., http://www.durhamregion.com/news/article/1285572
SOCNET: "a Facebook page to 'Save the Bowmanville Train Whistle'" - http://www.durhamregion.com/news-story/3501527-residents-connect-to-save-the-bowmanville-train-whistle/
OUTDESC: "Council has denied the request to ban the whistles." - https://www.facebook.com/groups/199431710152688/permalink/248829525212906/
NARR: Save the Bowmanville Train Whistle is an Environmental campaign aiming to keep the train whistle in the community. The initiator is a group of individuals who started the campaign after another group of individuals presented a petition to the  Clarington Council (Canada) in order to ban the Train Whistle. Digital activity consisted of Facebook group page and an online petition.  There is no information about the offline participation of the “save the train whistle” (but the other group presented  800 signatures supporting the ban).The structure of the campaign can best be described as communitarian and informal.  As of June 3, 2013. The campaign did not achieve their goals because the Council decided to consider a whistle ban and asked staff to look at the urban areas of Clarington and bring back a report on the potential cost and feasibility.  LS

TITLE: Aysen Social Movement
GOALDESC: "for subsidies to balance food, water, electricity and fuel costs; quality health and education; employment equity and retirement pensions based on regional needs; greater citizen participation in the decisions that affect the region including natural resources exploitation; better access and infrastructure." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/18/chile-aysen-region-social-movement-gains-strength/
INITDESC: FORMAL, INDIV, possible INFORMAL "Social Movement for Aysen Region, which is made up by 25 social organizations, unions and farmers"
TARGDESC: "Economy Minister, Pablo Longueira," "Interior Minister Rodrigo Hinzpeter"
PARTOFF: "locals held a series of protests calling for better quality of life and lower living costs" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/18/chile-aysen-region-social-movement-gains-strength/, "protesters of the Social Movement for Aysen Region ... have blocked roads, occupying airfields [es] and docks, burning tires and setting up barricades in Coyhaique and other towns in the region" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/18/chile-aysen-region-social-movement-gains-strength/
OUTDESC: "The government has signed an agreement with the AysŽn Social Movement (MSPRA) after several meetings in Santiago which addressed the movementÕs demands" - http://www.santiagotimes.cl/chile/politics/23605-aysen-social-movement-leaders-sign-agreement-with-government
NARR: Aysen Social Movement is a human rights campaign aiming to gain better quality of life with the initiator(s), a coalition of formal and informal organization, based in Chile and the target(s), the Chilean government based in Chile. Digital activity consisted of Twitter use. Offline activity consisted of road blockages and rallies. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a coalition. As of May 1, 2013 the campaign is over, with the government having met demands. KS.

TITLE: Books Without Tax
GOALDESC: "‘Libros Sin IVA’ [es] is a citizen campaign which seeks to eliminate the 19% value added taxon books in Chile" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/11/chile-citizen-campaign-seeks-to-eliminate-tax-on-books/
INITDESC: INDIV "celebrities, writers and other supporters of this campaign" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/11/chile-citizen-campaign-seeks-to-eliminate-tax-on-books/
TARGDESC: "[Chilean] Congress and eventually to President Sebastián Piñera's administration" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/11/chile-citizen-campaign-seeks-to-eliminate-tax-on-books/
OUTDESC: No change in tax rate: "Standing at 19 percent in addition to regular sales tax, Chilean taxes on books are the highest in the world. " - http://www.santiagotimes.cl/culture/events/26485-chilean-coastal-city-celebrates-used-books
NARR: Books Without Tax is a tax reform campaign aiming to eliminate excessive sales taxes on books with the initiator(s), a small group of friends, based in Chile and the target(s), the Chilean Government. Digital activity consisted of blogging, an e-petition, videos, facebook pages, massive twitter activity, and use of a campaign website. No offline activity was indicated. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a small group of friends launched the campaign, which was then picked up and furthered by thousands of supporters, a loose organizational structure. As of April 22, 2013 the campaign is ongoing, but has failed to achieve a change in the tax rate.  FE

TITLE: Against Planning Petrochemical Plant in Ningbo
GOALDESC: "Following several days of mass protests against two proposed petrochemical projects amid environmental and health concerns, officials in the coastal city of Ningbo announced late Sunday that the projects would be halted. The government’s announcement failed to deter protesters, however, who continued to gather outside the government offices Monday and demand that the city’s mayor step down. - http://cmp.hku.hk/2012/10/29/28267/
INITDESC: INDIV No organizational initiators described
MICBLOG: "Sina Weibo and other platforms remain the primary source of information on this story." - http://cmp.hku.hk/2012/10/29/28267/
VIDEO: "video posted to Chinese social media from the scene in Ningbo have already been deleted" - http://cmp.hku.hk/2012/10/29/28267/
PARTOFF: "several days of mass protests" Protest of a few thousand people - http://cmp.hku.hk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/Ningbo-protesters-middle-finger-outside-govt.jpg - http://cmp.hku.hk/2012/10/29/28267/
OUTDESC: "officials in the coastal city of Ningbo announced late Sunday that the projects would be halted." - http://cmp.hku.hk/2012/10/29/28267/
NARR: Against Planning Petrochemical Plant in Ningbo is a environmental campaign aiming to block construction of petrochemical plants with the initiator(s), individuals, based in China and the target(s), the local government, based in China. Digital activity consisted of microblogging. Offline activity consisted of blockades and protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as very loose. As of May 13, 2013 the campaign is over, having reached success. KS

TITLE: Nagoya Mayor: Apologize for Massacre Denial
GOALDESC: "for an immediate apology from Nagoya's mayor... following the mayor's blunt denial of a World War II massacre." - http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/xinhua/2012-02-23/content_5233033.html
INITDESC: "many Chinese netizens" - http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/xinhua/2012-02-23/content_5233033.html
MICBLOG: "posted Tuesday from his account on Sina Weibo, a popular Chinese microblogging site." - http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/xinhua/2012-02-23/content_5233033.html
OUTDESC: " The Chinese city of Nanjing has suspended its sister-city relationship with Nagoya, Japan, after NagoyaÕs mayor expressed doubts that the Japanese ArmyÕs 1937 Nanjing Massacre actually took place, the Nagoya City Hall said Wednesday." ... "On Wednesday, Mr. Kawamura remained unrepentant, saying that he did not intend to retract the statement or apologize" - http://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/23/world/asia/chinese-city-severs-ties-after-japanese-mayor-denies-massacre.html?_r=0
NARR: Nagoya Mayor: Apologize for Massacre Denial is an anti-violence campaign by Chinese netizens aiming to get the mayor of Nagoya Japan to apologize for denying the Nanjing Massacre. Digital activity consisted of discussion of the event on weibo, including calls to action. Offline activity consisted of one teacher sending a letter.  There is no indication if boycotts suggested on weibo were actually carried out. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a crowd campaign composed of individual weibo users. As of May 8, 2013 the campaign is over.  The mayor did not apologize. [no author indicated]

TITLE: No to Holding Multiple Public Offices
GOALDESC: "to call upon Ivorian political leaders to renounce multiple offices" -http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/28/cote-divoire-online-campaign-says-no-to-multiple-public-offices/
INITDESC: INDIV "Ivorian bloggers" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/28/cote-divoire-online-campaign-says-no-to-multiple-public-offices/
EPET: "organizing a petition to call upon Ivorian political leaders to renounce multiple offices." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/28/cote-divoire-online-campaign-says-no-to-multiple-public-offices/
OUTDESC: "Current government leaders have engaged in dialogue with the netizens, notably on twitter" "Minister Lobognon, like Guillaume Soro, has given assurances that he will not seek to simultaneously take up multiple elected offices - already one small victory for this nascent citizen movement." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/28/cote-divoire-online-campaign-says-no-to-multiple-public-offices/
NARR: No to Holding Multiple Public Offices is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to prevent Ivorian politicians from holding multiple offices, initiated by Ivorian bloggers. Digital activity consisted of images shared on Facebook, a twitter hashtag, and an e-petition. There does not appear to be any offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a group of digital activists successfully mounting a number of digital tactics and engaging politicians in debate, mostly by Twitter. As of May 9, 2013, the campaign is ongoing.  A few politicians addressed the campaigners' concerns via Twitter and at least one agreed not to take multiple offices. MJ

TITLE: For Recognition of LGBT Citizens on Cuban Census
GOALDESC: for "same-sex unions [which] were originally going to be included" in the census, to be reinstated - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/12/cuba-for-a-census-in-which-all-unions-count/
INITDESC: INDIV "bloggers and activists in favor of sexual diversity", FORMAL "Center for Sexual Education (CENESEX)" - http://www.cenesexualidad.sld.cu/contacto http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/12/cuba-for-a-census-in-which-all-unions-count/
TARGDESC: "the National Office of Statistics and Information (ONEI) " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/12/cuba-for-a-census-in-which-all-unions-count/
OUTDESC: "Cuban authorities have refused to include questions about Cubans' sexual orientation or transgender status" on the Census - See more at: http://www.gaystarnews.com/article/cuba-refuses-count-lgbts-2012-census030912#sthash.15nSiH2p.dpuf
NARR: For Recognition of LGBT Citizens on Cuban Census is a gender and sexuality campaign aiming to include LGBT questions on the national census with the initiator(s), Cuban citizens, based in Cuba and the target(s), the Cuban government based in Cuba. Digital activity consisted of blogs. Offline activity consisted of flag raising. The structure of the campaign can best be described as loose and informal. As of April 22, 2013 the campaign is over, but failed to achieve recognition on the census. KS

TITLE: Free Pussy Riot
GOALDESC: "[against] the Russian punk band Pussy Riot [being] charged with hooliganism" - http://www.cnn.com/2012/08/17/world/pussy-riot-social-media
INITDESC: INDIV "Celebrity supporters" - http://www.cnn.com/2012/08/17/world/pussy-riot-social-media, INDIV "balaclava-clad campaigners" - http://www.cnn.com/2012/08/17/world/pussy-riot-social-media
PARTOFF: "balaclava-clad campaigners gathered outside Russian embassies across Europe and the U.S." - http://www.cnn.com/2012/08/17/world/pussy-riot-social-media, "In Kiev, members of the feminist activist group Femen reportedly used a chainsaw to cut down an orthodox cross" - http://www.cnn.com/2012/08/17/world/pussy-riot-social-media
OUTDESC: "All three were convicted and sentenced to two years in a penal colony on August 17, 2012. ... Tolokonnikova stated that "Our imprisonment serves as a clear and unambiguous sign that freedom is being taken away from the entire country."" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pussy_riot#Trial.2C_conviction_and_sentencing
NARR: Free Pussy Riot is a freedom of expression campaign aiming to get the Russian government to free all the members of the band Pussy Riot, jailed for criticizing President Putin in a religious space. Digital activity consisted of a number of formal and information organizations and individuals denouncing the imprisonment via websites, Facebook, and Twitter.  Both Twitter and e-petition participation was over 100,000.  There does not seem to have been much offline protest. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a semi-coordinated coalition of formal and informal European advocacy, free expression, and artists' groups taking action offline, with some actions unconnected to their coordinated effort. Massive international legacy media coverage also occurred.  As of April 18, 2013 two of the three group members arrested remain in jail. MJ

TITLE: European Anti-ACTA Campaign
GOALDESC: "reject the [Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement] treaty, and criticizing proposals to delay the vote" - http://techpresident.com/news/22311/germany-activists-help-coordinate-europe-wide-anti-acta-protests
INITDESC: FORMAL "41 advocacy organizations" - http://techpresident.com/news/22311/germany-activists-help-coordinate-europe-wide-anti-acta-protests, FORMAL "Digitale Gesellschaft" - http://techpresident.com/news/22311/germany-activists-help-coordinate-europe-wide-anti-acta-protests, FORMAL "European Digital Rights Initiative" - http://techpresident.com/news/22311/germany-activists-help-coordinate-europe-wide-anti-acta-protests, INFORMAL " In Berlin, for example, the Left Party, the Greens, Pirates and the Chaos Computer Club coordinated with Digitale Gesellschaft, while other protests have a connection to Anonymous" - http://techpresident.com/news/22311/germany-activists-help-coordinate-europe-wide-anti-acta-protests
SITE: http://acta.digitalegesellschaft.de, http://www.laquadrature.net, http://advocacy.globalvoicesonline.org/, http://act-on-acta.eu, jestemprzeciwacta.pl, EDRi.org
SOCNET: " Ahead of the June 9th protest, she wrote that activists had been regularly updating about the status of European Parliament votes on Twitter and Facebook" - http://techpresident.com/news/22311/germany-activists-help-coordinate-europe-wide-anti-acta-protests
PARTOFF: "That Saturday, according to German press reports, there were about 1,500 demonstrators in about 40 towns in Germany. Other press reports indicate several hundred in Paris and Brussels." - http://techpresident.com/news/22311/germany-activists-help-coordinate-europe-wide-anti-acta-protests, "Anonymous activists had gathered in several towns to organize so-called "Paperstorms" to distribute flyers against ACTA or organized other events" - http://techpresident.com/news/22311/germany-activists-help-coordinate-europe-wide-anti-acta-protests, "In the town of Bielefeld, a university town of about 320,000 in North Rhine-Westphalia, there were protests on both days in February with about 1,500 and 700 participants" - http://techpresident.com/news/22311/germany-activists-help-coordinate-europe-wide-anti-acta-protests
OUTDESC: "On 4 July 2012, the European Parliament rejected the agreement in plenary session" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-Counterfeiting_Trade_Agreement
NARR: European Anti-ACTA Campaign is a freedom of information campaign with a variety of initiators, including NGOs, political parties, loose networks, and individual volunteers in countries across Europe.  The target was the European Parliament, which was set to vote on the treaty in July od 2012. Online activity consisted of sharing of both policy-related and practical mobilization information via websites, mostly operated by digital rights NGOs.  Twitter, Facebook, and videos, translated into multiple languages, were also used. Protests took place in 200 cities across Europe in February, and NGOs and members of Anonymous distributed over 120,000 pieces of printed material. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose and inclusive network composed of amateurs and professionals, amateurs and loose networks.  There seems to have been little central control, but some coordination (for example, for the Feb. 11 protests).  As of March 20, 2013 the campaign was a success: "on 4 July 2012, the European Parliament rejected the agreement."  [no author indicated]

TITLE: For Better Education in Algeria
GOALDESC: "against the record longevity of the minister [of education in Algeria" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/06/19/algeria-twitter-protest-against-the-state-of-education/
INITDESC: INDIV "Algerians on Twitter" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/06/19/algeria-twitter-protest-against-the-state-of-education/
OUTDESC: "Appointed member of the Council of the Nation in 2012 after over 16 years, Minister of National Education" (translated) - http://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aboubakr_Benbouzid
NARR: For a Better Education in Algeria is an education campaign aiming to protest the long tenure of the Minister of Education with the initiator(s), Algerian Twitter users, based in Algeria and the target(s), the Algerian government based in Algeria. Digital activity consisted of microblog use. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as independent Twitter users participated in a loose campaign. As of April 22, 2013 the campaign is over.  The man targeted is not longer Minister of Education, but it is unclear why.  KS

TITLE: Against Open-Pit Mining in El Mirador
GOALDESC: "we will demand that the government respect Pachamama, water, life, and also Article 3 of the Mining Mandate that was issued by the Constituent Assembly, which declared the elimination of mining concessions in water sources and protected zones." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/17/ecuador-march-for-life-says-no-to-large-scale-mining/
INITDESC: FORMAL "indigenous Ecuadorian communities and other civil organizations are against these types of projects", "organized by .... the Unión Nacional de Educadores (National Union of Educators — Une) [es], the Frente Popular Zamora Chinchipe (The Popular Front of Zamora Chinchipe) and the Asamblea de los Pueblos del Sur (Assembly of the Peoples of the South)." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/17/ecuador-march-for-life-says-no-to-large-scale-mining/
TARGDESC: "The Ecuadorian government has decided to sign the mining contract without having passed an Environmental Impact Assessment or obtained an Environmental License, and also without the consent of the communities and indigenous people", "we will demand that the government respect Pachamama, water, life, and also Article 3 of the Mining Mandate"
PARTOFF: "President Correa, for his part declared [es] the beginning of the march a failure since only 500 people attended" "It was estimated [es] that in Cuenca there were already some 2000 participants. " "The day after the contract was signed, an activist group entered [es] the Chinese embassy in Quito to show their objection." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/17/ecuador-march-for-life-says-no-to-large-scale-mining/
OUTDESC: "Chinese-owned mining company Ecuacorriente S.A. expects to begin construction of production facilities during the second half of this year at the open-pit Mirador copper project, a company official said." - http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20130412-709011.html
NARR: Against Open-Pit Mining in El Mirador is an indigenous rights campaign aiming to stop mining operations with the initiator(s), a broad coalition of indigenous, labor, and left wing groups based in Ecuador and the target(s), the Ecuadorian Government and Ecuacorriente, based in Ecuador and China. Digital activity consisted of blogging and citizen journalism video coverage. Offline activity consisted of marches and protests throughout the country. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a tightly organized coalition. As of May 17, 2013 the campaign is ongoing. FE

TITLE: Rajoy: Resign
GOALDESC: "called for senior members of the party to resign" - http://www.euronews.com/2013/02/01/spanish-protesters-call-for-rajoy-resignation-as-corruption-scandal-closes-in/
INITDESC: INDIV "More than 500 protesters rallied outside the headquarters" - http://www.euronews.com/2013/02/01/spanish-protesters-call-for-rajoy-resignation-as-corruption-scandal-closes-in/
TARGDESC: "Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy" "Spain’s ruling People’s Party " - http://www.euronews.com/2013/02/01/spanish-protesters-call-for-rajoy-resignation-as-corruption-scandal-closes-in/
EPET: "An online protest has already gathered more than 100,000 signatures calling for anyone linked with the payments scandal to resign" - http://www.euronews.com/2013/02/01/spanish-protesters-call-for-rajoy-resignation-as-corruption-scandal-closes-in/
PARTOFF: "More than 500 protesters rallied outside the headquarters of SpainÕs ruling PeopleÕs Party on Thursday night"-http://www.euronews.com/2013/02/01/spanish-protesters-call-for-rajoy-resignation-as-corruption-scandal-closes-in/"
OUTDESC: "Mariano Rajoy Brey (Spanish pronunciation: [ma??jano ra?xoi ??ei]); born 27 March 1955) is the Prime Minister of Spain" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mariano_Rajoy
NARR: Rajoy: Resign is a democracy campaign aiming to throw the Spanish Prime Minister out of office with the initiator(s), individuals, based in Spain and the target(s), the Prime Minister based in Spain. Digital activity consisted of an online petition. Offline activity consisted of protests in Spain. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a coalition of individuals. As of May 19, 2013 the campaign is over without success, as the Prime Minister is still in power. KS

TITLE: Miners Protest Reduced Coal Subsidy
GOALDESC: "protesting the government's decision to do away with 63 percent of state subsidies of coal" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/06/29/spain-striking-miners-bring-struggle-to-the-net/
INITDESC: INDIV "Spanish miners" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/06/29/spain-striking-miners-bring-struggle-to-the-net/
PARTOFF: "Spanish miners went on an indefinite strike in the coalfields and in the streets, blocking roadways and forming barricades" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/06/29/spain-striking-miners-bring-struggle-to-the-net/, "the Marcha Negra (Black March), a march started last Friday which will end in Madrid on July 11" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/06/29/spain-striking-miners-bring-struggle-to-the-net/, "Another of the events closely followed by the Internet has been the removal of the minersÕ wives when they attended a budget vote in the Senate last week. Once the results of the vote were made public, the women began to sing the hymn of the miners, some in tears." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/06/29/spain-striking-miners-bring-struggle-to-the-net/
OUTDESC: "The Spanish government will not renew a controversial subsidy for coal-fired power stations worth around 400 million euros/year after it expires at the end of 2014" - http://www.pointcarbon.com/news/1.2158654
NARR: Miners Protest Reduced Coal Subsidy is a worker's rights campaign aiming to resist cuts to subsidies for the coal mining industry with the initiator(s), Spanish Miners unions and their supporters, based in Spain and the target(s), the Spanish Government. Digital activity consisted of tweeting and posting video. Offline activity consisted of a series of protests and marches across Spain. The structure of the campaign can best be described as led by unions and endorsed by a broad network of individual supporters. As of 2013 the campaign failed to stop the subsidy cut, but continue to post updates to twitter and do not appear to have ceased activity. FE [no date given]

TITLE: "I Won't Pay" Campaign
GOALDESC: "ask for solutions loophole that allowed fine cars not pay tolls." - http://ca.wikipedia.org/wiki/No_vull_pagar
INITDESC: INDIV "Casadellà Joseph Turon, a resident of English (the jungle ), decided not to pay a toll of the AP-7 and record the action, which was posted on YouTube ." - http://ca.wikipedia.org/wiki/No_vull_pagar
TARGDESC: "members of the Planning and Sustainability Commission of the Parliament of Catalonia" - http://ca.wikipedia.org/wiki/No_vull_pagar
VIDEO: " decided not to pay a toll of the AP-7 and record the action, which was posted on YouTube " - http://ca.wikipedia.org/wiki/No_vull_pagar
PARTOFF: "disobedience campaign tolls held a mass action to toll at noon Algemes’" [ translated] apparently mass groups decided not to pay the tolls - http://ca.wikipedia.org/wiki/No_vull_pagar  "At nine in the morning of May 15 of 2012 , [14] [15] promoter Joseph Casadellˆ campaign began a three-day march on foot,"
OUTDESC: "The Minister of Planning and Sustainability, Llu’s Recoder , has called for May 14, the group formed by the government of the Generalitat of Catalonia , the political groups, concessionaires, unions and chambers of commerce to study the reorganization of the tolls. [ 25] The Government of Catalonia announced on 15 May , in the midst of controversy during the 2012 privatized the tunnels Vallvidriera managed so far to Tabasa . [35] On May 24 , the RACC persuaded the Spanish government the return of the full amount of the tolls, through a system of deductions of income tax , for those users paying toll. [36]" [translated] - http://ca.wikipedia.org/wiki/No_vull_pagar
NARR: "I Won't Pay" is an economic justice campaign in Spain in which Catalan drivers do not wish to pay highway tolls.  Their target is Abertis, the company that collects the tolls, and also figures in regional and national government, though the main method of their campaign was simply not to pay the tolls, which 100,000 people did.
