The structure of the campaign can best be described as a stunt by an individual massively amplified through social media, such that specialized web infrastructure (a campaign blog, a Twitter account, a Facebook page) were created by others to support this initiative and mobilize massive online direct action (nonpayment of the tolls). The structure is a bit chaotic, with massive participation but no center, so central coordination of tactics beyond nonpayment, or even unified identification of targets. As of May 8, 2013 the campaign ongoing, though seems to have died down.  Many people did not pay tolls, and the government met about the issue.  But tolls are still required on Catalan roads. MJ

TITLE: Against Government Interference in Religion in Ethiopia
GOALDESC: "against alleged government's interference in their religious affairs" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/12/ethiopia-muslims-take-campaign-online-for-religious-independence/
INITDESC: FORMAL "Ethiopian Muslims both online and offline have been protesting" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/12/ethiopia-muslims-take-campaign-online-for-religious-independence/
SOCNET: https://www.facebook.com/DimtsachinYisema, https://www.facebook.com/ethiopianmuslims, https://www.facebook.com/Nur.Ethio "Rumours were circulating on Facebook" "one of the Facebook pages created in order to coordinate the protests" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/12/ethiopia-muslims-take-campaign-online-for-religious-independence/
MICBLOG: "Ethiopian Muslims have turned to Facebook and Twitter to make their voices heard" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/12/ethiopia-muslims-take-campaign-online-for-religious-independence/
PARTOFF: at least several hundred people - http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=iuLn2PBm5Fw
OUTDESC: Campaign continues, no evidence of government acceding to demands. "Though the government thought that Ethiopian Muslims would decrease their peaceful protests in the Ramadan season, the peaceful Friday protests have increased in different parts of the Country. Police have also begun taking measures in some parts of the Country." - http://ethsat.com/2013/07/20/ethiopian-muslims-continue-to-peacefully-protest/
NARR: Against Government Interference in Religion in Ethiopia is a religious freedom campaign in which Ethiopian Muslims are demanding that their government not interfere in their religious affairs. Digital activity consisted of active use of Facebook, to document protest and for other activities (translation of the mostly Amharic posts was not possible using our machine translation methods.) Offline activity consisted of about half a dozen offline protests which seem to have draw hundreds of protesters. The structure of the campaign can best be described as groups of Ethiopian Muslims using Facebook groups to share news, build community, and publicize (and probably organize) offline protests. As of APril 18, 2013 the campaign has received attention from (unnamed) international media but there is no evidence that the government has acceded to their demands.  MJ

TITLE: Respect the Constitution of Ethiopia
GOALDESC: "to demand their government to start respecting the Ethiopian Constitution." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/11/movement-to-respect-the-constitution-in-ethiopia/
INITDESC: INDIV "A group of young Ethiopian bloggers and activists based in Addis Ababa teamed up with Ethiopian netizens" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/11/movement-to-respect-the-constitution-in-ethiopia/
BLOG: "A group of young Ethiopian bloggers" started the campaign - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/11/movement-to-respect-the-constitution-in-ethiopia/
PARTOFF: 200 people in protest photo Ð http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/11/movement-to-respect-the-constitution-in-ethiopia/
OUTDESC: It appears that awareness was raised, but the impact is unclear Ð http://storify.com/opride/respecttheconstitution-faqs
NARR: "Respect the Constitution of Ethiopia" is a democracy and rule of law campaign initiated by Ethiopian bloggers and netizens asking the national government to respect the national Constitution. Digital activity consisted of a Facebook group, hashtag, and at least one event organized through Facebook. Offline activity consisted of that protest and at least one other protest. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose network of individual activist working together, mostly only. As of May 8, 2013 the campaign is ongoing but there is no evidence the government has responded in any way. MJ

TITLE: Save Police Pensions
GOALDESC: "protect police pensions from an unfair attack by retaining the current level of contributions" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1718-East-Anglian-Daily-Times.docx
INITDESC: INDIV "Sgt Nigel Tompsett" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1718-East-Anglian-Daily-Times.docx
OUTDESC: No indication of decision about pensions from anticipated government discussion; no e-petition link for outcome - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1718-East-Anglian-Daily-Times.docx
NARR: Save Police Pensions is an economic campaign aiming to decrease the portion of pensions paid by police officers with the initiator(s), an individual police officer, based in Great Britain and the target(s), the British government based in Great Britain. Digital activity consisted of an e-petition. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formalized e-petition. As of May 6, 2013 there is no indication of the outcome. KS

TITLE: PEN Protesta
GOALDESC: "for accountability for the murders and disappearances of journalists in Mexico" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/14/mexico-pen-protesta-international-writers-protest-in-solidarity-with-mexican-colleagues/
INITDESC: FORMAL "PEN International" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/14/mexico-pen-protesta-international-writers-protest-in-solidarity-with-mexican-colleagues/
PARTOFF: "PEN Protesta! was held at Casa Lamm, a cultural centre and gallery located in the legendary Colonia Roma district of Mexico City" (around 100 people) http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/14/mexico-pen-protesta-international-writers-protest-in-solidarity-with-mexican-colleagues/
OUTDESC: "Mexico, Where journalist murders go unpunished...Mexican crime reporter shot to death in Oaxaca Mexico City, July 18, 2013-", http://www.cpj.org/americas/mexico/
NARR: PEN Protesta is a freedom of expression and anti-violence campaign aiming to convince the Mexican government to protect journalists. Digital activity consisted of an online petition and offline activity consisted of a newspaper ad and an international delegation. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a professional organization, PEN, using its own resources to bring attention to violence in Mexico with little success. As of April 5, 2013 the campaign violence continues in Mexico. MJ

TITLE: Name and Shame Burton Cyber-Bully
GOALDESC: "contesting a police decision to only caution an online ‘troll’ who taunted her in the wake of her son’s death" - http://www.burtonmail.co.uk/News/Support-growing-for-mum-tormented-by-online-troll-19092012.htm
INITDESC: INDIV "A MOTHER... Bridget Agar" - http://www.burtonmail.co.uk/News/Support-growing-for-mum-tormented-by-online-troll-19092012.htm
OUTDESC: MPs introduced laws and prosecutors suggested law may have been misapplied http://www.burtonmail.co.uk/News/Attorney-General-admits-troll-caution-may-have-been-wrong-20130605171115.htm
NARR: Name and Shame Burton Cyber-Bully is a anti-bullying campaign aiming to being her tormentor to justice with the initiator(s), an individual, based in Great Britain and the target(s), various government officials, based in Great Britain. Digital activity consisted of an e-petition. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formal campaign. As of May 21, 2013, the campaign is over, with no information about the outcome available. KS

TITLE: Broom Revolution
GOALDESC: "calls for the resignation of high profile ministers" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/23/georgia-broom-revolution-as-parliamentary-elections-approach/
INITDESC: INDIV " A protest was organized by the Tbilisi State University students, however they were joined by all major universities." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/23/georgia-broom-revolution-as-parliamentary-elections-approach/
TARGDESC: "Students demanded the Minister of Internal Affairs Bacho Akhalia and several other officials to step down. " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/23/georgia-broom-revolution-as-parliamentary-elections-approach/
PARTOFF: "Thousands have protested in the Georgian capital, Tbilisi, after videos showing physical abuse in the country's prison system aired on some television stations and were shared on YouTube.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/23/georgia-broom-revolution-as-parliamentary-elections-approach/
OUTDESC: No information regarding whether there was a change on the ministers
NARR: Broom Revolution is a Georgian anti-violence campaign by students and other aggrieved citizens asking the Interior Minister to resign over egregious abuse of prisoners. Digital activity consisted of sharing of digital video of the abuse, discussion of the case on Facebook, and citizen journalists using Twitter to report offline protests. Offline activity consisted of protests in the hundreds and low thousands in the capital, across the country, and even abroad. The structure of the campaign can best be described as angry citizens discussing a problem online and then a subset of them (students) taking the protest offline and giving it a single demand. As of May 17, 2013, the campaign was a success. The minister resigned. MJ

TITLE: Anti-Occupation Comments on Russian President's Facebook Page
GOALDESC: "the withdrawal of Russian occupational forces from Georgia!" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/23/georgia-online-campaign-targets-russian-presidents-facebook-page/
INITDESC: INDIV "a group of Forum.ge [ka] users" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/23/georgia-online-campaign-targets-russian-presidents-facebook-page/
SOCNET: "Facebook...More than 200 users of the social networking site then started to post comments and continue to do so."
MICBLOG: "Facebook, Google Blogger, LiveJournal and Twitter, forcing the latter offline for two hours on 7 August, 2009,", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/23/georgia-online-campaign-targets-russian-presidents-facebook-page/
OUTDESC: "Georgia (still) considers South Ossetia to be occupied by the Russian army" http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Ossetia
NARR: Anti-Occupation Comments on Russian President's Facebook Page is a national identity campaign aiming to challenge the occupation of certain areas of Georgia by Russian forces. The initiators were Georgian forum users, the target was the President of Russia. Digital activity consisted of posting anti-occupation comments on the President's Facebook page and using the blog LiveJournal to give the call to action. There was no offline action.  The structure of the campaign can best be described as a group of 200 individuals coming together for one day to protest via social media. As of April 5, 2013, the campaign is over and the occupation continues.  MJ

TITLE: Global Rallies Follow Murder of Linden Protesters
GOALDESC: against police violence toward demonstrators in Guyana - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/04/guyana-the-occupy-movement-supports-linden/
INITDESC: INDIV "Concerned Guyanese" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/04/guyana-the-occupy-movement-supports-linden/
PARTOFF: "There were close to seventy persons at our launch, and dozens still join us weekly" Ð http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/04/guyana-the-occupy-movement-supports-linden/
OUTDESC: No news stories exist with "Occupy Guyana" keyword, and source1 contains no outcome info.
NARR: Global Rallies Follow Murder of Linden Protesters is a campaign resisting state violence aiming to protest killings in Linden by the government with the initiator(s), Occupy Guyana, Red Thread, Global Women's Strike, and other informal and formal organizations, based in Guyana and the UK and the target(s), the Guyanese Government. Digital activity consisted of mostly of facebook posting, though youtube, twitter, and blogging were used as well. Offline activity consisted of protests and occupations in Guyana and London. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose coalition of formal and informal organizations. As of April 17, 2013 the campaign is received substantial media coverage, is continuing to post on the Occupy Guyana facebook page, but it is unclear if offline activity is ongoing or if the goals of the movement were achieved. FE

TITLE: Save the Cattle in Mui Wo
GOALDESC: "insist that all the 14 cattle should be continue to live in the community" rather than being relocated - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/22/hong-kong-campaigning-against-cattle-relocation-policy/
INITDESC: INDIV "animal rights activists and local residents" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/22/hong-kong-campaigning-against-cattle-relocation-policy/
OUTDESC: "the government has agreed to arrange a meeting between the rural committee and animal rights activists later this week on August 25, 2012" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/22/hong-kong-campaigning-against-cattle-relocation-policy/
NARR: Save the Cattle in Mui Wo is an environmental campaign aiming to stop the removal of cattle in Mui Wo with the initiator(s), Friends of the Mui Wo Cattle, based in China and the target(s), the rural government of Mui Wo near Hong Kong. Digital activity consisted of facebook use and blogging. Offline activity consisted of taking care of the cattle. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an informal organization supported by a broad digital crowd. As of May 8, 2013 the campaign is ongoing, and the cattle are apparently still in Mui Wo. FE

TITLE: http://podkontrol.ru/
GOALDESC: "[against] the decision that “the statute of limitations had run out” on those human rights abuses" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/21/haiti-online-reaction-to-the-duvalier-decision/
INITDESC: FORMAL "Amnesty International" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/21/haiti-online-reaction-to-the-duvalier-decision/, INDIV "Haitians" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/21/haiti-online-reaction-to-the-duvalier-decision/
TARGDESC: "the investigative magistrate looking into human rights charges against Haiti's ousted dictator Jean-Claude “Baby Doc” Duvalier" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/21/haiti-online-reaction-to-the-duvalier-decision/
PARTOFF: "On February 7, 2012 dozens of Haitians gathered in front of the Ministry of Justice in a demonstration organized by several civil society organizations to call for justice in the case of Jean-Claude Duvalier." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/21/haiti-online-reaction-to-the-duvalier-decision/
OUTDESC: "Former Haitian dictator Jean-Claude "Baby Doc" Duvalier faced corruption and human rights charges in a court on Thursday" - http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/28/us-haiti-duvalier-idUSBRE91R12C20130228
NARR: The Haiti: Online Reaction to the Duvalier Decision campaign aiming to protest possible amnesty for Baby Doc Duvalier with the initiator(s), bloggers and Haitians and NGOs based in Haiti and the target(s), the Haitian legal system based in Haiti. Digital activity consisted of social networks, microblogs, blogs, and FLickr. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose group of unaffiliated individuals and NGOS. As of April 8, 2013 the campaign is ongoing, although Duvalier has been brought to court and is facing increased legal charges.  KS

TITLE: Campaign to Criminalize Domestic Violence
GOALDESC: "‘Bring attention to the issue of domestic violence in the Hungarian Parliament’ " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/26/hungary-parliament-forced-to-take-domestic-violence-seriously/
INITDESC: "NGOs fighting domestic violence" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/26/hungary-parliament-forced-to-take-domestic-violence-seriously/
OUTDESC: "the Parliament was eventually forced to treat domestic violence seriously. After the ruling Fidesz party changed its position, a week later, the retake of the initiative was supported by 366 deputies in favour, none against, with ten deputies abstaining" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/26/hungary-parliament-forced-to-take-domestic-violence-seriously/
NARR: Campaign to Criminalize Domestic Violence is an anti-violence campaign targeting the Hungarian Parliament.  The initiators were consultancy-advocacy hybrid organizations that seem to do both paid work and independent advocacy.  They were joined by individuals who organized through Facebook. Digital activity consisted of a Facebook group that shared news on the issue and organized a spontaneous protest. There was also discussion of a petition with over 100,000 signatures, but it was not stated whether or not it was digital.  Offline activity consisted of a flash protest. The structure of the campaign can best be described as small hybrid advocacy organizations working with individuals. As of April 26, 2013 the campaign is a success.  The Parliament voted to criminalize domestic violence. MJ

TITLE: Campaign to Enforce Law Protecting Falcons
GOALDESC: To stop the massacre of Amur Falcons "Last month a group of activists (Ramki Sreenivasan from Conservation India, Shashank Dalvi, Bano Haralu, Rokohebi Kuotsu) travelled to Nagaland to check out information that thousands of falcons were being hunted annually on the banks of the Doyang reservoir during their passage through that region. They accompanied a hunting group and documented the massacre:" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/29/each-year-more-than-100000-amur-falcons-are-killed-in-nagaland/
INITDESC: FORMAL "a group of activists (Ramki Sreenivasan from Conservation India, Shashank Dalvi, Bano Haralu, Rokohebi Kuotsu)" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/29/each-year-more-than-100000-amur-falcons-are-killed-in-nagaland/
OUTDESC: "The Honourable Minister (for environment and forests), Miss Jayanthi Natarajan personally intervened and The Indian Forest Department and District Administration also acted fast to destroy nets and release several still-captive falcons. The sale of falcons has now been stopped and at least one person has already been jailed. However, hunters in Nagaland has defied the ban for many years and it may happen again in future if the behaviors of the local hunters are not changed. " -http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/29/each-year-more-than-100000-amur-falcons-are-killed-in-nagaland/
NARR: Campaign to Enforce Law Protecting Falcons is a nature campaign aiming to stop the massacre of falcons with the initiator(s), an informal conservation group based in India, later applified by aninternational conservation organization and National Geographic. The target(s), the Indian government based in India. Digital activity consisted of e-petitions and video. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as directed by an informal organization. As of May 1, 2013 the campaign is over.  The Indian government agreed to act to protect the falcons, but the action is not seen as solving the problem in the longterm. KS

TITLE: Solidarity Campaign for Indian Women Arrested for Facebook Post
GOALDESC: Users arrested after facebook post about death of right wing Indian politician - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/19/outrage-in-india-on-arrest-of-girls-for-facebook-post/
INITDESC: INDIV "Netizens were outraged. On Twitter:"
TARGDESC: "“immediate” action against police personnel for arresting the girls. - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/19/outrage-in-india-on-arrest-of-girls-for-facebook-post/
OUTDESC: "The nationwide outrage over the arrests forced police and the state to backtrack. Transfer orders were given to two senior policemen and a Palghar court magistrate too was moved out. Not soon after, as the Supreme Court questioned the legality of the arrests, the state director general of police and the government decided to drop the charges against Shaheen and Rinu." - http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-12-17/mumbai/35867867_1_shaheen-dhada-palghar-court-magistrate-fb-account
NARR: Solidarity Campaign for Indian Women Arrested for Facebook Post is a campaign aiming to get local government officials to drop the charges against two women who criticized a religious leader on Facebook. Digital activity consisted of significant Twitter discussion, including a hashtag, blogging, and an e-petition. There was at least one offline in-person lobbying meeting between an activist and a state official.  The structure of the campaign can best be described as individuals voicing outrage at the event across a variety of channels almost immediately after the arrest occurred.  The creator of the e-petition put the demands of other netizens into strategic focus, but she was not the initiator of the campaign.  As of May 9, 2013, the campaign is a success. The charges against the women were dropped within days of their arrest. MJ

TITLE: Free Waqar
GOALDESC: "to release Waqar immediately and mete out justice" -http://www.dnaindia.com/india/1662116/report-free-waqar-a-campaign-for-justice-in-kashmir
INITDESC: INDIV "A group of youth, who call themselves Friends of Waqar" (org does not pre-date campaign)
OUTDESC: Waqar was released from prison - https://twitter.com/FreeWaqar/status/221685267445194753
NARR: Free Waqar is a human rights campaign aiming to release Waqar with the initiator(s), an informal group and individuals, based in India and the target(s), the Indian government based in India. Digital activity consisted ofTwitter and Facebook. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose and informal campaign. As of May 7, 2013 the campaign is over, having achieved success. KS

TITLE: Against Fraud in the Next Elections
GOALDESC: "to demand the criteria of impartiality of the Election Law, the formation of an independent National Electoral Commission" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/11/angola-violence-protest-elections/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "The protest was organized by a group of young people", "A number of members of the Angolan association of human rights defenders OMUNGA were imprisoned", "The organization announced another protest"  - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/11/angola-violence-protest-elections/
TARGDESC: "Discontentment with the government of President José Eduardo dos Santos [en]" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/11/angola-violence-protest-elections/
SOCNET: "according to reports [en] from various people on the spot, on Facebook, Twitter and blogs." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/11/angola-violence-protest-elections/
MICBLOG: "according to reports [en] from various people on the spot, on Facebook, Twitter and blogs." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/11/angola-violence-protest-elections/
PARTOFF: no numbers "the city of Luanda was again the stage for a protest" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/11/angola-violence-protest-elections/
OUTDESC: "The human rights environment in Angola is not conducive for free, fair and peaceful elections," said Leslie Lefkow, deputy Africa director for the rights monitoring group [Human Rights Watch]." - http://www.cnn.com/2012/09/02/world/africa/angola-elections
NARR: Against Fraud in the Next Elections is a pro-democracy campaign initiated by Angolan association of human rights defenders OMUNGA, a group of rappers, bloggers, and researchers including Nelson Pestana, Brigadeiro Mata Frakuxz, and Carbono Casimiro based in Ireland and Angola and the target, the government of President José Eduardo dos Santos based in Angola.Digital activity consisted of [parton, all Application variables coded “1”]. Offline activity consisted of protests in Luanda and Bengeula, Angola. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose network of advocates and human rights organizations. As of 2013 the campaign is appears to have ended, achieving some degree of content sharing, but apparently failing to achieve widespread coverage or response beyond violence from the administration. FE [no date given]

TITLE: Unveil Women's Right to Unveil in Iran
GOALDESC: "On 10 July, 2012 a Facebook campaign by “Iranian Liberal Students and Graduates” was launched to say ‘No’ to compulsory hijabs." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/06/iran-unveil-womens-right-to-unveil/
INITDESC: INDIV “Iranian Liberal Students and Graduates”
OUTDESC: "In Iran, where wearing the hijab is legally required, women, especially younger ones, have taken to wearing transparent and very loosely worn hijabs" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hijab#Sartorial_hijab_as_practiced
NARR: Unveil Women's Right to Unveil in Iran  is a human rights campaign aiming to say no to compulsory hijabs with the initiator(s), a group of students, based in Iran and the target(s), Iranians based in Iran. Digital activity consisted of Facebook and videos. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as led by an informal group. As of April 29, 2013, the campaign is ongoing without success. KS.

TITLE: Demanding Respect for Human Rights of Asylum Seekers in Germany
GOALDESC: "abrogation of mandatory residence, mandatory camp residency, and deportation." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/refugees-on-hunger-strike-in-germany-against-politics-of-deterrance/
INITDESC: INDIV "The protest is led mostly by Iranian refugees, young people that were forced to leave their homeland after the Green Revolution." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/refugees-on-hunger-strike-in-germany-against-politics-of-deterrance/
TARGDESC: "After a discussion with the Federal Commissioner for Migration, Refugees and Integration, Maria Böhmer, the refugees ended their hunger strike" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/refugees-on-hunger-strike-in-germany-against-politics-of-deterrance/
BLOG: http://no-racism.net/article/3318/ "The protest camps in the individual cities and the main camp in Berlin set up blogs" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/refugees-on-hunger-strike-in-germany-against-politics-of-deterrance/, http://gustreik.blogsport.eu/, http://asylstrikeberlin.wordpress.com/
PARTOFF: "On October 24, 2012 twenty-five asylum-seekers went on hunger strike in front of the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin, Germany" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/refugees-on-hunger-strike-in-germany-against-politics-of-deterrance/, "refugees built protest camps in eight other cities over the summer under the name ÒRefugee Tent Action.Ó" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/refugees-on-hunger-strike-in-germany-against-politics-of-deterrance/, "on September 8, about 70 refugees and supporters set out in a refugee caravan [de] on the almost 600-km stretch from WŸrzburg to Berlin" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/refugees-on-hunger-strike-in-germany-against-politics-of-deterrance/, "the largest demonstration to date against the living conditions of asylum-seekers, with 6,000 protesters on October 13" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/refugees-on-hunger-strike-in-germany-against-politics-of-deterrance/, "On October 15, refugee and activist protesters took over the Nigerian Embassy in Berlin" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/refugees-on-hunger-strike-in-germany-against-politics-of-deterrance/
OUTDESC: "the refugees ended their hunger strike on Friday, November 2. Bšhmer seemed ready to comply on the questions of refugee camps and mandatory residence, but maintained the official government line with regards to deportation." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/refugees-on-hunger-strike-in-germany-against-politics-of-deterrance/
NARR: Demanding Respect for Human Rights of Asylum Seekers in Germany is a immigrant rights campaign aiming to end mandatory residence, mandatory camp residency, and deportation.  It was initiated by Iranian refugees and targets the German national government. Digital activity consisted of blogs, livestreams, a campaign twitter hashtag, and at least one campaign Facebook page. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a small group of committed refugee activists staging longterm public offline action and using online tools to amplify themselves.  Sympathetic German citizens have assisted with the logistics of these offline protests and have further amplified the protest online. As of May 8, 2012 the campaign is still active. The Federal Commissioner for Migration, Refugees and Integration agreed to acceded to two of their three demands in 2012, but the issue was not resolved. MJ

TITLE: Exonerate Marcus Garvey
GOALDESC: "to clear Marcus Garvey's name ... as a convicted felon" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/27/jamaica-campaign-to-exonerate-marcus-garvey-part-1/
INITDESC: INDIV "Jamaican diaspora blogger, Geoffrey Philp" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/27/jamaica-campaign-to-exonerate-marcus-garvey-part-1/
OUTDESC: The campaign is ongoing, and the pardon has not been issued - http://petitions.moveon.org/sign/exonerate-marcus-garvey?source=c.url&r_by=4631897
NARR: Exonerate Marcus Garvey is a ethnic rights campaign aiming to pardon Marcus Garvey with the initiator(s), an individual and an informal organization, based in Jamaica and the target(s), President Obama and the US Congress, based in the USA. Digital activity consisted of blog, and e-petitions. Offline activity was not included in this campaign. The structure of the campaign can best be described as led by an individual, but gathering additional support from individuals. As of April 29, 2013, the campaign is ongoing. KS

TITLE: Opposition to Jordanian Internet Censorship Law
GOALDESC: "We urge the Telecommunications Regulatory Commission and the Ministry of Communication and Information Technology and the Jordanian government to withdraw your decision to apply the policy of blocking web sites." (translated) - http://7oryanet.com/?p=911
INITDESC: INDIV "Jordanian netizens" - https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2012/08/jordanians-protest-internet-censorship-law-sopa-style-blackout
OUTDESC: "On September 11, 2012, the Jordanian National Assembly approved legislation to regulate Internet publications." - http://www.loc.gov/lawweb/servlet/lloc_news?disp3_l205403330_text
NARR: Opposition to Jordanian Internet Censorship Law is a free speech campaign aiming to stop the implementation of a censorship law in Jordan with the initiator(s), a broad group of websites (unspecified), based, presumably, in Jordan and the target(s), the Jordanian Government. Digital activity consisted of making websites go dark, tweeting, and signing an online petition.  There was no apparent offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an unorganized group of individual concerned citizens and businesses. As of April 19, 2013 the campaign is has ended with the passage of the censorship law, after having mobilized over 150 websites to black out, gaining thousands of petition signatures and over 5000 tweets of support. FE

TITLE: Boycott of Lotte
GOALDESC: "[for removing Lotte's] discriminative policy on credit card charges, which have been imposed unfairly on small retailers" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/20/south-korea-mega-corporation-lotte-faces-nationwide-boycott/
INITDESC: INDIV "small business owners" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/20/south-korea-mega-corporation-lotte-faces-nationwide-boycott/
MICBLOG: "In the Twittersphere, net users have encouraged each other to join the move by blacklisting Lotte's drinks, beverage and confectionary." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/20/south-korea-mega-corporation-lotte-faces-nationwide-boycott/
OUTDESC: Outcome unclear, unable to find additional outcome source.
NARR: Boycott of Lotte is a economic campaign aiming to boycott a large business with the initiator(s), small business owners, based in Korea and the target(s), Lotte, a business conglomerate, based in Korea. Digital activity consisted of Twitter. Offline activity consisted of boycotts. The structure of the campaign can best be described as loose. As of April 24, 2013 the campaign is over but the outcome is unclear.  KS

TITLE: Asiana Flight Attendants Demand Right To Wear Trousers
GOALDESC: "[for allowing] women crew members to wear trousers" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/08/korea-flight-attendants-fight-for-the-right-to-wear-trousers/
INITDESC: INDIV "Female flight attendants of Asiana Airlines" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/08/korea-flight-attendants-fight-for-the-right-to-wear-trousers/
PARTOFF: "Female flight attendants of Asiana Airlines, one of the nation's major airlines, held a press conference" Ð http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/08/korea-flight-attendants-fight-for-the-right-to-wear-trousers/
OUTDESC: "Female flight attendants with South Korea's Asiana Airlines on Tuesday won a long-running battle to overturn a skirts-only dress code after the national human rights commission ruled it discriminatory" Ð http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/130326/asiana-flight-attendants-win-fight-wear-trousers
NARR: Asiana Flight Attendants Demand Right To Wear Trousers is a feminist campaign aiming to change the restrictive dress code for flight attendants of Asiana Airlines with the initiator(s), feminist Park Bong and South Korea's Network for Glocal Activism, based in South Korea and the target(s), Asiana Airlines based in South Korea. Digital activity consisted of twitter commentary and reporting and an e-petition.  The structure of the campaign can best be described as an uncoordinated group of commentators and a formal organization taking up the issue. As of 2013 the campaign has resulted in changing the dresscode of Asiana airlines and has achieved mainstream media coverage.  FE [no date given]

TITLE: For Freedom of Expression at Korean National Broadcaster
GOALDESC: "When asked in an interview whether he would ever consider stepping down as a way of taking responsibility for the fiasco, Kim Jae-chul responded [ko] that he will not resign until he is, “laid in a coffin.” - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/08/south-korea-journalists-stage-mass-walkout-from-national-broadcaster/
INITDESC: FORMAL "Around 400 unionized employees [ko] launched the strike" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/08/south-korea-journalists-stage-mass-walkout-from-national-broadcaster/
TARGDESC: "I ask this to MBC president Kim Jae-chul" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/08/south-korea-journalists-stage-mass-walkout-from-national-broadcaster/
PARTOFF: "Han Hak-soo ... posted photos from a rally." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/08/south-korea-journalists-stage-mass-walkout-from-national-broadcaster/
OUTDESC: "With the firm promises of parliamentary representatives to fire network president Kim Jae-chul and  elect a new board of directors in August, union members have finally decided to put an end to the strike." - http://www.humanrightskorea.org/2012/170-day-mbc-strike-ends-with-agreements-from-lawmakers/
NARR: For Freedom of Expression at Korean National Broadcaster is a free expression campaign aiming to eliminate censorship within the Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation with the initiator(s), the MBC labor union, based in South Korea and the target(s), MBC and its president Kim Jae-Chul. Digital activity consisted of tweets and letters of support, photo documentation on twitter and video. Offline activity consisted of a 170 day strike in South Korea. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a union and broad support from other media producers and individuals. As of 2013 the campaign has ended, after enjoying broad support on twitter and with employees returning to work after receiving assurances that parliament would take action and fire the company president.  FE [no date given]

TITLE: For Longer Poll Hours in South Korea
GOALDESC: "calling for longer poll hours, clashing with the ruling conservative party." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/10/02/south-korean-voters-calling-for-longer-poll-hours/
INITDESC: INDIV "young South Korean voters are calling for longer poll hours", "Net users filed an online petition" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/10/02/south-korean-voters-calling-for-longer-poll-hours/
TARGDESC: "urging the government and the National Election Commission to pass the pending proposal" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/10/02/south-korean-voters-calling-for-longer-poll-hours/
OUTDESC: "Polls opened early Wednesday in South Korea's closely contested presidential election, which pits The daughter of a former military ruler against a former human rights lawyer. Voting will end at 6 pm local time, or 0900 UTC, and results are expected later in the day", http://www.voanews.com/content/south-korea-presidential-electioni/1567636.html
NARR: For Longer Poll Hours in South Korea is a rule of law campaign aiming to extend poll hours with the initiator(s), individuals, based in Korea and the target(s), the government based in Korea. Digital activity consisted of microblogs, blogs and an e-petition. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formal campaign built around an e-petition. As of May 6, 2013 the campaign is over and successful as poll hours were extended. KS

TITLE: Against New Electoral Law in Kuwait
GOALDESC: "The protest came in reaction to the Amir Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah decree to change the electoral law, making a citizen vote for one candidate instead of four, as it used to be in the elections of Kuwaiti parliament. The protest was not only an objection for making such a change but more importantly to protest the change of a law without the parliament or the people having their say in it. " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/10/23/kuwait-the-countrys-biggest-protest/
INITDESC: INDIV "In a unique step, this demonstration was organized through Twitter. The account @KarametWatan [ar] (which translates to A Nation's Dignity) was started to call for the protest. It suggested an orange avatar (in reference to the 2006 youth movement that changed the electoral law from 25 districts to 5), and organized the meeting points with the following map:" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/10/23/kuwait-the-countrys-biggest-protest/
PARTOFF: "the Karamat Watan (A Nation's Dignity) march, which took place on Sunday, was made on Twitter, and attracted about 150,000 out of the country's population of 3 million" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/10/23/kuwait-the-countrys-biggest-protest/
OUTDESC: "Many of the arrests came after a series of street protests and online debate last year over changes to an electoral law passed by the emir" - http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/04/10/us-kuwait-politics-rally-idUSBRE93912120130410
NARR: Against New Electoral Law in Kuwait is a pro-democracy campaign aiming to stop the implementation of a new restrictive election law with the initiator(s), a group of protesters who remain anonymous, based in Kuwait and the target(s), the Kuwaiti Government. Digital activity consisted of reporting and promoting protests on Twitter. Offline activity consisted of massive protests in Kuwait. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a mass protest with unclear organization. As of May 17, 2013 the campaign has failed as the campaign was passed by the emir. FE

TITLE: Calling for Citizenship Rights with Candles
GOALDESC: "[for] the rights [of stateless people in Kuwait] to documents, education, health care, employment, and most importantly naturalization" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/21/kuwait-stateless-protesters-attacked-and-arrested-for-demanding-rights/
INITDESC: INDIV "Kuwait's stateless population" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/21/kuwait-stateless-protesters-attacked-and-arrested-for-demanding-rights/
PARTOFF: " Back in February and March, hundreds of them took to the streets to demonstrate for those rights, where they faced police brutality and arrests.... Last week, there were several small protests in reaction to the trials of protesters.... 30 men who entered a hunger strike on that same day." "(est. 500) #stateless protesters" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/12/21/kuwait-stateless-protesters-attacked-and-arrested-for-demanding-rights/
OUTDESC: "Last month, parliament passed a bill that calls for extending Kuwaiti citizenship to up to 4,000 people. The government has previously said as many as 34,000 bidoon could eventually qualify for citizenship. Yet if the legislation is signed into law by the emir, Sabah Al Ahmad Al Jaber Al Sabah, it is not certain the bidoon will benefit." - http://www.thenational.ae/news/world/middle-east/kuwaits-bidoon-may-still-be-in-limbo#ixzz2a08pQWOQ
NARR: Calling for Citizenship Rights with Candles is a minority rights campaign aiming to protest discriminatory policies against the Bedoon community of Kuwait with the initiator(s), blogger 7anthala Al-Bedoon, based in Kuwait and the target(s), the Kuwaiti government. Digital activity consisted of blogging, posting photos to twitter, and posting videos to youtube. Offline activity consisted of the lighting of candles throughout Kuwait. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an unorganized group of individuals and organizations that support the cause. As of 2013 the campaign ahieved partial success.  A law was passed to give some bidoons citizenship. FE [no date given]

TITLE: AlloFail
GOALDESC:
"Raising of Lebanese public pressure towards the Mobile Telecom operators to offer the best products and services at the best prices and quality.
Benchmarking Lebanese Mobile Telecom market with regional and international markets in terms of, but not strictly to, transparency and products and services issues.
Monitoring Lebanese Mobile Telecom operators’ activities in terms of, but not strictly to, transparency and products and services issues." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/31/lebanon-allofail-lobbying-for-better-mobile-services/
INITDESC: INDIV "This June, a campaign under the slogan of “AlloFail” was launched by young people like Hussein Dajani, who decided not just to sit and complain but rather make some tangible changes." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/31/lebanon-allofail-lobbying-for-better-mobile-services/
TARGDESC: " Telecom providers are answering and acting upon people’s complaints" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/31/lebanon-allofail-lobbying-for-better-mobile-services/
OUTDESC: No indication of action taken toward demands - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/31/lebanon-allofail-lobbying-for-better-mobile-services/
NARR: AlloFail is an information and technology campaign aiming to harness citizen interest in the telecom industry with the initiator(s), concerned citizens, based in Lebanon and the target(s), citizens, based in Lebanon. Digital activity consisted of YouTube videos, Facebook, Twitter.. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as led by individuals. As of April 29, 2013, the campaign is over but the outcome is unclear. KS

TITLE: Stand Up For Colombo's Trees
GOALDESC: "want to make sure that no more trees are cut in the future. We also want to appeal to relevant authorities to make the protection of the existing trees a priority in city planning." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/03/social-media-unites-to-stand-up-for-saving-colombos-trees/
INITDESC: INDIV "a number of netizens created a Facebook page titled “Stand Up For Colombo's Trees”" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/03/social-media-unites-to-stand-up-for-saving-colombos-trees/
TARGDESC: "appeal to relevant authorities to make the protection of the existing trees a priority in city planning." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/03/social-media-unites-to-stand-up-for-saving-colombos-trees/
PARTOFF: "More than a hundred people stood with innovative placards in several main roads of Colombo joining in a silent protest." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/03/social-media-unites-to-stand-up-for-saving-colombos-trees/
OUTDESC: No indication of response to or action taken toward demands - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/03/social-media-unites-to-stand-up-for-saving-colombos-trees/
NARR: Stand Up For Colombo's Trees is an environmental protection campaign by a group of netizens to convince the government not to cut down any more trees in the city of Colombo in Sri Lanka. Digital activity consisted of a Facebook group and blogging about the cutting of trees and an offline protest attended by about 200 people in Colombo. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a small group of committed activists using Facebook and blogs organize and bring attention to an injustice. Though the campaign successfully mobilized and offline protest it seems to be no longer active and the government seems to have made no response to the campaign. MJ [no date diven]

TITLE: For Education Reform in Morocco
GOALDESC: "The entire education system needs to be changed," "asking for a good education system"- http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/10/morocco-internet-helps-students-mobilize-for-change/
INITDESC: INDIV "a group of Moroccan students launched a Facebook page called “The Union of Moroccan Students to Change the Education System” - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/10/morocco-internet-helps-students-mobilize-for-change/
TARGDESC: "“encourage civil society and the Moroccan political elite to open a national debate on measures to reform the system" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/10/morocco-internet-helps-students-mobilize-for-change/
PARTOFF: "The group called [Fr] for a nationwide demonstration on Monday, August 6, 2012" ... "On the day of the protest, hundreds of students and their parents responded to the call as documented by pictures and videos posted and shared on the internet."
OUTDESC: "We have organized many activities and sensitization of protest to date. Among the most notable, August 6, there was a sit-in organized nationally in twenty cities in Morocco, for the right to education and free. The first action of our movement has been a success. On October 18, we organized art activities (distribution of books, theater, music ...) in solidarity with the international movement around the world as part of the International Student Movement. Our latest action is the campaign "student renaissance", inspired by the one launched by the Women Uprising in the Arab World, and calling for solidarity with students struggling to change the education system. We received centiares contributions from the first day and the campaign continues today ." [translated]  - http://www.jadaliyya.com/pages/index/9543/penser-le-changement-de-l%C3%A9ducation-au-maroc_-inter
NARR: For Education Reform in Morocco is an education campaign aiming to start a debate about national education reform.  It was started by a Facebook group calling themselves "The Union of Moroccan Students to Change the Education System" and targets Moroccan civil society and political elites. Digital activity consisted of a Facebook page and digital video. Offline activity consisted of at least one protest in Casablance. The structure of the campaign can best be described as ongoing campaign created by a group of young people using social media as their organizational infrastructure. As of May 9, 2013 the campaign is ongoing.  There is no evidence that the campaign has encouraged the national discussion of civil society and political elites that the initiators intended. MJ

TITLE: Against Morocco's Rape Marriage Law (Article 475)
GOALDESC: "draw attention to the plight of women like Amina who are forced to marry their rapists, who also get to escape punishment" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/16/morocco-sit-in-planned-to-raise-awareness-about-the-plight-of-rape-victims/
INITDESC: "Moroccans are planning to take their protest" - https://www.facebook.com/RIPAminaNonAuViolAvecLaCompliciteDeLEtat/info
TARGDESC: "Moroccans are planning to take their protest to the Parliament" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/16/morocco-sit-in-planned-to-raise-awareness-about-the-plight-of-rape-victims/
PARTOFF: Sit in organized, no numbers specified - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/16/morocco-sit-in-planned-to-raise-awareness-about-the-plight-of-rape-victims/
OUTDESC: The government changed the law - http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/01/2013123225637555571.html
NARR: Against Morocco's Rape Marriage Law (Article 475) is a gender rights campaign aiming to end a law that often forces rape survivors to marry the rapist with the initiator(s), citizens and an informal organization, based in Morocco and the target(s), the Moroccan government based in Morocco. Digital activity consisted of Facebook. Offline activity consisted of protests and sit-ins. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formalized coalition. As of May 19, 2013 the campaign is over, having successfully seen the law overturned. KS

TITLE: Committee to Defend the Constitution and Democracy Protests in Moldova
GOALDESC: "demanding to dissolve the parliament and to set a date of early elections" - http://eastbook.eu/en/2012/01/country-en/moldova-en/moldova-anti-governmental-protests-in-chisinau/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Committee to Defend the Constitution and Democracy" - http://eastbook.eu/en/2012/01/country-en/moldova-en/moldova-anti-governmental-protests-in-chisinau/
TARGDESC: "leaders of the ruling Alliance for European Integration" - http://eastbook.eu/en/2012/01/country-en/moldova-en/moldova-anti-governmental-protests-in-chisinau/
PARTOFF: "several thousands were protesting against the governmental policy", http://eastbook.eu/en/2012/01/country-en/moldova-en/moldova-anti-governmental-protests-in-chisinau/
OUTDESC: "The Alliance for European Integration was the ruling coalition in Moldova from the July 2009 election until it lost a no confidence vote on February 13, 2013. It was succeeded by the Pro-European Coalition.", https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alliance_for_European_Integration
NARR: Committee to Defend the Constitution and Democracy Protests in Moldova is an anti-government campaign aiming to protest against the government with the initiator(s), a mix of individuals and and informal organization, based in Moldova and the target(s), the Moldavian government, also based in Moldova. Digital activity consisted of social networks and commenting on blogs. Offline activity consisted of protests in Moldova. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an informal organization led campaign. As of April 8, 2013 the campaign is a success.  The ruling coalition lost a no confidence vote in February of that year. KS

TITLE: Yo Soy 132
GOALDESC: "[for] the right to information and the right to freedom of speech" - http://www.vice.com/es_mx/la-guia-vice-para-las-elecciones/lgvple-131-ms-uno
INITDESC: INDIV "a group of students from the Universidad Iberoamericana" (translated) - http://www.vice.com/es_mx/la-guia-vice-para-las-elecciones/lgvple-131-ms-uno
PARTOFF: Rally against Pena Nieto at UI - http://www.vice.com/es_mx/la-guia-vice-para-las-elecciones/lgvple-131-ms-uno, protests at other Mexican universities (TEC, ITAM, and Anahuac) - http://www.vice.com/es_mx/la-guia-vice-para-las-elecciones/lgvple-131-ms-uno, march at Estela - http://www.vice.com/es_mx/la-guia-vice-para-las-elecciones/lgvple-131-ms-uno, general assembly of students from several universities - http://www.vice.com/es_mx/la-guia-vice-para-las-elecciones/lgvple-131-ms-uno
OUTDESC: "The movement successfully demanded that the second presidential debate be broadcast nationally. It also proposed a third debate organized by members of the Yo Soy 132 movement that was held without the presence of Enrique Pe–a Nieto, the candidate for the PRI, who rejected the invitation and said it lacked conditions of impartiality." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yo_Soy_132
NARR: Yo Soy 132 is a pro-democracy campaign aiming to protest media bias in presidential elections with the initiator(s), students, based in Mexico and the target(s), the Mexican government and media based in Mexico. Digital activity consisted of microblogging. Offline activity consisted of demonstrations and protests in Mexico. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a national movement of students and concerned individuals. As of April 10, 2013, the campaign achieved some success.  A presidential debate was broadcast according to their demands. KS

TITLE: Campaign for a Fair Energy Law
GOALDESC: "demanding fair energy legislation and an end to state-controlled price hikes in Macedonia" "against price hikes of state-controlled monopoly commodities (electricity, fuel, central heating) " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/04/despite-threats-macedonian-activists-fight-for-fair-energy-law/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "grassroots civil initiative AMAN" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/04/despite-threats-macedonian-activists-fight-for-fair-energy-law/, http://amanmk.wordpress.com/%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%82/
TARGDESC: "state" "the authorities, represented by the Regulatory Commission for Energy" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/04/despite-threats-macedonian-activists-fight-for-fair-energy-law/
SOCNET: "infiltration by partisan agent provocateurs, hacking and mysterious closing down of their recurrent Facebook event", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/04/despite-threats-macedonian-activists-fight-for-fair-energy-law/
PARTOFF: "they held a protest in front of the state Public Broadcasting Service", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/04/despite-threats-macedonian-activists-fight-for-fair-energy-law/
OUTDESC: (March 2013) "The Government of Macedonia ("GoM") has announced its intention to privatise (recapitalize) JSC "Macedonian Power Plants" ("ELEM") by privatising 49% of the shares to a private investor. ELEM is a 100% state owned company which produces around 96% of the entire domestic production of electricity.", http://www.mondaq.com/x/238910/Corporate+Commercial+Law/Corporate+Energy+And+Infrastructure
NARR: Campaign for a Fair Energy Law is an economic justice campaign aiming to stop inflation of electricity prices by state-run company with the initiator(s), AMAH, based in Macedonia and the target(s), the Macedonian Government. Digital activity consisted of reporting on protests and grievances on blogs, a Facebook page, twitter posting, mapping, and video coverage. Offline activity consisted of protests and petition drives in Macedonia. The structure of the campaign can best be described as organized by a grassroots informal organization with apparently wide support throughout the country. As of May 17, 2013 the campaign is partially successful, since the power company in question is no longer wholely owned by the government. FE

TITLE: Don't Save the General
GOALDESC: "for the end of their country's military rule" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/14/mauritania-the-people-want-the-end-of-military-rule/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Coordination of Democratic Opposition" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/14/mauritania-the-people-want-the-end-of-military-rule/
TARGDESC: "the regime of Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/14/mauritania-the-people-want-the-end-of-military-rule/
PARTOFF: "Mauritanians took to the streets in a massive march calling for the end of their country's military rule." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/14/mauritania-the-people-want-the-end-of-military-rule/
OUTDESC: "Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz (born 20 December 1956) is the President of Mauritania." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohamed_Ould_Abdel_Aziz
NARR: Don't Save the General is a pro-democary campaign aiming to depose Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz, who came to power through a coup with the initiator(s), the coordination of Democratic Opposition (a coalition of opposition parties), the February 25th Youth Movement, and For Mauritania, an NGO, based in Mauritania and the target(s), President Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz. Digital activity consisted of blogging, tweeting, and using facebook events. Offline activity consisted of massive protests in Mauritania. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a disparate coalition of opposition groups without much clear coordination. As of April 19, 2013 the campaign has ended and President Abdel Aziz remains in power, though the campaign did mobilize thousands of people for street protests.  FE

TITLE: No to French Guardianship for Mauritania
GOALDESC: "No to Guardianship" of Mauritania by France - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/28/mauritania-february-25th-movement-says-no-to-guardianship-of-france/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "the February 25th movement" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/28/mauritania-february-25th-movement-says-no-to-guardianship-of-france/, https://www.facebook.com/m25fev/info
PARTOFF: thousands of protesters in march - http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=-SMEZem8PFY
OUTDESC: no outcome information in Source1 and additional outcome source could not be located.
NARR: No to French Guardianship for Mauritania is a political freedom campaign aiming to protest France's involvement in Mauritania's political situation with the initiator(s), an informal organization of students, based in Mauritania and the target(s), the government, based in Mauritania. Digital activity consisted of Twitter, Facebook and videos. Offline activity consisted of rallies. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an informal organization. As of May 1, 2013 the campaign is over, and Mauritania still has sovereignty. KS

TITLE: Against Foreign Mining in Mauritania
GOALDESC: "demand the reduction of the environmental pollution caused by these companies" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/a-mauritanian-blogging-week-against-foreign-mining/
INITDESC: INDIV "A group of Mauritanian bloggers launched a blogging campaign" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/a-mauritanian-blogging-week-against-foreign-mining/
TARGDESC: " their opinions about the issue of foreign companies, accused of looting Mauritania's mineral wealth." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/05/a-mauritanian-blogging-week-against-foreign-mining/
OUTDESC: "The [Mauritanian] mining, fishing, agricultural, banking, petroleum and technology sectors are actively seeking foreign direct investment." - http://www.state.gov/e/eb/rls/othr/ics/2013/204691.htm
NARR: Against Foreign Mining in Mauritania is an economic justice campaign aiming to pressure companies to remit more payments to Mauritania and improve safety with the initiator(s), a group of bloggers, based in Mauritania and the target(s), international mining companies. Digital activity consisted of blogging and twitter posts. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose group of bloggers. As of May 6, 2013 the campaign doesn't appear to have been successful, and it is unclear if it is ongoing. FE

TITLE: Stop Section 114A: Opposition to Malaysia Internet Censorship Law
GOALDESC: "against the recently introduced Section 114A, an amendment in the law that is deemed by many as a threat to internet freedom" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/17/malaysia-government-vows-to-review-web-censorship-law-after-protest/
INITDESC: INDIV "Malaysians" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/17/malaysia-government-vows-to-review-web-censorship-law-after-protest/
EPET: " It began on May 31, 2012 when Centre for Independent Journalism (CIJ) launched an online petition to call on the government to withdraw the Evidence (Amendment) (No. 2) Act. The petition, which received more than 3300 signatures, was handed over to the Deputy Minister in the Prime Minister’s Department VK Liew in Parliament on June 26, 2012." - no link provided - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaysia_Internet_Blackout_Day_(2012)
OUTDESC: FORMAL "the Centre for Independent Journalism " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/17/malaysia-government-vows-to-review-web-censorship-law-after-protest/
NARR: Stop Section 114A: Opposition to Malaysia Internet Censorship Law is a free speech campaign aiming to stop the implementation of a law that would hold individuals liable for 3rd party content posted on websites with the initiator(s), the Centre for Independent Journalism, the National Union of Journalists, and a broad array of organizational and individual websites, based in Malaysia and the target(s), the Malaysian Government. Digital activity consisted of blogging, shutting down websites. Offline activity consisted of lobbying, public forums and public informational tables in Malaysia. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a campaign initiated by professional interest groups by deeply supported and implemented by a broad array of individuals and organizations. As of April 19, 2013 the campaign is has ended, and the law was implemented, despite supporters shutting down hundreds of websites and receiving legacy news coverage.  FE

TITLE: Against Lynas Advanced Materials Plant in Malaysia
GOALDESC: "Recently, the Save Malaysia! Stop Lynas! campaign started to protest against the release of radioactive waste from a rare earth processing plant in Malaysia." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/04/27/malaysia-rare-earth-processing-plant-creates-backlash/
INITDESC: INFORMAL Stop Lynas Coalition https://twitter.com/StopLynasCoaltn
PARTOFF: A picture shows a march taking place, thought it is impossible to tell how many people - at least 20 are in the shot.
OUTDESC: "Save Malaysia Stop Lynas objects to what it describes as potentially dangerous radioactive waste that comes from processing the commodities. The company and the Malaysian government maintain the project is safe." - http://blogs.wsj.com/searealtime/2013/04/18/rare-earth-protesters-in-malaysia-forge-an-election-alliance/?mod=google_news_blog
NARR: Against Lynas Advanced Materials Plant in Malaysia is an environmental protection campaign aiming to protest radioactive waste with the initiator(s), Malaysian citizens, based in Malaysia and the target(s), Lynas based in Australia. Digital activity consisted of Facebook and Twitter. Offline activity consisted of a march. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose campaign. As of May 7, 2013 the campaign has failed since the Lynas plant project is still moving forward. KS

TITLE: Against Removal of Fuel Subsidy in Nigeria
GOALDESC: "[against] the removal of fuel subsidy by the government" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/01/13/occupy-nigeria-from-cyberspace-to-face-to-face/
INITDESC: FORMAL "trade unions" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/01/13/occupy-nigeria-from-cyberspace-to-face-to-face/
EPET: "There is even an Occupy Nigeria petition" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/01/13/occupy-nigeria-from-cyberspace-to-face-to-face/
SOCNET: "a Facebook Page or two named ÒOccupy NigeriaÓ" http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/01/13/occupy-nigeria-from-cyberspace-to-face-to-face/ (Facebook search based on this information reveals: https://www.facebook.com/OccupyNigeriaGroup, https://www.facebook.com/pages/Occupy-Nigeria/248063985262363, https://www.facebook.com/pages/Occupy-Nigeria/185630604869061, and other smaller groups)
MICBLOG: #occupynigeria #fuelsubsidy @toluogunlesi @feathersproject "tweets are coming in so fast at times its almost impossible to keep up with the conversation. " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/01/13/occupy-nigeria-from-cyberspace-to-face-to-face/
PARTOFF: no numbers "For days, the nation had been shut down: no one worked, earned or learned." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/01/13/occupy-nigeria-from-cyberspace-to-face-to-face/
OUTDESC: "[President] JonathanÕs attempt to scrap the gasoline subsidy on Jan. 1, 2012, without prior announcement sparked a week of strikes and protests, forcing the government to partially reinstate them" - http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-03-19/nigeria-s-jonathan-still-plans-to-cut-gasoline-subsidy-correct-.html
NARR: Against Removal of Fuel Subsidy in Nigeria is an economic campaign aiming to protest and end to fuel subsidies with the initiator(s), labor unions, based in Nigeria and the target(s), the Nigerian government based in Nigeria. Digital activity consisted of Twitter. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a large-scale campaign initiated by a formal organization. As of April 30, 2013 the campaign succeeded since subsidies were partially reinstated. KS

TITLE: Against Inmpunity of Rape in Nepal
GOALDESC: "to seek justice and immediate attention on the recent cases of violence against women." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/29/delhis-rape-case-stir-movement-for-justice-in-nepal/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "groups have come forward to form a movement for justice and rule of law in the country.","The activists prepared a petition" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/29/delhis-rape-case-stir-movement-for-justice-in-nepal/
TARGDESC: "a petition and put it online to be signed and submitted to Prime Minister Dr. Baburam Bhattarai to seek justice and immediate attention" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/29/delhis-rape-case-stir-movement-for-justice-in-nepal/
PARTOFF: "Activists in Nepal have been protesting in front of Prime MinisterÕs residence at Baluwatar for the past few days" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/29/delhis-rape-case-stir-movement-for-justice-in-nepal/
OUTDESC: No indication of response to or action taken toward demands in source and outcome source link broken - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/29/delhis-rape-case-stir-movement-for-justice-in-nepal/ & http://nepalasithappens.blogspot.com/2013/04/anti-rape-protests-in-nepal-enters.html
NARR: Against Inmpunity of Rape in Nepal is an anti-rape campaign aiming to pressure the Nepali Government to implement more severe penalties for rape with the initiator(s), groups of activists in Nepal. Digital activity consisted of twitter and facebook commentary, and a petition. Offline activity consisted of protests in Nepal, including ongoing daily protests at the Prime Minister's residence. The structure of the campaign can best be described as unclear given the reporting, though there does appear to be a high degree of coordination. As of May 8, 2013 the campaign is ongoing, having been offered limited concessions from the government, but not having achieved its stated goals. FE

TITLE: Chupa Chups: Stop Using Plastic Sticks
GOALDESC: "change [lollipop sticks] to a more sustainable material [from plastic]" - http://ebusinesspacific.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1594:sam-judd-never-underestimate-the-little-people&catid=77:fooda-wine&Itemid=352
INITDESC: INDIV "Astral Sligo" - http://ebusinesspacific.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1594:sam-judd-never-underestimate-the-little-people&catid=77:fooda-wine&Itemid=352, INFORMAL "the Two Hands Project" - http://ebusinesspacific.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1594:sam-judd-never-underestimate-the-little-people&catid=77:fooda-wine&Itemid=352
OUTDESC: "confectionary manufacturing giant Chupa Chups to start a project that will change the product to a more sustainable material" - http://ebusinesspacific.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1594:sam-judd-never-underestimate-the-little-people&catid=77:fooda-wine&Itemid=352
NARR: Chupa Chups: Stop Using Plastic Sticks is an environmental campaign aiming to stop the use of plastic lollipop sticks with the initiator(s), individuals, based in New Zealand and the target(s), Chupa Chup based in Spain. Digital activity consisted of Facebook. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a small, tight campaign. As of May 19, 2013, the campaign is over with complete success, as Chupa Chup now uses sustainable materials. KS

TITLE: Save the Maui's Dolphin
GOALDESC: "opposition to proposed iron ore seabed mining in New Zealand’s coastal waters" - http://www.surfsister.com.au/index.php/impact/surfers-for-cetaceans/360-kasm-kiwis-against-seabed-mining
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Kiwi’s Against Seabed Mining (KASM)" INFORMAL "Surfers For Cetaceans" - http://www.surfsister.com.au/index.php/impact/surfers-for-cetaceans/360-kasm-kiwis-against-seabed-mining, http://kasm.weebly.com/contact-us.html, http://www.s4cglobal.org/contact.php
TARGDESC: "Mr. Andrew Summerville, representative of the Trans Tasman Resources (TTR) mining company" - http://www.surfsister.com.au/index.php/impact/surfers-for-cetaceans/360-kasm-kiwis-against-seabed-mining, http://www.ttrl.co.nz/
PARTOFF: "two hundred other concerned coastal people" Ð http://www.surfsister.com.au/index.php/impact/surfers-for-cetaceans/360-kasm-kiwis-against-seabed-mining
OUTDESC: "There's a moratorium on seabed mining in parts of Australia, because of environmental concerns. The Greens want one here too, but the minister says that won't be happening." - http://www.3news.co.nz/Greens-seek-halt-to-Taranaki-seabed-mining/tabid/1607/articleID/294795/Default.aspx#ixzz2a0S05ioD
NARR: Save the Maui's Dolphin is an environmental campaign aiming to stop the proposal Seabed mining in the New Zealand’s coastal waters. The initiator is K.A.S.M. (Kiwi’s Against Seabed Mining based in New Zeland). The campaign targets the New Zealander government in order to ban this kind of mining (as it is in some Australian regions). Online activity consisted in a post in a website and the website of KASM. Offline activity was a March in the Raglan West Bridge, New Zealand. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a advocacy organization campaign which is locally supported by individuals and informal organizations (surfers). As of June 3, 2013 the campaign is ongoing and has not achieved their goals, because the company continues claiming that the “dolphin” region does not have special environmental value for deserving protection.  LS

TITLE: Pakistani Groups Lobby International Firms Not to Respond to Censorship Software Proposal
GOALDESC: "calling on technology companies not to respond to the call for proposals [to create a large scale internet filtering system]" - http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2012/04/20124785420873341.html
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Advocacy group Bolo Bhi" - http://bolobhi.org/about-us/contact/, FORMAL "Islamabad-based digital rights group Bytes for All" - http://content.bytesforall.pk/contact, http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2012/04/20124785420873341.html
OUTDESC: "on March 19, an article in the International Herald Tribune-affiliated Express Tribune declared the filtering plans shelved." "As a result, a number of technology companies, including Cisco and McAfee SmartFilter (both of which, it should be noted, sell their censorship wares to other countries), made statements refusing to sell to the PTA" - http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2012/04/20124785420873341.html
NARR: Pakistani Groups Lobby International Firms Not to Respond to Censorship Software Proposal is an anti-censorship campaign by formal and information Pakistani advocacy groups asking tech companies in the US, Canada, and China not to respond to a contract by the Pakistani government for new censoring services.  Digital activity consisted of description of the campaign on the organizations' websites and an e-petition that received few signatures. Offline activity consisted of letters to the CEOs of these companies. The structure of the campaign can best be described as small yet well-connected and strategically-skilled grassroots organizations in Pakistan connecting with major international rights organizations (Business and Human Rights Resource Centre, Article 19, the Global Network Initiative, Access, and the Electronic Frontier Foundation) and successfully pressuring not only the companies not to bid, but pressuring the Pakistani government to withdraw the contract offer. They also received media attention from major US newspapers, including the NYT. As of April 11, 2013, the campaign succeeded in achieving its goal.  The government withdrew is call for proposals.  MJ

TITLE: Indigenous Protest of Mining and Hydroelectric Facilities
GOALDESC: "protesting mining and construction of hydroelectric facilities in their district" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/12/panama-silvia-carrera-the-indigenous-leader-who-took-on-the-government/
INITDESC: FORMAL "the indigenous people of Ngobe Bugle" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/12/panama-silvia-carrera-the-indigenous-leader-who-took-on-the-government/
PARTOFF: "the indigenous people of Ngobe Bugle decided to take over the highway on January 31, 2012, protesting mining and construction of hydroelectric facilities in their district.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/12/panama-silvia-carrera-the-indigenous-leader-who-took-on-the-government/
OUTDESC: "The crisis has been alleviated for the moment with an agreement between the indigenous group and the government.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/12/panama-silvia-carrera-the-indigenous-leader-who-took-on-the-government/
NARR: Indigenous Protest of Mining and Hydroelectric Facilities is an indigenous rights campaign aiming to prevent the national government's efforts to set up mining and hydroelectric facilities in the district of the Ngobe Bugle in Panama, where both target and initiator are based. Digital activity consisted of a Twitter account being started by an indigenous leader. Offline activity consisted of blocking the national highway for days and a speech in the legislature. The structure of the campaign can best be described as direct action by a indigenous group, with some discussion of their campaign offline. As of April 5, 2013 there has been an agreement with the government, but the indigenous group still threatened protests, indicating that they did not see that victory as final or secure.  MJ

TITLE: Campaign Against Conga Mining Project
GOALDESC: "against polluting mining activities [in Cajamarca, Peru]" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/07/peru-following-the-great-water-march/
INITDESC: INDIV "community landowners" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/07/peru-following-the-great-water-march/
PARTOFF: "another march took place in Cajamarca, the Jug March [es], where 2,000 people marched" "While Terra.pe writes [es] of 200 people, EFE counts [es] 300. Newspaper El Comercio mentions [es] that 600 community landowners started the journey, and RPP indicates [es] that 300 people arrived at Cajamarca's Plaza de Armas to sleep overnight and continue marching the next day." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/02/07/peru-following-the-great-water-march/
OUTDESC: "Newmont Mining Corporation (NYSE: NEM) ("Newmont" or the "Company") announced today that, in agreement with the government of Peru, it has suspended construction activities at the Conga project" - http://www.mining.com/newmont-suspends-construction-at-the-conga-project-in-agreement-with-the-government-of-peru/
NARR: Campaign Against Conga Mining Project is a economic and environmental campaign aiming to save lakes from the Conga Mining Company with the initiator(s), a loose coalition of individuals and interested organizations, based in Peru and the target(s), the mining company based in Peru. Digital activity consisted of microblogs, social networks, blogs and videos. Offline activity consisted of the Water March and rallies. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a crowd of people marching together, supported by digital activists covering their activity. As of April 8, 2013 the campaign succeeded.  The company suspended the project. KS

TITLE: Filipino Protest of Cybercrime Law
GOALDESC: "for the repeal of a cybercrime law that has been dubbed as “E-Martial Law.”" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/10/04/philippines-anti-cybercrime-law-sparks-online-protests/
INITDESC: "Filipino netizens" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/10/04/philippines-anti-cybercrime-law-sparks-online-protests/
SITE: "Some websites also voluntarily blacked out their websites in solidarity with the anti-cybercrime law campaign." - https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=365596786854608&set=a.130663580347931.34470.128615437219412&type=1&relevant_count=1&ref=nf
SOCNET: Facebook users blacked out profiles, no numbers provided http://globalvoicesonline.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/comment-blocked-332x300.jpg
OUTDESC: The law was passed, but protest apparently continues - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cybercrime_Prevention_Act_of_2012#cite_note-9
NARR: Filipino Protest of Cybercrime Law is a free speech campaign aiming to stop the passage and implementation of a cybercrime law with the initiator(s), concerned internet users, Anonymous, and Kabataan Partylist, a youth political action group, based in the Philippines and the target(s), the Philippino Government. Digital activity consisted of twitter and facebook usage, blacking out websites, an e-petition, and video production. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose network of individuals and groups opposed to the bill. As of May 7, 2013 the campaign is over, though the campaign won an injunction against the implementation of the bill, it was ultimately passed. FE

TITLE: Save Bondoc Peninsula
GOALDESC: "expose massive rights violation in Bondoc Peninsula, Quezon in northern Philippines. In particular, they are demanding the immediate removal of military troops in the province." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/06/philippines-save-bondoc-peninsula-campaign/
INITDESC: "The Save Bondoc Peninsula Movement " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/07/06/philippines-save-bondoc-peninsula-campaign/, https://www.facebook.com/notes/save-bondoc-peninsula-movement/internatl-hr-groups-aquinos-oplan-bayanihan-undeclared-martial-law-in-south-quez/476342629123048
PARTOFF: no numbers "a Peace Caravan and Mercy Mission in the Bondoc Peninsula from June 25 to July 2 to document human rights abuses and to give relief operations, medical and psychosocial assistance, among others."
OUTDESC: Activists continue with campaign, no evidence of official response. "The Save Bondoc Peninsula Movement and Karapatan-Southern Tagalog have been calling for the pullout of the military from the villages of South Quezon and Bondoc Peninsula. The human rights groups documented 128 cases of different types of abuses. - See more at: http://bulatlat.com/main/2013/07/15/foreign-delegates-in-rights-conference-to-investigate-cases-of-military-abuses/#sthash.GaieaOWi.dpuf" - http://bulatlat.com/main/2013/07/15/foreign-delegates-in-rights-conference-to-investigate-cases-of-military-abuses/
NARR: Save Bondoc Peninsula is a anti-military campaign aiming to end the military occupation of Bondoc Peninsula with the initiator(s), Save Bondoc Peninsula (a coalition of NGOs, grassroots groups, and individuals), based in the Philippines and the target(s), the Philippino government and military. Digital activity consisted of blogging, using video and photos to document protests and grievances, and Facebook usage. Offline activity consisted of protests in the Philippines.
