The structure of the campaign can best be described as a coalition of NGOs, grassroots groups, and individuals organized relatively coherently. As of April 22, 2013 the campaign appears to have ended after having received media coverage, but without, apparently, meeting their stated goals. FE

TITLE: Opposing Government Austerity: ‘Screw the troika! We want our lives‘
GOALDESC: "to defeat austerity with credible alternative proposals" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/17/portugal-15spt-troika-austerity-queselixeatroika/
INITDESC: INDIV "citizens are using their blogs to reflect on the momentum that the protests have brought, and writing about possible paths for strengthening citizenship." - http://www.queselixeatroika15setembro.blogspot.pt/p/internacional.html
TARGDESC: "discontented with the measures imposed by the government and the troika" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/17/portugal-15spt-troika-austerity-queselixeatroika/
PARTOFF: "Between 660,000 and 1 million people of all ages took to the streets in more than 40 cities throughout the country and abroad" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/17/portugal-15spt-troika-austerity-queselixeatroika/
OUTDESC: "the Portuguese constitutional court has ruled that four of the nine austerity measures will have to be amended" - http://www.dw.de/portugal-stumbles-on-overturned-austerity-plans/a-16730268
NARR: Opposing Government Austerity: ‘Screw the troika! We want our lives‘  is an anti-austerity campaign aiming to stop EU austerity programs in Portugal with the initiator(s), a broad base of Portuguese protesters, and the target(s), the Portuguese Government, the EU, and the IMF based in Portugal, the US, Belgium, and Germany. Digital activity consisted of using twitter and facebook, blogging, using maps, and reporting with video. Offline activity consisted of massive protests in Lisbon. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a huge mobilization of a broad range of Portuguese. As of May 8, 2013 the campaign is ongoing, having stopped some of the austerity measures. FE

TITLE: Supporting Stricter Control of Foreign-Funded NGOs
GOALDESC: "calling for stricter controls on foreign-funded Russian NGOs." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/04/02/russia-online-petition-seeks-to-increase-controls-on-foreign-funded-ngos/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Podkontrol.ru argues that it is proposing", "Endorsed by 13 “affiliate organizations,” the initiative enjoys the support of pro-regime political groups like the Anti-Orange Committee, Dmitri Rogozin's ‘Congress of Russian Communities,’ and Alexander Dugin's ‘International Eurasian Movement.’" - http://podkontrol.ru/, http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/04/02/russia-online-petition-seeks-to-increase-controls-on-foreign-funded-ngos/
TARGDESC: " the petition calls on the government to adopt “the Law on the Foreign Financing of NGOs,”  - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/04/02/russia-online-petition-seeks-to-increase-controls-on-foreign-funded-ngos/
OUTDESC: The law was passed  - http://podkontrol.ru/
NARR: Supporting Stricter Control of Foreign-Funded NGOs is an anti-civil society campaign by a number of pro-Putin groups asking the government to more stringently regulate Russian NGOs that receive foreign funds, a stated goal of Putin himself. Digital activity consisted of a very successful online petition and some blog posts supporting it. There does not appear to have been any offline activity.  The structure of the campaign can best be described as a number of formal and informal pro-Putin grassroots groups pushing Putin's agenda using digital activism. As of April 11th the campaigns succeeded in achieving its goal. The suggested bill was created and passed.  MJ

TITLE: Protest of Bias by NTV Channel
GOALDESC: "This group was created in order to call for a boycott of NTV and its advertisers." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/19/russia-anatomy-of-a-protest-film-causes-ntv-lies-scandal/
INITDESC: INDIV "a few hundred protesters gathered for", "The unsanctioned rally was organized via social networks", "There is now a “Boycott NTV” Facebook page, with 1,566 members", "Another Facebook group, “I do not watch NTV,” has 1,607 ‘likes'. - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/19/russia-anatomy-of-a-protest-film-causes-ntv-lies-scandal/
TARGDESC: "boycotting the products and services of the channel's advertisers.", "your company will refuse to advertise on NTV"
SOCNET: https://www.facebook.com/NeSmotruNtv, https://www.facebook.com/groups/266441033438650/ , https://www.facebook.com/events/132595713535350/, causes-ntv-lies-scandal/ https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?, set=a.413801251979524.118988.100000489596416&type=3 - "Bloggers got completely tired of accusatory #NTV journo-crap. DDoSed #NTV servers and completely trashed Vkontakte page: vk.com/ntv" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/19/russia-anatomy-of-a-protest-film-
HACK: "Bloggers got completely tired of accusatory #NTV journo-crap. DDoSed #NTV servers and completely trashed Vkontakte page: vk.com/ntv" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/19/russia-anatomy-of-a-protest-film-causes-ntv-lies-scandal/
PARTOFF: " a few hundred protesters gathered for a mock funeral of the Òtruthful television.Ó - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/19/russia-anatomy-of-a-protest-film-causes-ntv-lies-scandal/
OUTDESC: Despite protests against "Anatomy of a Protest" a second installment was produced by the channel and broadcast a few months later: "'Anatomy of a Protest 2,' an investigative report broadcast on the state-owned NTV television network on Friday...'This is simply slander,' Udaltsov told RIA Novosti." - http://en.rian.ru/politics/20121005/176433559.html
NARR: Protest of Bias by NTV Channel is an anti-media bias campaign aiming to critique NTV's pro-government bias with the initiator(s), a broad group of journalists and opposition members, based in Russia and the target(s), NTV based in Russia. Digital activity consisted of blogging, massive twitter activity, protests organized through facebook, and coverage of events through social media. Offline activity consisted of protests in Moscow. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an unorganized group of journalists, bloggers, opposition members and other social media users. As of 2013 the campaign is had massive support online, with 13,805 tweets, and large scale participation on facebook and on blogs.  Additionally, several protests resulted from the campaign, with no clear participation figures, but indications of at least 100 arrests at one protest. However, the campaign failed to stop bias.  A second installment of the documentary was subsequently aired by the channel. FE [no date given]

TITLE: Against Russian Internet Blacklist
GOALDESC: "to protest proposed government legislation that opponents believe is a thinly disguised attempt to censor the Internet"
INITDESC: FORMAL "Russian Wikipedia", Livejournal, V Kontakte - http://techpresident.com/news/wegov/22547/wikipedia-russia-strikes-24-hours-protest-proposed-legislation-create-internet-blacklist
SITE: http://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%97%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B0 "The Russian Wikipedia went dark for 24 hours on Tuesday to protest proposed government legislation" - http://techpresident.com/news/wegov/22547/wikipedia-russia-strikes-24-hours-protest-proposed-legislation-create-internet-blacklist
BLOG: "The people behind LiveJournal, by far the most popular blogging platform in Russia with an estimated 1.6 million users, publishedtheir reasonsfor opposing the bill in a Russian and English post." - http://techpresident.com/news/wegov/22547/wikipedia-russia-strikes-24-hours-protest-proposed-legislation-create-internet-blacklist, http://livejournal.livejournal.com/19317.html
OUTDESC: "RussiaÕs so-called Internet blacklist law, the infamous Bill 89417-6, took effect Thursday." - http://www.dailydot.com/news/russia-blacklist-bill-894176-begins-censorship/
NARR: Against Russian Internet Blacklist is an information and expression campaign initiated by the Russian arm of Wikipedia to stop a restrictive Internet bill being considered by the national legislature. Digital activity consisted of Wikipedia going black, and two other tech firms posting banners and publishing their disapproval on their sites. Offline activity consisted of a tiny protest in front of the Duma. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a tech group with western links initiating a campaign that did not see much additional participation either by other tech firms or by citizens (beyond lots of shares). As of May 17, 2013 the campaign failed.  the law passed and went into effect. MJ

TITLE: Demanding Freedom and Due Process for Mohammed Albajady
GOALDESC: "[against Mohammed Albajady's] extrajudicial treatment/detention" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/05/saudi-arabia-tweeting-albajadys-hunger-strike/
INITDESC: INDIV "Saudi netizens" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/05/saudi-arabia-tweeting-albajadys-hunger-strike/
PARTOFF: Mohammed Albajady himself "has been on hunger strike in protest against his detention for almost two weeks"
OUTDESC: "sentencing of a prominent Saudi Arabian human rights activist to four years in jail followed by a five-year travel ban" "the Specialized Criminal Court in Riyadh handed down the sentence to Mohammed Saleh al-Bajady Ð believed to be currently in the sixth week of a hunger strike Ð in a secret session." - https://www.amnesty.org/en/for-media/press-releases/saudi-arabia-human-rights-activist-sentenced-four-years-jail-following-secr
NARR: Demanding Freedom and Due Process for Mohammed Albajady is a human rights campaign aiming to end the unlawful detention of Mohammed Albajady with the initiator(s), the Gulf Center for Human Rights and Saudi netizens, based in Ireland and Saudi Arabia and the target(s), the Saudi authorities, based in Saudi Arabia. Digital activity consisted of Twitter. No offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a call to action from a formal organization and citizen activity online. As of April 10, 2013 the campaign has not succeeded in achieving the prisoners release. KS

TITLE: Against Detention Without Trial in Saudi Arabia
GOALDESC: "[against denial of] access to trials and [against withholding knowledge] of charges in Saudi Arabia" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/06/09/saudi-arabia-protests-to-free-detainees-held-without-trial/
INITDESC: INDIV "The families of detainees" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/06/09/saudi-arabia-protests-to-free-detainees-held-without-trial/
PARTOFF: Photos show dozens of protesters http://globalvoicesonline.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/3.jpg
OUTDESC: Protesters were punished, and did not appear to secure the release of prisoners http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/17/saudi-arabia-peaceful-protesters-to-be-flogged-judge-rules/
NARR: Against Detention Without Trial in Saudi Arabia is a human rights campaign aiming to spread awareness of detainees held by the government with the initiator(s), families of the detainees, based in Saudi Arabia and the target(s), the Saudi Kingdom based in Saudi Arabia. Digital activity consisted of video and microblogs. Offline activity consisted of protests in Saudi Arabia. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a call to action by individuals with a collective identity but no collective name. As of April 19, 2013 the campaign has not succeeded in changing detention practices. KS

TITLE: #SudanRevolts
GOALDESC: "for regime change in Sudan" - http://www.pbs.org/mediashift/2012/07/in-the-face-of-censorship-sudanrevolts-goes-social195
INITDESC: INDIV "[Sudanese] protestors" - http://www.pbs.org/mediashift/2012/07/in-the-face-of-censorship-sudanrevolts-goes-social195
VIDEO: "This Youtube video calls attention to the recent protests in Sudan and the #SudanRevolts movement." - http://www.pbs.org/mediashift/2012/07/in-the-face-of-censorship-sudanrevolts-goes-social195
PARTOFF: "Hundreds of protesters have been arrested, detained, and beaten" - http://www.pbs.org/mediashift/2012/07/in-the-face-of-censorship-sudanrevolts-goes-social195, "To protest increased censorship, approximately 100 journalists held a demonstration in front of the SudanÕs National Commission for Human Rights in Khartoum on July 5." - http://www.pbs.org/mediashift/2012/07/in-the-face-of-censorship-sudanrevolts-goes-social195
OUTDESC: "Lieutenant General Omar Hassan Ahmad Al-Bashir is the President of Sudan" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omar_al-Bashir
NARR: #SudanRevolts is a human rights campaign aiming to end the Sudanese regime with the initiator(s), informal organizations and netizens, based in Sudan and the target(s), the Sudanese government based in Sudan. Digital activity consisted of Twitter, videos, blogs and maps. Offline activity consisted of protests in the Sudan. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose uprising of individuals and informal organizations. As of April 10, 2013,  the campaign is ongoing but failed to bring down Al-Bashir's regime. KS

TITLE: Free the AstraZeneca Beagles
GOALDESC: "against AstraZeneca  plans to fly dogs over from Sweden to England for animal testing." - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1711-Manchester-Evening-News.docx
INITDESC: FORMAL "Win Animal Rights" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1711-Manchester-Evening-News.docx, http://www.animalconcerns.org/resource.html?itemid=200608150122050.77008&catid=5
OUTDESC: "In February activists began to campaign against AstraZeneca to release dogs being moved from a Swedish facility to a British one. The pharmaceutical agreed to rehome 80 dogs after approval from the veterinarian, however the remainder were considered important to continued medical research efforts." - http://speakingofresearch.com/2013/04/
NARR: Free the AstraZeneca Beagles is an animal rights campaign aiming to secure the release of Beagles used for pharmaceutical research with the initiator(s), Win Animal Rights and Swedish animal rights activists, and the target(s), AstraZeneca based in the UK. Digital activity consisted of facebook usage, blogging, and twitter usage. Offline activity consisted of protests in the UK and Sweden. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a well organized group organized informally. As of May 16, 2013 the campaign has been partially successful, having secured the release of 80 dogs.FE

TITLE: Save Togo
GOALDESC: "for the implementation of recommendations made by the National Commission on Human Rights relating to torture and wide ranging constitutional change" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/06/19/togo-save-togo-protesters-violently-clash-with-police/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "several political and human rights organisations" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/06/19/togo-save-togo-protesters-violently-clash-with-police/
PARTOFF: no numbers other than number of injured, which range from 54-120 "A peaceful march" " Other demonstrations are scheduled for the upcoming week." "Since its creation, the collective has organised several marches"- http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/06/19/togo-save-togo-protesters-violently-clash-with-police/
OUTDESC: Things seem to have gotten worse: "Amnesty International is preoccupied by the recent escalation in the repression against political opponents or persons demonstrating dissatisfaction with the governmentÕs policies. " - http://www.amnestyusa.org/our-work/countries/africa/togo
NARR: Save Togo is a human rights campaign aiming to have the government follow human rights recommendations with the initiator(s), Save Togo, based in Togo and the target(s), the Togo government, based in Togo. Digital activity consisted of Twitter, Facebook, videos and a blog. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a coalition of connected organizations. As of April 29, 2013 the campaign is ongoing but human rights conditions in Togo have actually gotten worse. KS

TITLE: Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra: Resign
GOALDESC: "calling for the ouster of the government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/25/pitak-siam-rally-turns-violent-in-thailand/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "The anti-government rally organized by Pitak Siam or “protect Thailand” network" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/25/pitak-siam-rally-turns-violent-in-thailand/
TARGDESC: "They accused the Yingluck government of corruption and of being disrespectful to the King." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/25/pitak-siam-rally-turns-violent-in-thailand/
PARTOFF: "the highest realistic estimation was about at 30,000 [protestors], whereas police didnÕt even more than 20,000." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/25/pitak-siam-rally-turns-violent-in-thailand/
OUTDESC: "The incumbent PM is Yingluck Shinawatra, leader of the Pheu Thai Party. She has held the position since 5 August 2011." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Thailand
NARR: Pitak Siam Calls for Prime Minister's Resignation is a political campaign aiming to protest the current government with the initiator(s), an organization, based in Thailand and the target(s), the government based in Thailand. Digital activity consisted of videos and microblogs. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formal campaign. As of May 13, 2013 the campaign is over without achieving success. KS

TITLE: Justice for Cihan Kirmizigul
GOALDESC: " to protest injustice against political prisoners." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/11/turkey-outrage-at-sentencing-of-scarf-case-student/
INITDESC: INDIV "His professors at university started “Ö?rencime Dokunma Kampanyas?” [tr] (Don't Mess With Our Students campaign) under the leadership of Mehmet Karl?, research fellow at Galatasaray University" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/11/turkey-outrage-at-sentencing-of-scarf-case-student/
TARGDESC: "The Turkish judicial system has for some time been under the scrutiny" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/11/turkey-outrage-at-sentencing-of-scarf-case-student/
BLOG: "Kirmizigul's friends and professors started a blog [tr] to make his case known" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/11/turkey-outrage-at-sentencing-of-scarf-case-student/ called Ö?rencime Dokunma (do not touch my students) - http://www.ogrencimedokunma.org/
PARTOFF: "The supporters of jailed students gathered in Taksim Square in Istanbul on the evening of May 11, to protest injustice against political prisoners." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/11/turkey-outrage-at-sentencing-of-scarf-case-student/
OUTDESC: Hard to tell from the outcome source translation, but it appears he got a reduced sentence, though he still is serving time - http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/kirmizigul_3uncu_pakette-1128017
NARR: Justice for Cihan Kirmizigul is a Turkish campaign against ethnic discrimination in the judiciary aiming to undo the unjust conviction of a Kurdish student. The initiators were his friends and professors, along with an informal student organization called  Ö?rencime Dokunma (Do Not Touch my Students), which advocates for students who are unjustly imprisoned.   Though not clearly stated, the target is the government/judiciary.  Digital activity consisted of tweeting images of offline protest and sharing news about his case on the organization blog. Offline activity consisted of at least two street protests in Istanbul. The structure of the campaign can best be described as friends of the imprisoned student working with an informal student advocacy group. As of May 4, 2013, the campaign was a partial success.  Some charges against the student were reversed while others were upheld. [no author indicated]

TITLE: Opposition to Media "Bullying" by WWCT
GOALDESC: " demanding Tsai Eng-ming to resign from all media management position. They also called for professional journalistic practice and an anti-media monopoly law." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/04/taiwan-smear-campaign-sparks-historic-media-monopoly-protest/
INITDESC: INDIV "The Youth Coalition Against Media Giant [zh] was set up by students from 28 universities and it organized a demonstration against WWCT" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/04/taiwan-smear-campaign-sparks-historic-media-monopoly-protest/
TARGDESC: "We demand NCC [Taiwan media regulator the National Communications Commission] to defend a democracy that protect diversity, journalistic autonomy and press freedom." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/04/taiwan-smear-campaign-sparks-historic-media-monopoly-protest/
EPET: "Parent groups launched a petition against media bullying of students" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/04/taiwan-smear-campaign-sparks-historic-media-monopoly-protest/ - https://www.facebook.com/events/492688487411626/
PARTOFF: "around 700 students showed up outside the headquarter of WWTC" Ð http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/04/taiwan-smear-campaign-sparks-historic-media-monopoly-protest/; "More than 9,000 people joined the September 1 rally" ÐÊhttp://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/04/taiwan-smear-campaign-sparks-historic-media-monopoly-protest/
OUTDESC: "Several media groups lashed out yesterday at the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) after anti-media monopoly legislation failed to be set for review in the Legislature's extra session." Ð http://www.chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/national/national-news/2013/06/13/381068/Anti-media-monopoly.htm
NARR: Opposition to Media "Bullying" by WWCT is a anti-media monopoly campaign aiming to protest the harassment of academics and journalists by We Want China Times with the initiator(s), a range of academics, journalists and media personalities, along with informal organizations, though the attack on Huang Kuo-chang sparked the protests based in China and the target(s), media conglomerate We Want China Times. Digital activity consisted of significant Facebook activity, blogging, an e-petition (unconfirmed), and video usage - as well as blogging and posts on newspaper websites. Offline activity consisted of protests with large turnouts in China. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose and uncoordinated effort by a range of individuals in the media industry, academics, and concerned parents and youth that have formed informal organizations for protest. As of 4/17/2013 the campaign is ongoing, having achieved widespread media coverage and substantial internet attention.(http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/04/taiwan-smear-campaign-sparks-historic-media-monopoly-protest/ ) FE

TITLE: Say "No" to the Defamation Law
GOALDESC: "against the adoption of the bill ... that calls for penalties of up to five years in jail for defamation" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/29/ukraine-protesting-the-controversial-defamation-bill/
INITDESC: INDIV "Ukrainian citizens" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/29/ukraine-protesting-the-controversial-defamation-bill/, INFORMAL "media outlets" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/29/ukraine-protesting-the-controversial-defamation-bill/, FORMAL "Reporters Without Borders" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/29/ukraine-protesting-the-controversial-defamation-bill/
OUTDESC: Against Defamation Bill in Ukraine is a governance campaign aiming to abandon the defamation bill with the initiator(s), citizens and an international organization, based in Ukraine and France and the target(s), the Ukrainian Parliament based in Ukraine. Digital activity consisted of placing a banner on news websites and running social networking pages. Offline activity consisted of a rally in Kyiv, Ukraine. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formal petition of a professional organization and a tight online mobilization of news outlets. As of July 24, 2013, the campaign is succeeded in its goal of abandoning the defamation bill. SL
NARR: Say "No" to the Defamation Law is a freedom of expression campaign aiming to convince members of the Ukrainian Parliament to withdraw a version of a draft law that would criminalize defamation and have chilling effects on journalism. The initiator group included an informal coalition of Ukrainian journalists, and the campaign was supported by the international organization Reporters Without Border. Digital activity consisted of news sites posting banners against the law on their homepage and a Facebook group with over 7,000 members which shared news. Offline activity consisted of at least two street protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose national coalition of middle class professionals (journalists), supported by an international organization based abroad. As of April 26 the campaign is a success and the law was withdrawn. MJ

TITLE: Against Vote-Rigging in Parliamentary Elections
GOALDESC: "The opposition is accusing election officials of re-writing the vote's results in favor of pro-government candidates. On Nov. 5, hundreds of people gathered in Kyiv for a protest rally against vote-rigging – and some of the protesters seem determined to stay in front of the Central Election Commission indefinitely, despite heavy riot police presence at the site and a recent court decision banning rallies in Kyiv." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/07/ukrainians-rally-in-protest-over-vote-rigging/
INITDESC: FORMAL The Ukrainian Opposition and supporters
PARTOFF: "hundreds of people gathered in Kyiv for a protest rally" Ð http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/07/ukrainians-rally-in-protest-over-vote-rigging/
OUTDESC: "The Central Election Commission of Ukraine adopted a resolution on November 5 recognizing the impossibility of announcing election results in five single-seat constituencies ... it also recognized the need to hold repeat elections in these constituencies" Ð http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukrainian_parliamentary_election,_2012#Repeat_elections_in_5_constituencies
NARR: Against Vote-Rigging in Parliamentary Elections is a democracy and rule of law campaign by opposition political parties asking the government to cease and undo attempts at vote-rigging. Digital activity consisted of individuals using Facebook to report vote-rigging around the country, and at least two hashtags. Offline activity consisted of protests in the capital, Kiev. The structure of the campaign can best be described as formal organizations (political parties) being assisted by individuals acting as citizen journalists. As of May 8, 2013, there is partial success.  The results of 5 contested districts were annulled, but new elections have not been called. MJ

TITLE: KONY 2012
GOALDESC: "make African cult and militia leader, indicted war criminal and the International Criminal Court fugitive Joseph Kony globally known in order to have him arrested by the end of 2012" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kony2012
INITDESC: FORMAL "Invisible Children, Inc." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kony2012
TARGDESC: "a select group of individuals ... [including] 12 'policy makers' that have 'the power to keep U.S. government officials in Africa' in order to work toward the capture of Kony" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kony2012
VIDEO: "As of 17 October 2012, the film had over 97 million views on video-sharing website YouTube,[10] and over 21.9 K "likes" on Vimeo" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kony2012
PARTOFF: "As part of the campaign, American supporters were asked to put up posters in their hometowns in an action named "Cover the Night", which took place on April 20, 2012." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kony2012
OUTDESC: "The campaign resulted in a resolution by the United States Senate and contributed to the decision to send troops by the African Union" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kony2012, "Joseph Rao Kony (pronounced IPA: [ko?];[7] born sometime between July and September 1961)[1] is the leader of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA), guerrilla group which used to operate in Uganda. " - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Kony
NARR: KONY 2012 is a human rights campaign aiming to create awareness about the conflict in Uganda with the initiator(s), a formal organization and individuals based in the USA and the target(s), students and opinion leaders based in the USA. Digital activity consisted of a very popular video and Facebook use. Offline activity consisted of speaking events and activities. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formal campaign using a variety of tactics. As of May 15, 2013 the campaign achieved some success in that the US Senate resolved to send troops to help in capturing Kony.  Kony was not yet been captured.  KS

TITLE: Enterprise Rent-A-Car: Stop Opposing Recall Law
GOALDESC: For Enterprise Rent-a-Car to "support... legislation 'to oversee the way car rental companies manage the safety recall process for vehicles in their fleets.'" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/1755-St.-Louis-Post-Dispatch-.docx
INITDESC: INDIV "Carol Houck" mother of two girls that died in an auto accident with in Enterprise car FORMAL "consumer groups " "Consumers for Auto Reliability and Safety, a national nonprofit based in California." - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/1755-St.-Louis-Post-Dispatch-.docx, http://www.carconsumers.org/contact.htm
OUTDESC: "Rental car firm reverses on recalls Enterprise, under fire for stand, now says it will back legislation for government oversight." - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/1755-St.-Louis-Post-Dispatch-.docx
NARR: Enterprise Rent-A-Car: Stop Opposing Recall Law is a “improving safety in rented cars” campaign aiming to make Enterprise change its position against the Law. The initiator(s), are several consumer organizations bases in USA. The target is the company at national level. Digital activity consisted of an online petition. There is no information about the offline activity of the campaign (although the competitors publicly announced their support to the law). The structure of the campaign can best be described as networks among consumer organizations that took this campaign among their different goals. As of June 3, 2013. The campaign has achieved its goal, Enterprise Rent-a-Car abruptly reversed by announcing it would support government oversight of policies for renting or selling vehicles under recall for safety reasons.LS

TITLE: New York Times Reporters Demand Better Conditions
GOALDESC: "compensation, health benefits and overtime pay, all of which the union feels should increase, rather than decrease, over time." - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1723-New-York-Observer.docx
INITDESC: FORMAL "New York Times union" - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1723-New-York-Observer.docx,
PARTOFF: "In the latest development at 620 Eighth Avenue, New York Times union organizers have called on hundreds of rank and file to leave the building at 3:35 today for a rally on the sidewalk west of the building. The message to Times management: Stop being so stingy! - no numbers provided
OUTDESC:
"After almost two years of contentious negotiations with management, New York Times staffers voted to ratify a new contract on Tuesday, the Newspaper Guild of New York announced.

The deal, which is valid through March 30, 2016, institutes modest bonuses and pay raises, introduces a controversial and less generous new pension plan, and preserves the current union health plan."
NARR: New York Times Reporters Demand Better Conditions is a economic justice campaign aiming to renegotiate the Times's union contract with the initiator(s), the union, based in the USA and the target(s), the New York Times based in the USA. Digital activity consisted of an e-petition. Offline activity consisted of a walk out and rally. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formal, organized campaign. As of May 20, 2013 the campaign is over and successful, with a new contract. KS

TITLE: Against New Instagram Terms of Service
GOALDESC: "[against] changes in Instagram's user agreement [that] give it broader rights to use its members' photos in advertisements" - http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2250190/Kim-Kardashian-leads-way-celebs-vow-quit-Instagram-backlash-new-photo-ownership-rules.html
INITDESC: INDIV "Kim Kardashian, Kendall Jenner, Khloe Kardashian and Lauren Conrad are amongst those planning on closing their accounts should the proposed new rules come into force" - http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2250190/Kim-Kardashian-leads-way-celebs-vow-quit-Instagram-backlash-new-photo-ownership-rules.html
OUTDESC: "Instagram has backpedaled on changes to its terms of service that appeared to let the maker of the photo-sharing app sell users' images" - http://news.cnet.com/8301-1023_3-57560370-93/instagram-rolls-back-terms-of-service-after-ownership-dustup/
NARR: Against New Instagram Terms of Service is a freedom of information campaign aiming to stop instagram's changes to its terms of service with the initiator(s), Instagram users, based in the USA and the target(s), Instagram, based in the USA. Digital activity consisted of Twitter. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose, unstructured effort. As of May 20, 2013 the campaign is over, having achieved success, when Instagram rolled back the proposed changes. KS

TITLE: The Cost of Knowledge
GOALDESC: "[against Elsevier's practice of charging] "exorbitantly high" prices for its journals and criticises its practice of selling journals in "bundles" so libraries "must buy a large set with many unwanted journals, or none at all" ... [and against] Elsevier's support for the Stop Online Piracy Act (SOPA), PIPA and the US Research Works Act" - http://www.theguardian.com/science/2012/feb/02/academics-boycott-publisher-elsevier
INITDESC: INDIV "PhD student Tyler Neylon" - http://www.theguardian.com/science/2012/feb/02/academics-boycott-publisher-elsevier, INDIV "Fields medal [winner] Timothy Gowers" - http://www.theguardian.com/science/2012/feb/02/academics-boycott-publisher-elsevier
OUTDESC: Against Elsevier is a consumer satisfaction campaign aiming to boycott the academic publisher Elsevier with the initiator(s), an academic, Gowers in Cambridge University, based in the U.K. and the target(s), Elsevier based in Amsterdam, Netherlands. Digital activity consisted of posting blogs and putting signatures to an online petition. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose network of professional academics using digital media. As of July 25, 2013, the campaign's goal has been partially achieved. SL
NARR: The Cost of Knowledge is a freedom of information campaign aiming to pressure Elsevier to change restrictive access practices with the initiator(s), a group of mathematicians, based in a broad range of countries, but primarily the US and UK and the target(s), Elsevier, a publisher based in Amsterdam. Digital activity consisted of an e-petition, a twitter feed, and a blog. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a network of scholars. As of Mau 6, 2013 the campaign is ongoing, having pressured Elsevier to make some limited changes. FE

TITLE: Reinstate University of Virginia President
GOALDESC: "On June 18, eight days after Sullivan's resignation, the Board of Visitors met to discuss the presidential situation. Their assumed aim was to appoint an interim president, while students, faculty, staff and community members gathered on the Lawn to support the cause of Sullivan's reinstatement. It was the first major protest.' - http://uvamagazine.org/only_online/article/how_social_media_helped_change_university_history#.Ufmk7I3VDGB
INITDESC: INDIV UVa students, faculty, staff and supporters
OUTDESC: "Great news at #UVA!!! RT @NBC29: #BOV tells crowd that they officially have passed a resolution to reinstate #Sullivan - crowd goes wild", http://uvamagazine.org/only_online/article/how_social_media_helped_change_university_history#.UeXO1Y21F8F
NARR: Reinstate University of Virginia President is a consumer satisfaction campaign aiming to reinstate the fired President of UVA with the initiator(s), students and an individual, based in the USA and the target(s), the Board of UVA, based in the USA. Digital activity consisted of microblogs and an e-petition. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose campaign with many actors. As of May 7, 2013 the campaign is over, having achieved success. Sullivan was reinstated.  KS

TITLE: I am Malala
GOALDESC: "calling on Pakistan to reform its education policy...calling for the rights of all girls to receive an education" - http://mashable.com/2012/10/15/i-am-malala/
INITDESC: FORMAL "U.N. Special Envoy for Global Education Gordon Brown" - http://mashable.com/2012/10/15/i-am-malala/
TARGDESC: "Pakistan" "to Pakistani President Asif Ali Zadari and U.N. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon." - http://mashable.com/2012/10/15/i-am-malala/
SOCNET: "a global community of more than 50,000 have banded together on Facebook to express support for Yousafzai.", http://mashable.com/2012/10/15/i-am-malala/
PARTOFF: "Pakistanis have rallied behind her, organizing a day of prayer, a lawyers' strke and "chains of hope" between cities.", http://mashable.com/2012/10/15/i-am-malala/
OUTDESC: (own words, the campaign is ongoing with no significant policy changeS) "http://mashable.com/2013/07/12/malala-day/"
NARR: I am Malala is a human rights campaign aiming to allow girls to be educated with the initiator(s), Gordon Brown of the UN, based in the USA and the target(s), the Pakistani government based in Pakistan. Digital activity consisted of an e-petition and Facebook page and videos. Offline activity was not present. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formal campaign for an e-petition. As of May 6, 2013, the campaign is ongoing without indication of outcome. KS

TITLE: Sallie Mae: Stop $50 Loan Forbearance Fee
GOALDESC: "against a $50 loan forbearance fee" - http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2012-02-03/business/bal-consuming-interests-sallie-mae-changes-fee-after-online-student-protest-20120203_1_sallie-mae-payments-fee
INITDESC: INDIV "Stef Gray" - http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2012-02-03/business/bal-consuming-interests-sallie-mae-changes-fee-after-online-student-protest-20120203_1_sallie-mae-payments-fee
OUTDESC:
" Sallie Mae will continue to charge the fee. But now, borrowers will get the fees applied to their balance after making six monthsÕ worth of on time payments.

Gray posted online that Sallie Mae changed its tune in less than three hours after her petition was dropped off at the lenderÕs headquarters. But Gray says sheÕs not giving up, because Sallie Mae didnÕt go far enough.

ÒI'm amazed that we've made this kind of progress against a financial behemoth like Sallie Mae, but it's also clear that their action wasn't enough. It does nothing to help borrowers like me who are in real financial trouble. Sallie Mae isn't going to get rid of us by offering weak half-measures.

"If we can keep up the pressure, we can get exactly what we asked for - an end to their greedy unemployment penalty. You can help: please sign my petition and share it with everyone you know right away."" - http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2012-02-03/business/bal-consuming-interests-sallie-mae-changes-fee-after-online-student-protest-20120203_1_sallie-mae-payments-fee
NARR: Sallie Mae: Stop $50 Loan Forbearance Fee is an Economic Justice campaign aiming to stop the unemployment fee imposed by the private student loan company Sallie Mae. Initiator is a single individual, she and the target are in the USA. Digital activity consisted of an online petition that reached 78 thousands signatures. There is no information of offline participation because the company announced its change in decision only 3 hours after the protest started.  This is a single initiator campaign amplified by a crowd. As of June 03, 2013 the campaign has partially achieved its goals, because Sallie Mae did not eliminate the fee but committed to divide it in six monthly payments when the persons start to pay again. LS

NARR: Against Firing of Journalist Change Ping is an information and expression campaign aiming to protest tight media restrictions and one journalist's firing. TARGDESC: " dozens of academics and women's rights activists took to the streets of Kabul to protest the delay in government investigation into the case of Shakila, a 16-year-old girl who had been reportedly raped and murdered [fa] last year in Afghanistan's Bamyan Province.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/06/afghanistan-girls-murder-sparks-anger-and-protests/

NARR: Justice for Shakila campaign is aimed to demand justice and make sure that Shakila's murderer does not go unpunished. The campaign can best be described as an informal network of offline protests loosely coordinated by some human rights organizations.  As of May 19, 2013 there is not information on goal achievement and the campaign is still ongoing. [no author indicated]

TITLE: Tomato Revolution
GOALDESC: "to protest low-quality law texts bringing only misfortunes to the society and the Bulgarian citizen. The law should be socially useful, not crafted against the people.", "against the uncritical attitude in signing the decrees of laws coming into force." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/25/bulgaria-the-rise-of-homo-domaticus/
INITDESC: INDIV "people gathered in front of the Bulgarian Parliament in the capital city of Sofia, thus officializing what has become known as the ‘Tomato Revolution.’", "Nikolay Kolev, aka Bossiya (The Barefoot), published an open letter [bg] on his blog, openly threatening to throw tomatoes at the government buildings, " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/25/bulgaria-the-rise-of-homo-domaticus/
TARGDESC: "he held the Bulgarian officials responsible for the rampant corruption in the country. The letter was sent to the Parliament, the President, the Prime Minister, the Supreme Judicial Council, the Bulgarian National Television and the Bulgarian National Radio." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/25/bulgaria-the-rise-of-homo-domaticus/
PARTOFF: " 300-400 people are attending."  - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/25/bulgaria-the-rise-of-homo-domaticus/

NARR: Tomato Revolution is a democracy and rule of law campaign aiming to protest Bulgarian government corruption with the initiator(s), Nikolay Kolev and thousands of other Bulgarian citizens, based in Bulgaria and the target(s), the Bulgarian government. Digital activity consisted of a livestream video, a Facebook page, blogs, and use of Twitter. Offline activity consisted of individual and massive protests in Sofia, Bulgaria. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose group of people who are angry with the government. As of May 19, 2013 the campaign is not successful because it has failed to create any sort of government response beyond arrests. DS

Despite the ruling, the Coordination of Improvement of Higher Education Personnel (CAPES) and the National Council for Scientific and Technological Development (CNPq) - funding agencies of the program - still allowing the enrollment of students in this area." - http://veja.abril.com.br/noticia/educacao/ciencia-sem-fronteiras-aceita-inscricoes-de-estudantes-de-humanidades

The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formal campaign to reverse a government decision. As of May 19, 2013 the campaign has achieved success--the program is still accepting student from the humanities. KS

TITLE: Defending the Right of Students to Photocopy
GOALDESC: "the legalisation of the use of photocopies for educational purposes." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/10/11/costa-rica-students-protest-veto-of-photocopying-law/
INITDESC: INDIV "Thousands of students participated in a march in San José on Tuesday, October 9, 2012, protesting for their right" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/10/11/costa-rica-students-protest-veto-of-photocopying-law/
TARGDESC: "We really need the lawmakers to examine their conscience, to listen to the new generation and reapprove the Bill regarding Photocopying for Studying on a unanimous basis." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/10/11/costa-rica-students-protest-veto-of-photocopying-law/
PARTOFF: "Thousands of students participated in a march in San José on Tuesday, October 9, 2012" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/10/11/costa-rica-students-protest-veto-of-photocopying-law/
OUTDESC: "Costa Rica’s ongoing dispute over its Intellectual Property Law may finally have come to an end this week, with the signing on Monday of a presidential decree that protects businesses that photocopy academic materials." - http://www.ticotimes.net/Business/Presidential-decree-ends-photocopying-row_Friday-October-26-2012
NARR: Defending the Right of Students to Photocopy is an information and expression campaign aimed at overturning a presidential veto of a educational-photocopying law, with the initiators, students, based in Costa Rica and the target, President Chinchilla, also based in Costa Rica. Digital activity consisted of 6,624 Facebook page likes, 123 tweets, and blogs. Offline activity consisted of a protest in San Jose, Costa Rica, with "thousands" of participants. The structure of the campaign appears to be a grassroots effort led by students in San Jose and augmented by social media. As of July 2, 2013, the campaign has achieved  success, since President Chinchilla signing a decree that protects photocopying businesses. JL

TITLE: Together for a Change! We Want a Real Democracy!
GOALDESC: "The demonstrators demand an immediate resignation of the centre-right government and a halt to the government-sponsored reforms aimed at savings with the aim of decreasing the state budget deficit below 3 percent of GDP." - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1742-CTK-National-News-Wire.docx

HACK: "Activists of Anonymous have blocked the web pages of Czech parties in parliament" "The web pages of the senior government Civic Democrats (ODS) and of the opposition Social Democrats (CSSD) and Communists (KSCM) were also out of operation." - http://digital-activism.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/1742-CTK-National-News-Wire.docx

OUTDESC: Government does not appear to have resigned but "Czech Prime Minister Petr Necas said Wednesday his centre-right government would be steering away from austerity to focus on economic growth. “We managed to bring the deficit down to under 3% of gross domestic product,”" - http://www.bbj.hu/economy/austerity-driven-czech-republic-to-focus-on-growth-_65673
NARR: Together for a Change! We Want a Real Democracy! is a Democracy and rule of Law campaign.  It is aimed to demand the resignation of the centre-right government and to stop national austerity policies. The initiator(s), are individuals, supported by an informal organizations in Prague, Czech Republic.  Digital activity consisted of blocking websites (hacking) of the political parties in the parliament. Offline activity is a camp-protest with around 100 people in Prague.  The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loosely organized campaign (similar to occupy movement).  As of 0June 3, 2011 the campaign has partially achieved its goals, because the government stopped the austerity policies but did not resign from office. LS

TITLE: Calling Egyptian Government to Switch to Open Source
GOALDESC: "A group of organisations, companies and high-profile individuals have released a statement calling for a protest on Sunday in front of the Cabinet in Cairo, in response to a recent government decision to purchase Microsoft software licenses and products to upgrade government agencies. Under the name Open Egypt, the signees demand the government re-evaluate their deal.", http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2012/12/28/open-source-movement-to-protest-microsoft-deal/
INITDESC: FORMAL, "A group of organisations, companies and high-profile individuals have released a statement calling for a protest on Sunday in front of the Cabinet in Cairo, in response to a recent government decision to purchase Microsoft software licenses and products to upgrade government agencies. Under the name Open Egypt, the signees demand the government re-evaluate their deal., http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2012/12/28/open-source-movement-to-protest-microsoft-deal/
TARGDESC: " the signees demand the government re-evaluate their deal", http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2012/12/28/open-source-movement-to-protest-microsoft-deal/
PARTOFF: "The vigil is scheduled to commence on Sunday at 11 in the morning in front of the Cabinet. ", http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2012/12/28/open-source-movement-to-protest-microsoft-deal/
OUTDESC: "Last year, when the Egyptian government decided to renew and upgrade Microsoft software licenses for a cost exceeding 43 millions dollars, Egyptian IT activists and specialists called the decision a waste of money and asked the government to use free open source software (FOSS) instead. The protest has lead the Egyptian government to decide at the beginning of this year to switch all government agencies to Open Source, and overall promote the use of open source in the country. According to Read more [...]", http://www.siliconafrica.com/tag/egypt-open-source/
NARR: Calling Egyptian Government to Switch to Open Source campaign initiated by a group of organizations, companies and high-profile individuals in Egypt.  Digital activism consisted of an online petition, twitter hashtag and a Facebook "event" page. Offline activity consisted on a vigil in front of the Cabinet. The structure of the campaign is a loose network of organizations and individuals which were trying to institutionalize the "open Egypt" movement into a NGO. As of May 19, 2013 the protest has lead the Egyptian government to decide to switch all government agencies to Open Source, and overall promote the use of open source in the country. [no author indicated]

TITLE: "Les Pigeons" vs. French Tax Hike
GOALDESC: "calling on the government for months to stop plans that would increase their tax burden." - http://techpresident.com/news/23052/frances-first-social-media-campaign-forces-government-roll-back-proposed-tax-increases
INITDESC: INFORMAL "The campaign began with an opinion piece published on September 28 in the French business daily La Tribune by venture capitalist Jean-David Chamboredon, the leader of an IT investors' lobbying group called France Digitale." - http://www.francedigitale.org/left-sidebar-page/
SOCNET: "This article would have gone unnoticed had it not been for a dedicated Facebook page, introduced on September 28 by the founders of young internet start-ups such as Whoozer and Yopps to share their indignation." - http://techpresident.com/news/23052/frances-first-social-media-campaign-forces-government-roll-back-proposed-tax-increases
OUTDESC: "In a practically unprecedented instance of a social media campaign affecting government policy in France, les pigeons were successful: President François Hollande’s government rolled back its planned tax hike." - http://techpresident.com/news/23052/frances-first-social-media-campaign-forces-government-roll-back-proposed-tax-increases
NARR: "Les Pigeons" vs. French Tax Hike is an economic justice campaign aiming to protest the French government's tax hike, with the initiator(s), Les Pigeons which is a group of young Internet entrepreneurs, based in France and the target(s), the French gov't. Digital activity consisted of a Twitter hashtag, a Facebook group, videos, and blogs. No offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a relatively organized network of young internet entrepreneurs and other mostly French citizens. As of May 19, 2013 the campaign is completely successful, as the French President rolled back its proposed tax hike. DS

TITLE: Supporting Recognition of French Minority Languages
GOALDESC: "Participants called for the endorsement of the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages [en]. Even though the treaty was signed by France in 1999, it has never been ratified.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/04/11/france-taking-a-stand-for-regional-languages/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "The participating associations are asking the presidential candidates to take a stand on the status of regional languages. As of today, regional languages are considered unconstitutional because the French State doesn't recognize minorities.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/04/11/france-taking-a-stand-for-regional-languages/
PARTOFF: "several simultaneous events took place in France's major cities, driven by the overarching goal of showing an unfailing support to regional as well as indigenous languages.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/04/11/france-taking-a-stand-for-regional-languages/
OUTDESC: "François Hollande, France’s new President, has promised to ratify the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages, guaranteeing protection and active support for regional languages in Europe", http://eucenterillinois-language.blogspot.com/2012/07/frances-new-president-to-ratify.html
NARR: Supporting Recognition of French Minority Languages is an ethnic and immigrant rights campaign aiming to get the French president to ratify the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages. The campaign was initiated by French minority language speakers throughout the country. Digital activity consisted of tweeting, videos, blogging, and media coverage. Offline activity consisted of protests and demonstrations in Toulouse, Quimper, Strasbourg, Bayonne, Perpignan, and Ajaccio, France. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an online-organized physical demonstration by a loosely organized coalition of minority language-rights activists. As of 19 May 2013, the campaign had been achieved, because French president Francois Hollande promised to ratify the charter. RM

TITLE: Stop the Badger Cull
GOALDESC: "Critics of the cull, which was supported by farmers, said it would be ineffective, not least because fleeing badgers would simply spread the disease beyond the pilot areas in southwest England where it had been due to begin shortly.", http://www2.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=587cce2f-c0a1-45c4-b8b0-72dcb6864a5a
INITDESC: INDIV, "Public opposition to the cull has been widespread, with more than 150,000 people signing an online protest petition initiated by former Queen guitarist Brian May", http://www2.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=587cce2f-c0a1-45c4-b8b0-72dcb6864a5a
EPET: "with more than 150,000 people signing an online protest petition initiated by former Queen guitarist Brian May" - http://www2.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=587cce2f-c0a1-45c4-b8b0-72dcb6864a5a
OUTDESC: "Britain has delayed a plan to shoot thousands of badgers to stop the spread of tuberculosis in cattle in the face of overwhelming public opposition to the cull.", http://www2.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=587cce2f-c0a1-45c4-b8b0-72dcb6864a5a
NARR: Stop the Badger Cull is an environmental protection campaign aiming to stop the cull of British badgers with the initiator(s), formal organizations and former Queen guitarist Brian May, based in   Britain and the target(s), Environment Secretary, based in Britain. Digital activity consisted of an online protest petition. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose network of individuals as well as a formal coalition of organizations to fight the planned cull of badgers. As of May 19, 2013, the campaign is partially achieved since Environment Secretary Owen Paterson has delayed a plan for the cull. SL

Digital activity consisted of social networks and microblogs and a blog. Offline activity consisted of protests and hunger strikes. As of May 18, 2013 the campaign is ongoing having achieved partial success (the release of Hana Shalabi). KS

TITLE: Against Athletic Honor for Rapist Ched Evans
GOALDESC: ""Over 5000 people have signed an online petition to remove footballer Ched Evans from an end-of-season honours list following his conviction for raping a 19-year-old woman", http://www.itv.com/news/wales/2012-04-30/petition-over-evans-season-honour/

TITLE: Don't Raise Darlington Ticket Prices

SITE: "Angry Darlington fans have set up an online protest" – http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/10015601.Fans_plan_boycott_as_non_league_club_hikes_admission_price/?ref=rss

TITLE: For Indigenous Rights in Guatemala
GOALDESC: "defend their lands, protest forced relocations, and call attention to other issues affecting rural communities." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/29/guatemala-indigenous-and-rural-communities-march-to-defend-their-land/
INITDESC: "Thousands of Guatemalan indigenous people and campesinos (countrymen) participated in a nine-day march", "Organized by the Comite de Unidad Campesino, (CUC) [Committee for Campesino Unity] the march demands" - http://www.cuc.org.gt/es/index.php?option=com_contact&view=contact&id=3&Itemid=71
TARGDESC: "demands the attention of the State of Guatemala, as well as local, national, and international media to the issues facing the rural Indigenous and campesino majority of the country." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/29/guatemala-indigenous-and-rural-communities-march-to-defend-their-land/
PARTOFF: "Thousands of Guatemalan indigenous people and campesinos (countrymen) participated in a nine-day march " - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/03/29/guatemala-indigenous-and-rural-communities-march-to-defend-their-land/

NARR: For Indigenous Rights in Guatemal is a rights of ethnic minorities and immigrants campaign aiming to defend against forced relocations with the initiator(s), a formal organization called Comite de Unidad Campesino and thousands of individuals, based in Guatemala and the target(s), the State of Guatemala. Digital activity consisted of use of a website, an online map, and a blog. Offline activity consisted of large protest marches in Guatemala. The structure of the campaign can best be described as well structured, behind one major organization, that publicizes the plight of thousands of individuals who participate in offline mobilization. As of May 19, 2013 the campaign is unsuccessful, since there appears to be no response from the Guatemalan government. DS

TITLE: Against Chris Brown Concert in Guyana

The structure of the campaign can best be described as an outcrying of protest from prominent bloggers without a formal campaign structure. As of May 18, 2013 the campaign is over, having achieved success when Chris Brown withdrew from his scheduled performance. KS

TITLE: Against National Education Program in Hong Kong
GOALDESC: "demand the national education curriculum be withdrew" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/03/hong-kong-national-education-program-prompts-hunger-strike-sit-in/
INITDESC: INFORMAL "Three elementary school students from Scholarism, an activist group against the implementation of the controversial national education program, started a three-day hunger strike on August 30," - http://scholarism.com/%E9%97%9C%E6%96%BC%E6%88%91%E5%80%91/
TARGDESC: "The government should not further delay in withdrawing the national education curriculum. CY Leung's government should respond to our demands, to public opinion"
PARTOFF: "more than 90,000 people took to the street ", "There were more than 8,000 protestors at around 7pm this evening"
OUTDESC: "The government of former U.K. colony Hong Kong – part of China since 1997 – has backed down from a plan to make elementary schools teach Chinese patriotism to students, according to reports." - http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/09/08/13745338-hong-kong-backs-down-on-plan-to-make-kids-learn-chinese-patriotism?lite
NARR: Against National Education Program in Hong Kong is a education campaign opposed to a national education program, with the initiator, an activist group called Scholarism, based in Hong Kong and the target, the Hong Kong Central People's Government, also based in Hong Kong. Digital activity consisted of over 167 thousand Facebook page likes and a blog posting. Offline activity consisted of at least 8,000 protestors and ten hunger strikers. The structure of the campaign appears to be a grassroots effort led by a well-organized informal activist group. As of June 25, 2013, the campaign has been completely successful, since the Hong Kong government dropped the proposed changes. JL

TITLE: Opposition to University Fees in Hungary
GOALDESC: "Hundreds of Hungarian students have taken to the streets to protest against these ‘student contracts’ (an English-language sample [.pdf] is here) – as well as against the significant cutbacks in higher education admission quotas (in 2011, the undergraduate quota was 40,610 students; in 2012 – 33,927 students).", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/13/students-rally-all-over-hungary-to-save-tuition-free-education/
INITDESC: FORMAL, "The current protests [hu] in Budapest and other big cities were organized by the grassroots student union called Hallgatói Hálózat (“Network of Students”) or HaHa, the National Union of Students (HÖOK), the Network of Academics (Oktatói Hálózat, OHA), the Network for the Freedom of Curriculum (Hálózat a Tanszabadságért, HAT) and the Network of Parents (Szül?i Hálózat).", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/13/students-rally-all-over-hungary-to-save-tuition-free-education/
TARGDESC: "The protests began on Monday, Dec. 10, and have so far continued through Thursday, following the government's announcement [hu] that in 2013 it would provide state-financed education to only 10,480 undergraduate students.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/13/students-rally-all-over-hungary-to-save-tuition-free-education/
PARTOFF: "Hundreds of Hungarian students have taken to the streets to protest against these ‘student contracts", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/13/students-rally-all-over-hungary-to-save-tuition-free-education/
OUTDESC: "Hungary's minister of human resources signed an agreement with the organization representing college students on Monday, ending weeks of protest demonstrations over government cuts in college, university and student funding.", http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90777/8102891.html
NARR: Opposition to University Fees in Hungary is a education campaign aiming to protest the government's decision to cut education funding with the initiator(s), students, based in Hungary and the target(s), the government based in Hungary. Digital activity consisted of Facebook and blogs.  Offline activity consisted of rallies and a sit in. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a coalition of students. As of May 24, 2013, the campaign is over after the government repealed the promised cuts. KS

TITLE: Against New Hungarian Constitution
GOALDESC: "The purpose of the January 2 rally was to speak up against the new constitution designed by the governing Fidesz and KDNP parties.:, http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/01/10/hungary-hey-europe-sorry-about-my-prime-minister/
INITDESC: FORMAL, "Non-governmental organizations, civil movements and some opposition parties allied for the time of the protest to demonstrate that opposing the government's politics results in joint forces.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/01/10/hungary-hey-europe-sorry-about-my-prime-minister/
TARGDESC: "The current government has buried only one interpretation of democracy, it was the parliamentary democracy...", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/01/10/hungary-hey-europe-sorry-about-my-prime-minister/
PARTOFF: "Although the rallies are growing more and more frequent, we confine this coverage to the protest that took place last Monday 2 January, presenting some Hungarian citizens’ views on the event.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/01/10/hungary-hey-europe-sorry-about-my-prime-minister/
OUTDESC: "In March 2013, Parliament amended the constitution for the fourth time, on a 265-11 vote, with Fidesz, the Christian Democrats and three independents in favor and the Socialists boycotting the vote; there were also 33 abstentions.[45][46] Subsequently, President János Áder signed the amendment into law, citing his legal duty and the need to preserve national unity.[47][48] The fifteen-page amendment touches on several aspects. It annuls rulings of the Constitutional Court made before the 2011 constitution went into force, while allowing their legal effects to remain. I", http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Hungary#2013_amendment
NARR: Against New Hungarian Constitution is a democracy campaign aiming to protest a new constitution with the initiator(s), formal, informal and individuals, based in Hungary and the target(s), government, based in Hungary. Digital activity consisted of blogs. Offline activity consisted of protests. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formal protest coalition. As of June 6, 2013 the campaign is over, without success as the constitution was enacted. KS

TITLE: Stop Honey Singh's Performance
GOALDESC: "An online petition and a twitter campaign against 28-year-old rapper Honey Singh ...."extremely vulgar and indecent songs". Thakur said in the FIR that the rapper's misogynistic and deeply troubling lyrics ", https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0AlqhPVifdtycdFktSER3dEQwWmUxZjE1dnc3cVdZM1E#gid=10
INITDESC: INDIV, "The Internet petition against Singh was started by Delhi-based writer Kalpana Misra, who believes the lyrics of some of his songs are 'pornographic,' 'unacceptable,' and grossly misogynistic.", http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-01-01/india/36093628_1_honey-singh-organisers-online-petition
TARGDESC: "GM of The Bristol Hotel Gurgaon India " (Petition) http://www.change.org/en-IN/petitions/gm-of-the-bristol-hotel-gurgaon-india-stop-honey-singh-s-performance
MICBLOG: "the social networking site Twitter was abuzz over the same issue, with Honey Singh's Gurgaon gig becoming a trending topic.", http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-01-01/india/36093628_1_honey-singh-organisers-online-petition
OUTDESC: "An online petition and a twitter campaign against 28-year-old rapper Honey Singh led to a New Year's Eve concert by him at Gurgaon's Bristol hotel being cancelled at the last minute.", http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-01-01/india/36093628_1_honey-singh-organisers-online-petition
NARR: Stop Honey Singh's Performance is an entertainment and fandom campaign by Indian citizens aiming to stop a New Year's Eve performance by Indian rapper Honey Singh. Digital activity consisted of Twitter activity and an e-petition. There was no offline activity. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a grassroots, crowd-sourced effort. As of 19 May 2013, the campaign was successful, because the organization hosting Singh's performance canceled the show and cited the online protest as a main reason. RM

TITLE: Israelis Oppose Their Governments Attacks on Gaza
GOALDESC: " oppose this operation." - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/18/israelis-protest-military-operation-against-gaza/

NARR: "Israelis Oppose Their Governments Attacks on Gaza" is a campaign opposing violence and armed conflict and aiming to "refuse to die or kill" for political ends, with the initiator, a Facebook group based in Israel, and the targets, Benjamin Netanyahu and Hamas, based in Israel and Palestine. The structure of the campaign can best be described as an ad-hoc collection of individuals who formed a Facebook group. As of May 19, 2013, the campaign has not been successful, since the group has received no response or action based on their demands. JL

TITLE: Demanding Respect for Human Rights of Italian Prisoners
GOALDESC: "[against] living conditions in Italian prisons and to demand that measures are adopted to reduce the numbers of prisoners and to give them the right to vote" - http://globalvoicesonline.org/2013/01/05/italy-iostoconmarco-hunger-strike-against-inhuman-jail-conditions/

NARR: Demanding Respect for Human Rights of Italian Prisoners is a human rights campaign aiming to improve conditions in Italian prisons with the initiator(s), an individuals, based in Italy and the target(s), the italian government based in Italy. Digital activity consisted of Twitter and Facebook and blogs. Offline activity consisted of a hunger strike. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formalized campaign based around the actions of an individual. As of May 19, 2013 the campaign has achieved partial success, with a court ruling that prison conditions are a violation of human rights.  No information was available about how the Italian prison system responded.  KS

TITLE: Close Ilva Steel Plant
GOALDESC: "We accuse the political leadership to be accomplice of an environmental and social disaster that for fifty years....We demand that whoever is responsible this tragedy, the state first, and then the Riva family, pay for the disaster they created.....We, the workers of Ilva, demand our full salary even if Ilva has to be closed for ten years for the requalification process.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/17/italy-uncertain-future-for-polluting-ilva-steel-plant-and-its-12000-employees/
INITDESC: FORMAL, "The committee, together with the main local unions, organised a rally on August 2", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/17/italy-uncertain-future-for-polluting-ilva-steel-plant-and-its-12000-employees/
TARGDESC: ".We demand that whoever is responsible this tragedy, the state first, and then the Riva family, pay for the disaster they created", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/17/italy-uncertain-future-for-polluting-ilva-steel-plant-and-its-12000-employees/
PARTOFF: " close to 1,000  people took the streets to acknowledge worker Cataldo", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/17/italy-uncertain-future-for-polluting-ilva-steel-plant-and-its-12000-employees/
OUTDESC: "taly's top court said on Tuesday that a government law to save the crisis-hit ILVA steel plant does not flout the constitution and so production at the factory can continue.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/08/17/italy-uncertain-future-for-polluting-ilva-steel-plant-and-its-12000-employees/
NARR: Close Ilva Steel Plant is an economic justice campaign aiming to demand that the owners and directors of Ilva pay for the damage they caused with the initiator(s), workers, based in Italy and the target(s), the government and the Riva family based in Italy. Digital activity consisted of online protests based on Facebook groups. Offline activity consisted of a rally in the city of Taranto, Italy. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a formal coalition of citizens and workers who formed a committee that organizes a rally. As of May 19, 2013, the campaign is not achieved since Italy's top court said on Tuesday that a government law to save the crisis-hit ILVA steel plant does not flout the constitution and so production at the factory can continue. SL

SITE: "Disillusioned fans created a website entitled "We demand the truth from T-ara" and by Wednesday had attracted some 330,000 subscribers." - http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iDqoZAQ_JCSzfNwFJur4Hb5g7ZkA?docId=CNG.0b67f7c4205c3f353e5518efce3d9848.c21

OUTDESC: "Core Content Media's CEO, Kim Kwang-soo, claimed that Hwayoung's contract was terminated "in deference to the complaints by T-ara's staff of nineteen people,". He has also stated that the bullying controversy was not the reason for her departure." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-ara
NARR: We Demand the Truth from T-ara is a fan and entertainment campaign aiming to understand why a member of a K-Pop group was fired with the initiator(s), unhappy fans, based in Korea and the target(s), the group T-ara based in Korea. Digital activity consisted of Twitter use and a website, with an online petition. Offline activity consisted of fans leaving fan clubs. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a coalition of actors. As of May 19, 2013 the campaign is over, with the singer having left the group. KS

TITLE: Stop LIRA!
GOALDESC: "The anti-Lebanese Internet Regulation Act (LIRA) movement, dubbed #stopLIRA on Twitter and elsewhere snowballed online in record time to halt the retrograde legislation that would have required journalists and bloggers to register their sites with the Ministry of Information.", http://www.huffingtonpost.com/magda-abufadil/lebanese-internet-regulation-act_b_1412276.html
INITDESC: FORMAL, "The Maharat Foundation, a press freedom and civil society NGO was quick to condemn the draft as it has been working closely with member of parliament Ghassan Moukheiber to update what already exists on the book", http://www.huffingtonpost.com/magda-abufadil/lebanese-internet-regulation-act_b_1412276.html
OUTDESC: No information, it looks an ongoing campaign
NARR: Stop LIRA! is an information and expression campaign aiming to stop Lebanese Internet Regulation Act with the initiator(s), cyber activists and bloggers, based in Lebanon and the target(s), Lebanon's Information Minister Walid El Daouk and the Ministry of Information. Digital activity consisted of the use of Twitter hashtag and blog posting. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose network of cyber activists and bloggers as well as a tight coalition of NGO to support their activism. As of May 19, 2013, the campaign is achieved since Ayman Mhanna, executive director of the Samir Kassir Foundation said "Right now, LIRA is no longer on the agenda." SL

Digital activity consisted of a Facebook group and some Twitter activity, some blogs and a video. No tangible offline activity (only hinted at the possibility). The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loose but large group of protesters, collected by a Facebook group, posting on personal blogs and twitter feeds. As of May 19, 2013 the campaign is partially successful, as the ruling political party has publicly voiced support for this. DS

TITLE: Against King's Budget in Morocco

INITDESC: INDIV, "Moroccans protested in the capital Rabat against the royal budget on November 18, 2012", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/11/18/moroccans-beaten-up-for-protesting-the-kings-budget/

NARR: Against King's Budget in Morocco is an economic justice campaign aiming to reduce personal spending by the king of Morocco. It was initiated by unemployed Moroccan youth. Digital activity consisted of Twitter use. Offline activity consisted of a protest in Rabat, Morocco. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a loosely organized crowd of protestors. As of 19 May 2013, the campaign is unsuccessful because protestors never even made it to the capitol building, and the budget was passed without government officials hearing their demands. RM

GOALDESC: "heading towards the so-called ‘Supervía Poniente‘ (Poniente Super-road) [es] in protest at the construction of the latter...[they] argue that the works will have a serious environmental impact.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/01/mexico-bike-ride-protest-clashes-with-local-government/
INITDESC: INFORMAL, " a group of cyclists, among them a civic organisation named Bicitekas [es], organised a bike ride", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/05/01/mexico-bike-ride-protest-clashes-with-local-government/

NARR: Against Superhighway Construction is a anti-construction campaign aiming to stop construction of a super highway with the initiator(s), a formal group, based in Mexico and the target(s), the government based in Mexico. As of June 7, 2013 the campaign is over, without success, as the road is under construction. KS

TITLE: Opposing Oaxaca Wind Farm
GOALDESC: "largely indigenous opposition to wind farms in the Isthmus of Tehuantepec of Oaxaca", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/27/mexico-federal-court-halts-controversial-wind-park/
INITDESC: FORMAL, "The largely indigenous opposition to wind farms in the Isthmus of Tehuantepec of Oaxaca, Mexico.... the indigenous Ikojts (Huave) peoples of the Isthmus of Tehuantepec celebrated and called for government and industry to comply with the decision, their grassroots struggle continues.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/27/mexico-federal-court-halts-controversial-wind-park/
TARGDESC: "The largely indigenous opposition to wind farms in the Isthmus of Tehuantepec of Oaxaca, Mexico.... the indigenous Ikojts (Huave) peoples of the Isthmus of Tehuantepec celebrated and called for government and industry to comply with the decision, their grassroots struggle continues.", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/27/mexico-federal-court-halts-controversial-wind-park/
PARTOFF: "Several groups have mobilized to protest" (around few hundred people), http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/27/mexico-federal-court-halts-controversial-wind-park/
OUTDESC: "The largely indigenous opposition to wind farms in the Isthmus of Tehuantepec of Oaxaca, Mexico won a tremendous victory on 7 December 2012 when a District Seven Federal Court judge granted an injunction (amparo) temporarily halting the construction of a controversial wind park in San Dioniosio del Mar in the southern state of Oaxaca. The judge, located in Salina Cruz, ruled that ”based on article 233 of the Injunction Law, this unequivocally orders the suspension of the challenged actions as being in violation of the land rights of the community.”", http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/12/27/mexico-federal-court-halts-controversial-wind-park/
NARR:
Opposing Oaxaca Wind Farm is a rights of ethnic minorities and immigrants campaign aiming to stop the construction of a controversial wind park with the initiator(s), indigenous communities, based in Mexico and the target(s), government and industry based in Mexico. Digital activity consisted of the use of blogs, Facebook page, and YouTube video. Offline activity consisted of protests and resistance in in the wind-rich regions of Oaxaca. The structure of the campaign can best be described as a tight network of indigenous communities, which results in a series of violent confrontations in the region between local protestors, industry, and state police.
As of May 19, 2013, the campaign is not achieved since the government and wind industry continue the construction while ignoring the requests of Huave peoples of the Isthmus to end the San Dionisio project altogether. SL
